Title: W.P. Productions, Inc. v. Tramontina U.S.A., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law, when a shareholder knows a company has dissolved and continues to move corporate money around, the shareholder, by default, is using the corporate form for the improper purpose of violating Florida's statutory Rule of Priorities, which prohibits corporations from making distributions to shareholders if doing so would make the corporation unable to pay its debts as they become due, so as to provide support for piercing the corporate veil. Fla. Stat. Ann. § 607.06401(3)(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation's sole shareholder used corporate form for improper purpose of evading Florida's Rule of Priorities, supporting piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: W.P. Productions, Inc. v. Tramontina U.S.A., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law, sole shareholder of S corporation, which was a judgment debtor, used the corporate form for improper purpose of evading Florida's statutory Rule of Priorities, which prohibited corporation from making distributions to shareholders if doing so would make the corporation unable to pay its debts as they became due, and thus judgment creditor could pierce corporate veil and hold shareholder personally liable; after corporation's dissolution, shareholder moved money from his shared personal and corporate account, which undermined ability of corporation's creditors to recover, and although shareholder claimed that the money he spent came from his personal funds, his payment of taxes did not indicate his amount of personal funds. Fla. Stat. Ann. §§ 607.06401(3)(a), 607.1420(5).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation's sole shareholder used corporate form for improper purpose of evading Florida's Rule of Priorities, supporting piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: O'Mahony v. Whiston
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Majority owners of corporation that owned old bar were personally liable for repaying an $86,000 loan minority owner made to corporation, under a veil piercing theory, in derivative action brought by minority owners of corporation against majority owners, alleging that majority owners used old corporation's assets to open new bar under new corporation, where majority owners had completely dominated corporation, abused its corporate formalities, and stripped it of all value, transferring money to themselves so that old corporation was an empty shell and unable to repay the loan.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Derivative Actions. Majority owners of corporation were liable for breach of fiduciary duty in form of misappropriation of corporate opportunity, in derivative action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Coast-to-Coast Produce, LLC v. Lakeside Produce USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, allegations by commercial wholesale produce distributors that Canadian produce company owned United States Produce Company, that the two entities were led by the same principals, that the entities shared a single PACA license number, that United States company used the same Canadian mailing address as Canadian company, and that companies comingled funds and featured integrated operations, sufficiently alleged that companies may have been mere instrumentalities of each other, as required to support an inference that companies were alter egos of each other, in action against produce companies to enforce distributors' rights under PACA, alleging that companies failed to pay for accepted produce. Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act, 1930 § 1, 7 U.S.C.A. § 499a et seq.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Abstention. Abstention for foreign bankruptcy cases did not apply to produce distributors' action to enforce rights under Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act.

Title: Coast-to-Coast Produce, LLC v. Lakeside Produce USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, allegation by commercial wholesale produce distributors that produce companies based in Canada and the United States misled the distributors regarding their operations and shirked their PACA trust obligations sufficiently alleged that companies engaged in fraudulent conduct, as required to support an inference that companies were alter egos of each other, in action against produce companies to enforce distributors' rights under PACA, alleging that companies failed to pay for accepted produce. Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act, 1930 § 1, 7 U.S.C.A. § 499a et seq.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Abstention. Abstention for foreign bankruptcy cases did not apply to produce distributors' action to enforce rights under Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act.

Title: Coast-to-Coast Produce, LLC v. Lakeside Produce USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, allegations by commercial wholesale produce distributors that produce companies based in Canada and the United States caused distributors $1.3 million in damages were sufficient to allege unjust loss, as required to support an inference that companies were alter egos of each other, in action against produce companies to enforce distributors' rights under PACA, alleging that companies failed to pay for accepted produce. Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act, 1930 § 1, 7 U.S.C.A. § 499a et seq.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Abstention. Abstention for foreign bankruptcy cases did not apply to produce distributors' action to enforce rights under Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act.

Title: Lifetouch National School Studios Inc. v. Oklahoma School Pictures, LLC
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: The alter ego remedy can be employed in a separate action to collect, from one company, a judgment obtained in previous litigation against another company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Triable issues of fact existed as to whether LLC created judgment debtor as an instrumentality to wrongfully obtain clients and business.

Title: Groth v. Ferrante
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil of judgment debtor to reach its shareholders was not warranted, in judgment creditors' action seeking to enforce default judgment; some corporate formalities were observed, including filing of tax returns and holding of annual shareholder meeting, judgment debtor had functioning board of directors, on which one of the judgment creditors served pursuant to corporate resolution, and alleged commingling of personal and corporate assets was based upon one shareholder's infusion of personal funds into judgment debtor to increase its value, rather than upon any improper expenditure of corporate funds for shareholder's personal benefit.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil of judgment debtor to reach shareholders was not warranted in judgment creditors' action seeking to enforce default judgment.

Title: GeoSolutions B.V. v. Sina.com Online
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Dutch tech business and its holding company failed to state a claim against California businesses in action against thirteen businesses, including two located in California, within Chinese conglomerate that operated social media application, arising from joint venture between those entities and plaintiffs, which plaintiffs alleged resulted in misappropriation of their technology; plaintiffs attempted to establish that California businesses were alter egos of some or all of the foreign defendants, but had not established alter ego status, meaning that none of the other conglomerate entities' conduct could be imputed to California businesses, and plaintiffs did not allege that either of the California businesses participated directly in any of the purported misconduct at issue.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Jurisdiction. Dutch tech business and subsidiary did not establish unity between California businesses and any foreign defendant for general jurisdiction purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Howard
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, Miami Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, piercing corporate veil was appropriate to hold Chapter 7 debtor, who was sole owner and operator of entities that creditor had purchased luxury and customized automobiles from, personally liable for any of entities' obligations in connection with claim that debtor did not transfer title of automobiles and treated the sold automobiles as corporate assets; debtor disregarded corporate formalities with respect to his personal obligations as well as disregarded the separateness of his various corporate entities, as he used corporate funds to pay for personal expenses and used the corporate funds of all entities interchangeably.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt arising from debtor's scheme whereby he failed to transfer title of luxury automobile to creditor fell within fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Stephens v. Mike's Transport, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 2.
Headnote: Trucking business was the alter ego or mere instrumentality of judgment debtors, supporting imposition of alter ego liability on business for judgment against debtors, which were a trucking business and its principal; debtor business ceased operating approximately one month after judgment, trucking business was formed one day after debtor business ceased operating, trucking business then "hired" debtor business's principal, both businesses shared same address, and only trucks used by trucking business were those formerly owned or leased by debtor business.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Trucking business was alter ego of judgment debtors and thus liable for judgment.

Title: Small v. Estate of Landesman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Invocation by estate of principal of judgment debtor company, against which judgment creditor had obtained judgment in underlying action, of doctrines of in pari delicto and unclean hands, which were implicated by broader fraud charges surrounding judgment debtor and related investment fund, was not persuasive in determining whether to grant judgment creditor's request to pierce corporate veil and hold principal liable for judgment entered against judgment debtor; criminal charges against judgment creditor had not been finally resolved.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor failed to present sufficient facts to warrant piercing corporate veil to recover judgment from estate of debtor's principal.

Title: Cortland Street Recovery Corp. v. Bonderman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: "No recourse clause" in indenture agreement did not bar judgment creditor's claims against entities and individuals allegedly liable for judgment entered in previous action to collect on contractual obligations to pay certain payment-in-kind (PIK) notes governed by indenture on which judgment debtor had defaulted, given that judgment creditor sufficiently alleged misconduct by those defendants, under an alter ego theory.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. New York law, rather than Luxembourg law, applied to issue of whether corporate veil of judgment debtors should be pieced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: JPV I L.P. v. Koetting
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Difficulty in enforcing a judgment or collecting a debt does not, by itself, constitute an inequitable result for purposes of the alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Insufficient evidence supported finding that managing members made no personal use of any LLC assets, for purposes of alter ego doctrine.

Title: Sikousis Legacy Inc. v. B-Gas Limited
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: A creditor's inability to collect a judgment alone is insufficient to justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Arbitration award-creditors failed to show that award-debtor was the alter ego of its parent company, as would support attachment of vessel.

Title: Arnold v. LME, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Shareholders who will be held personally liable for the corporation's debt must share in some level of culpability for the injustice caused by corporation's inability to pay its debts before corporate veil may be pierced.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Nature and control of owner-operated corporation weighed against piercing the corporate veil, in former employees' action against corporate owners.

Title: BMO Harris Bank N.A. v. Kuskie
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Former president of company, who alleged that company's shareholders declined to inject additional capital into company when it was struggling on one occasion, failed to allege that shareholders also failed to maintain adequate corporate records, failed to observe corporate formalities, or that shareholders siphoned funds from company, and thus, president did not state sufficient claim to justify piercing corporate veil, under Minnesota law, to hold shareholders liable for indemnification as company's alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Bank, which loaned money to company, failed to allege that shareholders who received distributions from company were directors or officers.

Title: Grayiel v. AIO Holdings, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky, Louisville Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, there is no valid basis for precluding a veil piercing action simply because the claim was not part of the original debt collection suit; in some cases, the creditor may know enough to proceed against all potentially liable parties but, in other instances, it may be appropriate to obtain the judgment first and only when it proves uncollectible then seek relief through veil-piercing litigation.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Lender was liable for aiding and abetting tortious conduct, related to scheme to defraud creditors.

Title: F&R Goldfish Corp. v. Furleiter
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Supplier of raw fish alleged that principals of corporate entities that purchased raw fish and owned property where fish was smoked and manufactured dominated the corporate entities and engaged in acts amounting to an abuse of the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against supplier, as required to maintain action seeking to pierce corporate veil to recover against principals on an account stated; supplier alleged that it forgave purchaser's debts in exchange for 40% interest in purchaser, it invested capital and inventory in exchange for 19% interest in property where fish was smoked and manufactured, principals subsequently refused to recognize supplier's interests, and corporate entity that owned property entered into contract to sell property to third party.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fish supplier alleged that owner of purchasing corporation dominated corporate entity and engaged in acts amounting to abuse of corporate form.

Title: Board of Trustees, Sheet Metal Workers' National Pension Fund v. Allure Metal Works, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Judgment creditor sufficiently alleged cause of action to enforce consent judgment against alleged alter ego of judgment debtor based on alter-ego theory; creditor alleged that alleged alter ego shared common officers with debtor, that alleged alter ego at one point occupied debtor's former business premises and acquired certain of its equipment and employees, and that alleged alter ego continued to conduct substantially the same business as debtor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Judgment creditor sufficiently stated cause of action to enforce consent judgment against judgment debtor's alleged alter ego or successor.

Title: In re Fragala
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil of Chapter 7 debtor's corporation was not appropriate under New York law based on debtor's answering state court complaint in his personal capacity in suit brought by creditor-subcontractor seeking to recover payment withheld by corporation for snow removal services because of alleged costs to repair damaged work sites, instead of denying liability for the corporation's debts; creditor named debtor personally as a defendant in the state court complaint and fact that debtor answered the complaint in his individual capacity did not concede personal liability or waive the protections of the corporate form.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt to creditor-subcontractor did not fall within discharge exception for debts obtained by false pretenses, false representation, or actual fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Fragala
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Chapter 7 debtor's failure to register his foreign corporation in Maryland before doing any intrastate, interstate, or foreign business in Maryland did not provide basis to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold debtor personally liable to creditor-subcontractor for payment withheld by corporation for snow removal services because of alleged costs to repair damaged work sites. Md. Code Ann., Corps. & Ass'ns § 7-301.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt to creditor-subcontractor did not fall within discharge exception for debts obtained by false pretenses, false representation, or actual fraud.

Title: Lopez v. Escamilla
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: Holding sole shareholder of judgment debtor corporation liable for judgment entered against debtor, as alter ego of corporation, would not have violated shareholder's due process rights, in action brought by judgment creditor; creditor did not move to summarily add shareholder to judgment, and instead initiated civil action, during which shareholder would have opportunity to answer complaint, engage in discovery, and file pre-trial motions, only shareholder made decisions and controlled corporation's litigation decisions, and creditor made showing that shareholder exclusively controlled corporate litigation decisions. U.S. Const. Amend. 14.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Fact issue regarding whether sole shareholder of judgment debtor corporation was liable as alter ego precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Lopez v. Escamilla
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: Extent to which sole shareholder of corporation had control over whether or not defense was advanced in lawsuit brought by individual against corporation was relevant to determination of whether holding shareholder liable, as alter ego, for judgment entered against corporation would violate shareholder's due process rights, in independent civil action brought by individual against shareholder. U.S. Const. Amend. 14.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Fact issue regarding whether sole shareholder of judgment debtor corporation was liable as alter ego precluded summary judgment.

Title: Highland Crusader Offshore Partners, L.P. v. Celtic Pharma Phinco B.V.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Failure of investment company to satisfy requirements under Bermuda law for piercing corporate veil of issuer and guarantors of notes precluded investment company from bringing claims arising from notes under alter-ego theory, or successor-in-interest theory, against individual and entity, where issuer, guarantors, and defendant entity were either Bermuda entities or subsidiaries of Bermuda entities, their contacts with Bermuda were not minimal, the entities were not controlled from New York, the transactions did not all occur in New York, and defendants gave sufficient notice of Bermuda law's applicability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff did not satisfy Bermuda-law requirements for piercing corporate veil of issuer and guarantors of notes.

Title: Rockefeller v. Statement Services, Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A proceeding to compel the turnover of property owed to a judgment debtor may be maintained under an alter ego theory. N.Y. CPLR § 5225(b).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Debt Collection. Judgment creditor was entitled to sum of $50,265 from judgment debtor in satisfaction of judgment against debtor's president in proceeding to compel turnover of property.

Title: Rockefeller v. Statement Services, Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Judgment creditor was entitled to sum of $50,265, plus statutory interest and attorney fees, from judgment debtor in satisfaction of a judgment against judgment debtor's president in proceeding to compel the turnover of property owed to a judgment debtor; judgment creditor's submission established through a reverse piercing of the corporate veil that president had complete domination over judgment debtor's and that president made multiple unexplained transfers of large sums of money between his joint account with a family member and judgment debtor's account and caused judgment debtor to pay the debts of another judgment debtor, and judgment creditor showed that the transfers of funds impeded his ability to enforce the judgment such that he, and not either judgment debtor or president, was entitled to possession of the funds. N.Y. CPLR § 5225(b).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Debt Collection. Judgment creditor was entitled to sum of $50,265 from judgment debtor in satisfaction of judgment against debtor's president in proceeding to compel turnover of property.

Title: Rockefeller v. Statement Services, Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Judgment creditor was entitled to sum of $200,265, plus statutory interest and attorney fees, from judgment debtor in satisfaction of a judgment against judgment debtor's president in proceeding to compel the turnover of property owed to a judgment debtor; judgment creditor's submissions established through a reverse piercing of the corporate veil that president had complete domination over judgment debtor's and that president made unexplained transfers of large sums of money to and from the account of judgment debtor from his personal accounts and his joint accounts with members of his family shortly before the installment payment was due and caused judgment debtor to pay debts of another debtor, and creditor showed that transfers of funds impeded ability to enforce judgment such that he was entitled to possession of funds. N.Y. CPLR § 5225(b).

Title: In re GTG Solutions, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: A judgment creditor may pursue a third party under an alter ego theory after the judgment creditor's attempts to collect an underlying judgment against the principal debtor have proven unsuccessful.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Bifurcation. Severance of provider's alter ego claim against its customer's owners, as third-party defendants, in action to collect on unpaid invoices, was proper.

Title: In re GTG Solutions, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: While mere fact that a corporation operates as an alter ego does not give rise to a separate and independent cause of action, a party may assert an alter ego theory against a third party in a second suit to collect a judgment.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Bifurcation. Severance of provider's alter ego claim against its customer's owners, as third-party defendants, in action to collect on unpaid invoices, was proper.

Title: Manichaean Capital, LLC v. Exela Technologies, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: Allegations that acquirer was headquartered at same address as company it acquired and later starved of funds, that it had failed to maintain proper business registrations for company, had significantly overlapping personnel with company, had referred to itself and its subsidiaries as one combined enterprise in filings with Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), and required company to obtain its consent before company could pay its own creditors were sufficient for company's former stockholders, as judgment creditors, to state that acquirer failed to observe certain corporate formalities with respect to company, as required to pierce corporate veil and hold acquirer liable for payments due under appraisal judgment. 8 Del. Code § 262.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Reverse piercing of corporate veil was appropriate to hold subsidiaries liable for payments to company's shareholders under appraisal judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Manichaean Capital, LLC v. Exela Technologies, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: Allegations that acquirer knew company it acquired would be required to pay judgment of some sort to company's dissenting stockholders when shareholders sent appraisal demand, that evidence was developed that showed the fair value of company was exponentially greater than price paid in merger, and that, despite evidence, acquirer and its related entities entered into accounts receivable securitization facility under which acquirer pledged receivables of company's subsidiaries to non-parties, despite fact they were not acquirer's to pledge, were sufficient for company's stockholders, as judgment creditors, to state claim that fraud and injustice had resulted and would continue to result from diversion of funds from company, as required to pierce corporate veil and hold acquirer liable for payments due under appraisal judgment. 8 Del. Code § 262.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Reverse piercing of corporate veil was appropriate to hold subsidiaries liable for payments to company's shareholders under appraisal judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Manichaean Capital, LLC v. Exela Technologies, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: Allegations that, under accounts receivable securitization facility under which acquirer of company pledged receivables of company's subsidiaries to non-parties, despite fact they were not acquirer's to pledge, and that managers of subsidiaries knew about company's inadequate capitalization and, knowing certain of their proceeds would otherwise go to company's former stockholders as judgment creditors, they actively diverted assets away from company, that no other stockholders would be adversely affected by piercing corporate veil, that acquirer and subsidiaries agreed to facility without involvement or consent of company, that reverse veil-piercing would serve public convenience expressed in appraisal statute, that stockholders did not engage in wrongful conduct, that reverse veil-piercing would not cause harm to third-party creditors, and that other remedies did not exist at law or equity to enforce charging order against company were sufficient for stockholders to state that subsidiaries were being used to perpetuate fraud or injustice against stockholders, as required to "reverse pierce" corporate veil and hold subsidiaries of company liable for payments due to stockholders under statutory appraisal judgment. 8 Del. Code § 262.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Reverse piercing of corporate veil was appropriate to hold subsidiaries liable for payments to company's shareholders under appraisal judgment.

Title: Manichaean Capital, LLC v. Exela Technologies, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: Charging order obtained by company's former stockholders, in which it sought to obtain payment of appraisal judgment from acquirer of company and its affiliated entities, which reflected that their shares were worth well in excess of what they were offered in merger, did not prohibit stockholders, as judgment creditor, from reverse veil-piercing in order to hold company's subsidiaries liable for payments due to stockholders under statutory appraisal judgment; reverse veil-piercing claim did not rest on or invoke remedy other than charging order but, instead sought judicially sanctioned expansion of entities against whom order could be enforced. 6 Del. Code § 18-703(d).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Reverse piercing of corporate veil was appropriate to hold subsidiaries liable for payments to company's shareholders under appraisal judgment.

Title: Bick v. Legacy Building Maintenance Company LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: Theory of piercing the corporate veil, not theory of agency, applied to lawyer's claim against corporation's president seeking to hold president personally liable for corporation's outstanding debt for legal services provided by lawyer's law firm, where lawyer alleged that president exercised dominion and control over corporation and intentionally undercapitalized corporation for unlawful purpose of avoiding debt to law firm.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil theory applied to claim asserting corporation's president controlled corporation and undercapitalized it for unlawful purpose.

Title: Steadfast Insurance Company v. T.F. Nugent Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Insurer failed to allege domination of company by family of company owners was used to commit a fraud or wrong, as required to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory under New York law in insurer's action seeking to recover money insurer paid to auction house whose painting was damaged in accident involving company employee.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Insurer plausibly alleged painting company's successor was incorporated and created solely to hide business assets of company.

Title: White Plains Plaza Realty, LLC v. Cappelli
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: There was no basis for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil in order to hold individual personally liable for underlying judgment, where judgment creditor failed to establish judgment debtor or individual committed fraud or wrong against judgment creditor.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Judgment debtor's write off of approximately $7.5 million in receivables owed to it by affiliated entities did not constitute conveyance.

Title: G & E Construction, LLC v. Rubicon Construction, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil was unwarranted to hold principal of general contractor that had been administratively dissolved personally liable, with respect to subcontractor's action on account against general contractor; while principal purchased a house and hired general contractor to renovate house, general contractor was paid for its work on principal's house by receiving draws from bank loan, general contractor had been granted a certificate of incorporation, defeating any inference that it had not formed as a corporation, and there was no basis to conclude that failure to comply with corporate formalities, absent evidence of wrongdoing, justified piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was unwarranted to permit general contractor's principal to have been held personally liable by subcontractor.

Title: Butler America, LLC v. Aviation Assurance Company, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: Substantial evidence supported finding that owner of debtor and other entities he controlled were alter egos of debtor, thus warranting amendment of judgment in favor of creditor to add owner and entities as judgment debtors; owner controlled all of the entities and debtor, which all had the same office and shared employees, owner used money paid to staff debtor to pay employees of other entities, money debtor paid to creditor, as well as money debtor paid for its defense of creditor's lawsuit, came from another entity, owner did not observe formalities required for keeping entities separate, debtor was just a shell, as it had no substantial business activity and no income with which to pay its debts, and it would be inequitable to preclude creditor from collecting its judgment by treating debtor as separate entity. Cal. Civ. Proc. Code § 187.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Substantial evidence established that debtor's owner and related entities were its alter egos, warranting amendment of judgment to add them as debtors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Butler America, LLC v. Aviation Assurance Company, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: Creditor was not equitably estopped from denying separate existence between debtor and other entities, which were owned and controlled by same individual, and thus owner and entities could be added to judgment in favor of creditor under alter ego theory; owner was not ignorant of the state of facts, which indicated that only function of debtor was to act as screen to avoid paying creditor, owner was not prejudiced by creditor's reliance on corporate form, owner used corporate form to his advantage and to prejudice of creditor, creditor did not acquiesce in complained-of actions, and owner's conduct in breaching agreement to pay creditor, fraudulently inducing creditor into entering settlement, breaching that agreement, and hiding behind shell entity was unconscionable and could not be aided by equity. Cal. Civ. Proc. Code § 187.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Substantial evidence established that debtor's owner and related entities were its alter egos, warranting amendment of judgment to add them as debtors.

Title: In re Royal Alice Properties, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Allegations in a creditor's complaint, regarding the control exercised by same, common shareholder over debtor and related corporate entity, regarding entities' common officers and/or directors, regarding fact that the different entities were operated out of same office and had records for their different properties that were kept by bookkeeper who also prepared the controlling shareholder's personal income tax returns, regarding debtor's lack of its own bank account and commingling of its and other corporate entity's receipts in shareholder's personal account, regarding fact that all of debtor's income derived from insiders, and regarding failure to observe corporate formalities and undocumented transfers of funds, stated plausible claim to hold debtor liable for acts or omissions of related entity on "single business enterprise" theory.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Common ownership and commingling of funds supported single business enterprise claim against debtor.

Title: In re Royal Alice Properties, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Allegations in creditor's complaint, that collateral proceeds which, pursuant to terms of its contract with entity that was operated as single business enterprise with debtor, should have been held in segregated account for its benefit were instead transferred directly or indirectly to debtor, stated plausible claim to hold debtor liable, on "single business enterprise" theory, for breach of underlying contract.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Common ownership and commingling of funds supported single business enterprise claim against debtor.

Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil of insurance corporation to hold corporation's sole shareholder, and other associated corporate defendants controlled by shareholder, jointly and severally liable for the unpaid judgment against insurance corporation in favor of employee of insurance corporation; although evidence did not support finding that insurance corporation was undercapitalized at all relevant times, insurance corporation was insolvent at the time the judgment debt was incurred, shareholder was in control of all the corporations and on multiple occasions diverted insurance corporation's assets for his personal benefit, the various corporations shareholder controlled did not treat each other as separate entities, and shareholder used insurance corporation to pay off notes, loans, and credit cards of the other corporations he controlled.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil of insurance corporation to hold corporation's sole shareholder liable for unpaid judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Horizontal veil piercing was necessary to avoid injustice, and thus it was appropriate to hold corporations controlled by sole shareholder of insurance corporation jointly and severally liable for the unpaid judgment against insurance corporation in favor of employee of insurance corporation; sole shareholder controlled the corporations, he intermixed and commingled the assets of the corporations, corporations' assets were used to benefit shareholder, personally, and each other, and shareholder disregarded the corporate entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil of insurance corporation to hold corporation's sole shareholder liable for unpaid judgment.

Title: Arben Corporation v. Durastone, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A judgment creditor may commence a proceeding, pursuant to statute governing payment or delivery of property of judgment debtor, seeking to enforce a default judgment against an alleged successor in interest of a judgment debtor under an alter ego theory. N.Y. CPLR § 5225(b).
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. Judgment creditor could not enforce judgment against alleged alter egos of judgment debtor.

Title: Arben Corporation v. Durastone, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Judgment creditor could not enforce judgment, obtained in underlying breach of contract action, against alleged alter egos of judgment debtor, in proceeding under statute governing payment or delivery of property of judgment debtor, where judgment creditors did not allege that money or assets were transferred from judgment debtor to alleged alter egos or that alleged alter egos were actually in possession of money or assets in which judgment creditor had an interest. N.Y. CPLR § 5225(b).
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. Judgment creditor could not enforce judgment against alleged alter egos of judgment debtor.

Title: Lopez v. Escamilla
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: Judgment creditor could seek to have debtor's principal found liable under alter ego theory either by motion to amend judgment or through separate complaint. Cal. Civ. Code § 3528.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. Creditor could seek alter ego liability of debtor's principal either through motion to amend judgment or through separate complaint.

Title: Dill v. Rembrandt Group, Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division VI.
Headnote: The mere fact that corporate creditors would go unsatisfied because they cannot reach a shareholder's personal assets does not, alone, justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Horizontal veil piercing was not supported where no evidence supported finding that sister corporations were alter egos of common owners.

Title: In re L. Scott Apparel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: To establish an alter ego relationship under California law, a plaintiff must show that an injustice would result from the recognition of separate corporate identities, and difficulty in enforcing a judgment or collecting a debt does not satisfy this standard.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Bankruptcy Court's recharacterization of $350,000 loan from claimant to debtor as equity and not debt under Delaware law was not clearly erroneous.

Title: Layne Christensen Company v. City of Franklin, Tennessee
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: If an unsatisfied judgment were the only fact necessary to establish injustice, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil under Tennessee law, the corporate form would be disregarded in virtually every case.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Fact issue existed whether company's acquisition of subsidiary resulted in mere continuance of subsidiary on issue of company's liability for subsidiary's defective work.

Title: Layne Christensen Company v. City of Franklin, Tennessee
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: When the record shows no evidence of unjust enrichment of shareholders or the sanction of scheme to transfer assets out of a corporation to avoid liabilities and the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil can show little more than the fact that it remains an unpaid creditor, such a showing falls under Tennessee law short of establishing that the corporate form was used to promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Fact issue existed whether company's acquisition of subsidiary resulted in mere continuance of subsidiary on issue of company's liability for subsidiary's defective work.

Title: Lyle v. Fulcrum Loan Holdings, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Judgment creditors stated claim against judgment debtor, its owner, and two other entities owned by judgment debtor's owner for piercing of the corporate veil; creditors alleged facts that, taken as true, showed that owner abused the corporate form of his entities, including that he disregarded corporate formalities, intermingled corporate and personal funds, staff, and property, undercapitalized the entities to avoid creditors, used corporate funds to pay individual obligations, and siphoned off corporate funds for himself, his family, and other entities he controlled.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Judgment creditors could seek relief from collusive consent judgment under statute allowing creditors to attack a judgment for fraud or collusion.

Title: Kittrell v. Dream Builder Investment, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Doctrine on piercing corporate veil did not apply to lender's breach of contract claim against brother of corporate borrower's owner and principal in absence of evidence that brother was an owner of the corporation when he sought the loan.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Promise repay lender within two weeks was not actionable fraud by brother of corporate borrower's owner as it concerned future event.

Title: In re Estate of Nelson
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Record did not support characterization of entertainment industry companies as mere alter egos of agents who represented them, and thus, trial court abused its discretion by holding agents jointly and severally liable for refund of commissions paid to companies to recording artist's estate, since agents signed advisor agreements with special administrator of estate as agents for their disclosed principals.
Document Preview: ESTATE PLANNING AND PROBATE  Injunction. Advisors to administration of estate were not deprived due process of law by temporary injunction ordering commissions to be held in escrow.

Title: In re Paul C. Larsen, P.A.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Fort Myers Division.
Headnote: Trustee of closely-held corporate debtor's Chapter 7 estate failed to satisfy burden of showing that corporate veil should be pierced in order to hold its president, shareholder and director personally liable for corporation's debts; while corporation's president, shareholder and director clearly controlled debtor, trustee failed to show that he so controlled it that corporation, which was an active for-profit corporation until it filed for bankruptcy, filed annual reports, and maintained its own bank account, had ceased to exist, that corporation was used to engage in any fraudulent or improper schemes, or that president's purported misuse of corporate form was cause of any injury sustained by corporate creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Corporate veil could not be pierced to hold president/director liable for debtor's debts.

Title: Gaubert Oil Company, Inc. v. Bayou Fuel Marine and Hardware Supplies, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Single business enterprise doctrine had only prospective application to business that was promissory note maker and two other businesses that note holder claimed were operated along with maker as single business enterprise in selling assets of businesses, and thus doctrine could not be applied to holder's revocatory action against maker's lenders following default on note, where other businesses were not obligors on the note, and did not have established obligation to holder at time of filing of revocatory action. La. Civ. Code Ann. arts. 2036, 2042.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Promissory note holder could bring revocatory action seeking to annul note maker's sale of movables against maker's lenders.

Title: In re W.R. Grace & Co.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In the alter ego or veil piercing context, a creditor's claim against a corporation's parent is derivative because it is based upon (1) the creditor's claim against the corporation for an unpaid debt, and (2) the corporation's alter ego/veil piercing claim against its parent.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Plans. Asbestos claimants' tort claims against Chapter 11 debtor's insurer were nonderivative claims, not subject to channeling injunction of confirmed plan.

Title: In re TransCare Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Allegations by Chapter 7 trustee of administratively consolidated estates of corporate debtor and affiliates that provided emergency medical and disability transportation services, including that lender and administrative agent for a group of lenders exercised remedies under loan agreement, without more, failed to allege that lender or agent dominated or controlled corporate debtor's policies or decisionmaking, as required to state claim for lender liability for debts of corporate debtor under either the "instrumentality" or "alter ego" theories.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee's allegations were sufficient to state claim to recharacterize alleged debt as equity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re TransCare Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To impose liability against a lender for debts of corporate debtor under either the "instrumentality" or "alter ego" theories, the plaintiff must allege facts showing that the lender was: (1) in complete domination of finances, policy, and business practices of the borrower in respect to the attacked transaction; (2) the control was used by the lender to commit fraud or perpetuate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty; and (3) the control and breach of duty must have proximately caused the injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee's allegations were sufficient to state claim to recharacterize alleged debt as equity.

Title: In re TransCare Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Actual, participatory and total control over the corporate debtor is the level of control necessary to establish lender liability under the instrumentality theory or the alter ego theory.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee's allegations were sufficient to state claim to recharacterize alleged debt as equity.

Headnote: The level of control required to establish lender liability for debts of corporate debtor under the instrumentality theory or the alter ego theory is often characterized as total or complete domination.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee's allegations were sufficient to state claim to recharacterize alleged debt as equity.

Title: In re Batcheler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, alter ego claim is cause of action to impose liability on corporation's principals or related entities, where corporation was organized or used to mislead creditors or to perpetrate a fraud upon them.

Title: d'Amico Dry d.a.c. v. Nikka Finance, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil in order to collect from entity other than judgment debtor, judgment creditor must demonstrate that dominant entity used its control over dominated entity to commit a fraud or injustice against judgment creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Diversion of assets was abuse of corporate form that supported veil-piercing.

Title: d'Amico Dry d.a.c. v. Nikka Finance, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Absent some other wrong or injustice that would result if corporate veil is not pierced, creditor's mere inability to collect on judgment is not alone sufficient to justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Diversion of assets was abuse of corporate form that supported veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: d'Amico Dry d.a.c. v. Nikka Finance, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Evidence that judgment debtor had been diverting, to related corporate entity, assets that could have been used to satisfy judgment debt was evidence of abuse of corporate form, which was sufficient to permit a piercing of corporate veil in order to hold related corporate entity liable on judgment debt, which arose from breach of a forward freight agreement; corporations largely ignored their respective independent business structures, had a significant overlap of ownership and directors, and failed to observe corporate formalities, and related company failed to compensate the other for its ship managing services, failed to fully reimburse it for crewmen's services, and used the debtor-corporation's property for its own purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Diversion of assets was abuse of corporate form that supported veil-piercing.

Title: Wichita Destination Developers, Inc. v. Focus Hospitality Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, judgment creditor stated claim against judgment debtor's alleged alter ego to pierce the corporate veil, based upon fraudulent conduct, by alleging that upholding the fiction of two separate corporate identities that shared the same owner, purpose, bank account, liabilities, and corporate books would promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Complaint stated claim for piercing corporate veil to collect judgment.

Title: Padron v. Bentley Marine Group, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil allows a plaintiff to impose legal liability for a corporation's obligations, or for torts committed by the corporation, upon some other individual that controls and dominates a corporation to such an extent that the corporation exists as a mere instrumentality or alter ego of that individual.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Defects. Investor in LLC that purchased boat manufacturer lacked the due process minimum contacts needed for personal jurisdiction in boat purchaser's action.

Title: In re Wolf
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, while corporate form cannot be disregarded for the benefit of its shareholder, there is no similar prohibition on disregarding corporate form at the behest of third-party creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Debtor's son was, on fraudulent transfer or corporate waste theory, for full value of debtor's former 100% equity interest in company.

Title: In re Stage Presence, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, creditors failed to establish that corporate debtor was completely dominated by its sole owner, as required to pierce the corporate veil; from a financial, business, and operating perspective the separate corporate existence of debtor was scrupulously guarded and observed, and the assets and liabilities of debtor were never commingled with those of owner, and the absence of other directors, or of regular directors' meetings, or of directors' minutes, was a sign of sloppiness, rather than an indication that the separate existence of debtor was ignored.

Title: Crystallex International Corporation v. Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In collection action, alter ego, or veil piercing, theory may be raised either as basis for primary liability, in which judgment creditor seeks to establish that alleged alter ego is liable for original judgment, and thus obtain new judgment against alter ego, or alternatively as basis for secondary liability, in which judgment creditor seeks more limited finding, namely that specific property at issue, though nominally held in third party's name, is, at this time, really judgment debtor's property. Fed. R. Civ. P. 69.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW  Foreign Sovereigns. Venezuelan state-owned oil company was Venezuela's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Clientron Corp. v. Devon IT, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Taiwanese "thin client" computer component manufacturer failed to establish under Pennsylvania law that husband and wife shareholders of corporate buyer, who held ownership as tenants by the entirety, were the alter ego of buyer, and thus manufacturer was not entitled to pierce buyer's corporate veil to reach personal assets of shareholders, absent adverse inference regarding discovery misconduct by husband, and although buyer withheld funds from manufacturer in obvious breach of contractual obligations; manufacturer could not show that withholding benefited shareholder's individual interests, and was unable to show how money transfers between entities owned by shareholders benefited shareholders personally as individuals, and buyer had several functional officers and more than 30 employees.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer failed to establish under Pennsylvania law that buyer was its shareholders' alter ego, and thus was not entitled to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Northwest Cattle Feeders, LLC v. O'Connell
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Under the denuding theory, liability of the individual defendant is derivative of the corporation's liability for some obligation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Sufficient minimum contacts existed between cattle brokering company president and Texas for personal jurisdiction, in fraud suit by cattle buyer.

Title: Sky Cable, LLC v. DIRECTV, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, a corporate form cannot be used as a "shield" to hinder creditors from collecting on adjudicated claims.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse piercing of LLC veil was available under Delaware law when LLC was alter ego of its sole member, as predicted by federal court.

Title: Shantou Real Lingerie Manufacturing Co., Ltd. v. Native Group International, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate debtor's principal dominated and controlled corporation, such that piercing the corporate veil was appropriate, where corporation did not observe corporate formalities or have any records such as resolutions or minutes, each of corporation's bank accounts was closed with a negative balance, principal incurred debt to infuse corporation with money, corporation and principal commingled personal and corporate funds and payment of debts, and principal was corporation's sole owner, officer, and shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate debtor's principal dominated and controlled corporation, such that piercing the corporate veil was appropriate.

Title: Shantou Real Lingerie Manufacturing Co., Ltd. v. Native Group International, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, piercing the corporate veil was not rendered inappropriate on grounds that creditor assumed the risk of doing business with corporate debtor absent any knowledge on the part of creditor of debtor's deteriorating financial condition or of its corporate structure.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate debtor's principal dominated and controlled corporation, such that piercing the corporate veil was appropriate.

Title: In re HH Liquidation, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Parent corporation's creditors have no claim to the subsidiary's assets, and vice versa.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Recharacterization of $25 million loan into equity was not appropriate.

Title: IMAX Corp. v. The Essel Group
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: There was no evidence that Indian conglomerate and its promoters transferred any assets from judgment debtor to related entity so as to make debtor incapable of honoring its obligations to judgment creditor, and thus even if trial court had general jurisdiction over related entity, there was no basis for creditor's recovery against related entity, or against conglomerate and promoters on ground that they and related entity were "single personality," in creditor's proceeding for order directing conglomerate and promoters to deliver funds or property sufficient to satisfy judgment based on contention that conglomerate fraudulently demerged judgment debtor and transferred assets out of it; related entity was not in existence at the time debtor was demerged. McKinney's CPLR 5201, 5225(b).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked personal jurisdiction over Indian conglomerate and its promoters on basis of tortious act committed outside state.

Title: Thomas v. Khrawesh
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: An unjust injury, as required for a Michigan court to allow piercing of the corporate veil, occurs when a plaintiff is unable to collect on a default judgment due to a corporate officer's wrongful conduct.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Former employee of dissolved corporation could pierce corporate veil to collect, from corporation's owner, default judgment previously awarded against corporation.

Title: Collins v. Collins
Court: Supreme Court of Vermont.
Headnote: A court may pierce a corporate veil to hold a shareholder personally liable to corporate creditors when the shareholder intentionally used the corporation to shield personal assets from creditor claims.
Document Preview: ESTATE PLANNING AND PROBATE  Trusts. Husband's father was permitted to change the beneficiary of his revocable trust from husband to husband's son after husband had filed for divorce.

Title: United States v. TDC Management Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, corporation and its owner, who was judgment debtor, had unity of interest that supported reverse veil-piercing to allow federal government, as judgment creditor, to satisfy judgment debt by garnishing funds owed to corporation from separate judgment in unrelated case; unity of interest factors that predominated were corporation's consistent disregard for corporate formalities including holding only seven board meetings and five shareholder meetings in 24 years and failing to file required annual reports, owner's domination and control of corporation's affairs as president, director, and sole shareholder, and extensive commingling of funds between corporation and owner's affiliated companies including undocumented, unsecured, interest-free, intercompany loans.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under alter ego theory, assets of corporation owned by judgment debtor were subject to garnishment by federal government as judgment creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: United States v. TDC Management Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, inequitable result would follow absent reverse piercing of corporate veil to allow federal government, as judgment creditor, to satisfy judgment debt owed by owner of corporation by garnishing funds owed to corporation from separate judgment in unrelated case, where owner had dissipated assets to avoid payment of judgment by series of loan repayments to his affiliated companies and by paying himself officer compensation, and garnishment of funds by veil piercing was only available method of satisfying judgment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under alter ego theory, assets of corporation owned by judgment debtor were subject to garnishment by federal government as judgment creditor.

Title: In re Zak
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Wholly-owned corporation that debtor-attorney established, because he could not split fees with non-attorney, in order to conceal sub-prime mortgage broker's involvement in loan modification business which they established using broker's customer list, was debtor-attorney's alter ego, whose veil could be pierced in order to hold debtor personally liable for the 50% share of profits that he agreed mortgage broker would receive; while there was no evidence as to whether corporate formalities were observed, broker testified that, following creation of corporation, she and debtor continued to make "decisions together, like we normally did."
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor's breached duties as partner to account for profits were fiduciary defalcations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Avant Capital Partners, LLC v. Strathmore Development Company Michigan, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Nonparty parent of wholly owned subsidiary judgment debtor that had failed to pay monetary judgment owed to judgment creditor was not "judgment debtor," within meaning of Michigan's Proceedings Supplementary of Judgment Act, enumerating court's powers after money judgment had been rendered, including subjecting any nonexempt assets of any judgment debtor to satisfaction of any judgment against judgment debtor, and thus, district court was not authorized to pierce veil of judgment debtor subsidiary to hold parent jointly and severally liable for subsidiary's judgment debt, where parent was never joined as party to judgment creditor's enforcement action or to underlying cause of action that gave rise to judgment debt. Mich. Comp. Laws Ann. § 600.6104(5).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Nonparty parent could not be added as jointly and severally liable judgment debtor with its wholly owned subsidiary by piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Sherrick
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, creditor, which had filed adversary complaint seeking determination that debt owed by Chapter 7 debtor, the president and sole owner of a construction company with which creditor had worked on a federal contract project, was nondischargeable, was entitled to pierce the corporate veil to hold debtor personally liable for his company's debt; the government paid debtor's company, which was then a certified Small Business Administration 8(a) contractor authorized to obtain federal contracts as a socially or economically disadvantaged business, $314,500 for the project in question, out of those funds debtor's company was entitled to its project management fee of $8,960 and creditor was entitled to the remainder, and, instead of paying creditor, debtor diverted more than $97,000 of the corporate funds to pay his personal income taxes, as well as additional sums to pay company's payroll taxes and significant penalties from insurance audit.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt owed creditor for work done on federal contract project fell within embezzlement discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Sherrick
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, to pierce the corporate veil and hold a debtor personally liable for his company's debt, creditor does not have to prove that debtor directly and personally received every dollar lost by creditor; instead, debtor may be liable even when he has only indirectly obtained some tangible or intangible financial benefit.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt owed creditor for work done on federal contract project fell within embezzlement discharge exception.

Title: 21st Century Financial Services, LLC v. Manchester Financial Bank
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, the alter ego doctrine does not guard every unsatisfied creditor of a corporation but instead affords protection when some conduct amounting to bad faith makes it inequitable for the corporate owner to hide behind the corporate form; difficulty in enforcing a judgment or collecting a debt does not satisfy this standard.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Partnerships. General partner of limited partnership that funded bank's pre-formation expenses was not alter ego of bank.

Title: Roscoe v. Angelucci Acoustical, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Sufficient evidence of a loss of corporate separateness supported trial court's order piercing the corporate veil so as to hold one of general contractor's principals personally liable for the judgment obtained against general contractor by a subcontractor on a construction project; general contractor had been formed by principal and his partner, who were also the two managing members of the project owner, specifically to serve as general contractor for the project, project was general contractor's sole asset, and principal or the project owner exercised complete dominion and control over general contractor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Sufficient evidence of a loss of corporate separateness supported trial court's order piercing general contractor's corporate veil.

Title: Board of Trustees of Employers–Shopmen's Local 516 Pension Trust Through Galton v. Columbia Wire & Iron Works, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: An inability to collect upon a judgment is not, by itself, an inequitable result, that would support piercing the corporate veil to hold shareholders liable for corporate debts, for example, where the corporation was once adequately capitalized but subsequently fell upon bad financial times.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Pension fund plausibly alleged alter ego liability for employer's withdrawal liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Board of Trustees of Employers–Shopmen's Local 516 Pension Trust Through Galton v. Columbia Wire & Iron Works, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: A plaintiff's inability to collect from an insolvent corporation can be an inequitable result, that would support piercing the corporate veil to hold shareholders liable for corporate debts, when the corporation is so undercapitalized that it is unable to meet debts that may reasonably be expected to arise in the normal course of business.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Pension fund plausibly alleged alter ego liability for employer's withdrawal liability.

Title: F&M Marketing Services, Inc. v. Christenberry Trucking and Farm, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Eastern Section, AT KNOXVILLE.
Headnote: Judgment creditor failed to establish the equities substantially favored piercing the corporate veil and holding sole shareholder liable for judgment debtor's debt; there was no evidence judgment debtor was undercapitalized, stock certificates were issued, and there was no evidence that judgment debtor was used as a business conduit for an individual or another corporation or was used as a subterfuge in illegal transactions.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor failed to establish the equities substantially favored piercing the corporate veil and holding sole shareholder liable for debt.

Title: In re Rouette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: To show that Chapter 7 debtors utilized the control that they possessed over their wholly-owned corporation in order to perpetrate a fraud or wrong against it, as required under Connecticut law for corporate creditor to pierce corporate veil and to hold debtors personally liable on its claim under instrumentality rule, corporate creditor had to show (1) that debtors exercised control over the specific transaction that caused creditor harm, and (2) that debtors exercised such control to perpetrate a fraud or wrong against creditor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Corporate creditor had no claim against individual debtor-shareholders' Chapter 7 estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Rouette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: While individual Chapter 7 debtors completely dominated their wholly-owned corporation, in routinely using it to pay their personal expenses as shareholder distributions at time when it was operating at aggregate loss, lack of evidence that they had used this dominance to perpetrate a wrong against corporate creditor in transactions that formed basis of its proof of claim prevented creditor from piercing corporate veil, on instrumentality theory, in order to hold debtors' estate personally liable on corporate debt.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Corporate creditor had no claim against individual debtor-shareholders' Chapter 7 estate.

Title: Cargill Soluciones Empresariales, S.A. de C.V., SOFOM, ENR v. Farallon
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Allegations by lender's successor were sufficient to state cause of action for breach of guaranty, based on alter ego liability, as against corporate guarantor's principal, in connection with guaranty of loan for borrower's development of luxury resort in Mexico; lender's successor alleged an absence of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, and the commingling of corporate and personal funds, as well as that principal directed guarantor to take various actions that harmed lender's successor, including failing to transfer property rights, siphoning resort revenues, and incurring unnecessary taxes.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Guaranty. Allegations by lender's successor were sufficient to state claim for breach of guaranty, based on alter ego liability, against guarantor's principal.

Title: Viajes Gerpa, S.A. v. Fazeli
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence did not support piercing of corporate veil to hold owner of debtor corporation individually liable in creditor's action to recover on debt arising out of settlement agreement and judgment executed pursuant thereto; any fraudulent conduct by owner did not relate to the underlying settlement agreement or the judgment, evidence reflected only general mishandling of corporate accounts, recordkeeping and operations, owner's use of corporate funds to pay his personal mortgage occurred years prior to settlement agreement and judgment, and transfer of corporate assets occurred almost three years after settlement and judgment. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Debt Collection. Owner was not individually liable for debt incurred before corporation forfeited its charter for failure to pay franchise taxes.

Title: Klauder v. Echo/RT Holdings, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Delaware.
Headnote: Bankruptcy trustee for parent company lacked standing to bring fraudulent conveyance action against purchasers of assets from subsidiary; subsidiary was not alter ego of parent company, there was no reason to disregard separate corporate structures, and parent company did not have direct interest in assets of subsidiary.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Bankruptcy trustee for parent company lacked standing to bring fraudulent conveyance action against purchasers of assets from subsidiary.

Title: Genband US LLC v. Metaswitch Networks Ltd
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Marshall Division.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine is used to pierce the corporate veil to hold the owner of a corporation liable for some underlying judgment against the corporation.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Computers and Electronics. Claims in patent directed to method and apparatus for interworking between Internet Protocol (IP) telephony protocols were patent eligible.
