Title: In re Loganbill
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Missouri, Central Division.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is generally used by a creditor of a corporation to ignore the limited liability of the corporate form and to hold the shareholders liable for the debts of the corporation; it is based on the theory that the corporation was a sham or the "alter ego" of the shareholder or perhaps of an officer or director.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Chapter 12 debtors' pattern of omissions and falsities supported dismissal or conversion of their bankruptcy case.

Title: In re Loganbill
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Missouri, Central Division.
Headnote: Creditor "pierces" the corporate veil or corporate form to place liability on the shareholders who, otherwise, would be shielded from liability by the corporate form.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Chapter 12 debtors' pattern of omissions and falsities supported dismissal or conversion of their bankruptcy case.

Title: Rodríguez–Miranda v. Benin
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, employer's Chief Executive Officer's (CEO) new company was employer's alter ego, for purposes of rule governing joinder of new parties as successor in interest, in former employee's collection action against employer, where employer and CEO's new company shared address, bank account, and website, and had same inventory and clients, and CEO was principal shareholder and chief executive of both companies. Fed. R. Civ. P. 25(c).
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Parties. District court did not plainly err in joining company's CEO and his mother as alter egos of company in collection action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Rodríguez–Miranda v. Benin
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, employer's Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and his mother were alter egos of employer and CEO's new company, to which CEO transferred employer's assets, for purposes of applying rule governing joinder of new parties as successor in interest in former employee's collection action against employer; CEO, as employer's sole shareholder and principal, exercised total control over employer and his new company, and did not maintain employer's corporate form, and employer regularly paid CEO and his mother's personal expenses. Fed. R. Civ. P. 25(c).
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Parties. District court did not plainly err in joining company's CEO and his mother as alter egos of company in collection action.

Title: Gallagher v. Persha
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: When the requisite evidence establishes that the corporate form has been abused, the corporate form will be pierced so that creditors (and sometimes others) can seek payment of a corporate debt from a responsible corporate shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Vendors were permitted to bring action to pierce corporate veil after obtaining judgment against corporate purchaser.

Title: Gallagher v. Persha
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: A corporate veil is pierced and liability imposed upon an individual shareholder or officer not because the shareholder or officer was necessarily liable under the cause of action resulting in the judgment against the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Vendors were permitted to bring action to pierce corporate veil after obtaining judgment against corporate purchaser.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Gallagher v. Persha
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Liability based on a theory of piercing of the corporate veil is imposed because the fact-finder has concluded that the individual so misused the corporation that it was unable to pay on the outstanding judgment and an injustice would occur if the corporate form was not ignored.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Vendors were permitted to bring action to pierce corporate veil after obtaining judgment against corporate purchaser.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Lim v. Miller Parking Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Corporate entities which, while owned by members of same family, had separate historical roots, kept separate books and observed adequate corporate formalities, were not alter egos, and veil that separated them could not be pierced at request of trustee of bankruptcy estate of first company, especially where, to extent that there had been flow of cash between companies, it generally flowed from second company to the first, in form of loans that shareholders of second corporation, the children of long-time principal of the first, had made to support their father's lavish spending; if first corporation wound up penniless, it was because its principal took everything it had, and more, for himself, and while second company's support may have allowed this bloodletting to continue longer than it otherwise could have, this did not amount to evidence of fraud nor did it support veil-piercing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate entities owned by members of same family were not alter egos, and veil that separated them could not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Airbus DS Optronics GmbH v. Nivisys LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Judgment creditor stated plausible claim under Arizona law that subsidiaries operated as mere alter egos, and that parent corporation should be held liable for their engagement in fraudulent transfers, on allegations that parent, through subsidiaries, transferred assets of judgment debtor subsidiary for purpose of shielding those assets from collection by judgment creditor, judgment creditor had two valid judgments against debtor for breach of contract, and it could not collect due to fact that debtor was stripped of its assets and then dissolved, and observance of subsidiaries' corporate form would "sanction a fraud" by validating parent's attempts to shield its assets.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor pleaded sufficient factual allegations to establish unity of control by parent corporation over subsidiaries.

Title: Agai v. Diontech Consulting, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence that principals dominated corporation, that corporation did not adhere to any corporate formalities such as holding regular meetings and maintaining corporate records and minutes, that principals used corporate funds for personal purposes, and that principals stripped corporation of assets as they wound down the business, leaving it without sufficient funds to pay its creditors, including two judgment creditors, warranted piercing of corporate veil, on the two judgment creditors' petition to enforce their judgments against corporation by holding principals personally liable for the judgments.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence presented by judgment creditors warranted piercing of corporate veil.

Title: 612 Wortman, LLC v. Varsity Bus Co., Inc.

Title: M.J. v. Wisan
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: Where a shareholder, officer, or director abuses the corporate form, and treats the legal entity as his alter ego, the law allows a creditor to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Utah law allows reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Bridge v. New Holland Logansport, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: The corporate veil is pierced, when it is pierced, not because the corporate group is integrated, but because it has neglected forms intended to protect creditors from being confused about whom they can look to for the payment of their claims.

Title: Steiner Elec. Co. v. Maniscalco
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Evidence supported determination to hold solvent corporation liable for debts of insolvent corporation; sole shareholder controlled both corporations, corporations' dealings with one another were often not properly documented, corporations' funds were commingled, and sole shareholder consistently treated both corporations in such a manner that both companies were, in practice, his alter egos.

Title: Steiner Elec. Co. v. Maniscalco
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court's determination that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that piercing corporate veil of insolvent corporation was warranted such that sole shareholder and his solvent corporate entity would be liable for debts of insolvent corporation; debtor corporation had been undercapitalized, sole shareholder and his corporations did not observe corporate formalities such as electing bona fide officers and documenting financial transactions, management fees were not in writing, corporations held joint bank account and commingled funds, shareholder diverted assets to himself and to his son-in-law both without compensation, and shareholder repeatedly borrowed and loaned money to corporations with no documentation or promissory notes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Costs. Judgment creditor was entitled to attorney fees incurred in piercing corporate veil and collecting judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Steiner Elec. Co. v. Maniscalco
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Decision to pierce corporate veil and to hold sole shareholder and solvent corporation liable for judgment against insolvent corporation served purpose of avoiding injustice and avoiding perpetuation of a fraud or deception; evidence showed that sole shareholder closed insolvent corporation in response to supplier's refusal to abandon its contractual rights to payment, insolvent corporation refused several settlement officers, and sole shareholder decided to close corporation when he received notice of mechanics' liens.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Costs. Judgment creditor was entitled to attorney fees incurred in piercing corporate veil and collecting judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Steiner Elec. Co. v. Maniscalco
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: The doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is an equitable remedy; it is not itself a cause of action but rather is a means of imposing liability on an underlying cause of action, such as a tort or breach of contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Costs. Judgment creditor was entitled to attorney fees incurred in piercing corporate veil and collecting judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Steiner Elec. Co. v. Maniscalco
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: When a judgment has been obtained against a corporation, parties may bring a separate suit to pierce the corporate veil in order to enforce the original judgment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Costs. Judgment creditor was entitled to attorney fees incurred in piercing corporate veil and collecting judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Bazarian International Financial Associates, L.L.C. v. Desarrollos Aerohotelco, C.A.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Allegations that Venezuelan hotel development company shared unity of ownership and interest with related project development entities, that related Venezuelan citizen was "dominating force" behind company and entities, and that company transferred valuable assets to entities in alleged effort to avoid paying "debt fee" to Florida investment banking company in accordance with investment banking agreement for financing for development of luxury hotel in Aruba were sufficient for Florida company to allege, under District of Columbia law, that entities were "alter egos" of Venezuelan company, as required to pierce corporate veil and impute to entities the Venezuelan company's duty to pay debt fee to Florida company.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Process. Service of process upon Venezuelan citizen and entities through e-mail and registered mail was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Flame S.A. v. Freight Bulk Pte. Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Registered owner of vessel and maritime company were alter egos, as required to pierce corporate veil in action for attachment of shipping vessel for purposes of satisfying foreign judgment, and asserting alter ego and fraudulent conveyance claims, where same person had ownership and control of both entities, officers did as the principal directed rather than exercising independent decision making, owner was undercapitalized, funds between owner and maritime company were intermingled amongst themselves and other affiliated entities, those entities did not observe corporate formalities and maintain proper records, they shared office space, and their dealings were not conducted at arm's length.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Charters. Registered owner of vessel and maritime company were alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Flame S.A. v. Freight Bulk Pte. Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Registered owner of vessel and maritime company had some shared ownership and employees, favoring conclusion that they were alter egos of one another on claim to pierce the corporate veil, in action for attachment of shipping vessel for purposes of satisfying foreign judgment, and asserting alter ego and fraudulent conveyance claims; percentage of overall shared employees was not determinative, but rather their roles and fluidity between owner, company, and affiliates.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Charters. Registered owner of vessel and maritime company were alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Flame S.A. v. Freight Bulk Pte. Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Registered owner of vessel could be alter ego of defunct maritime shipping company despite being established years after company's demise, as required to pierce the corporate veil in action for attachment of shipping vessel for purposes of satisfying foreign judgment, and asserting alter ego and fraudulent conveyance claims, where there was requisite causal link between entities through affiliated maritime company that was in existence at same time.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Charters. Registered owner of vessel and maritime company were alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Johnson v. Serenity Transportation, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: A plaintiff's difficulty collecting judgment from a corporation is not an inequitable result that warrants application of the alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Employer's customers were not joint employers of workers, who were mortuary drivers, and thus customers could not be liable under FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Ciavarella v. Zagaglia
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Undercapitalization of a corporation and the corporation's owner's personal use of corporate funds, which results in the corporation's being unable to pay a judgment, constitutes wrongdoing and injury sufficient to satisfy requirement that the owner's domination of the corporation be used to commit a fraud or wrong against a plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury, as required to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations of fraudulent conveyances between stone important companies was insufficient to warrant piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Sugartown Worldwide LLC v. Shanks
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, corporate control persons do not become liable to creditors for corporate guarantor obligations as alter egos based solely on their business decisions possibly motivated to frustrate a corporate creditor's recovery unless there is a personal benefit as evidenced by commingling, lack of corporate formalities, or other similar indicia showing the entity is the same as its control persons.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Judgment creditor's allegations were sufficient to warrant exercising personal jurisdiction over companies' control persons based on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Sugartown Worldwide LLC v. Shanks
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: While puppetry may create tort liability under Pennsylvania law regarding piercing the corporate veil, such control alone does not transform a corporate debt obligation into a personal judgment obligation of individual control persons under an alter ego theory.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Judgment creditor's allegations were sufficient to warrant exercising personal jurisdiction over companies' control persons based on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Sugartown Worldwide LLC v. Shanks
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Judgment creditor stated claim under Pennsylvania law for alter ego liability for judgment debtor against its individual control persons, where it alleged that control persons personally benefited from using judgment debtor as part of shell game to hide assets available to satisfy known judgment, depleting judgment debtor's assets to pay approximately $1.5 million in dividends to themselves and transferring assets from judgment debtor to its non-debtor successor-in-interest.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Judgment creditor's allegations were sufficient to warrant exercising personal jurisdiction over companies' control persons based on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Sugartown Worldwide LLC v. Shanks
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Judgment creditor failed to state claim under Pennsylvania law for alter ego liability for judgment debtor's successor-in-interest against its individual control persons, where it did not have judgment against successor-in-interest, it did not allege commingling of assets or common identity of successor-in-interest and control persons, and it did not allege any acts by control persons in their roles at successor-in-interest to benefit them personally.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Judgment creditor's allegations were sufficient to warrant exercising personal jurisdiction over companies' control persons based on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: American Federated Title Corp. v. GFI Management Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a judgment creditor may raise several types of claims within a special proceeding to recover assets improperly held by another party, including a fraudulent conveyance claim against a third party to which the judgment debtor transferred assets, and a claim to pierce the judgment debtor's corporate veil and hold a third party responsible for the debtor's obligations. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 5225(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted after companies made loan repayments to their owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Sentry Ins. v. Brand Management Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, principal of related professional employment organizations was liable under alter ego theory for their debts to workers compensation insurer for deductibles and unpaid premiums, where, among other things, organizations depended on principal for operating funds, bare adherence to corporate formalities and clear overlap in ownership existed, corporate-minute taking, regular board meetings, annual shareholder meetings, and host of practices indicative of business independence were eschewed, and owner committed wrong that harmed insurer by undercapitalizing insured organization.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of related professional employment organizations was liable for debt of those organizations under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Double Bogey, L.P. v. Enea
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Although California alter ego doctrine may allow for hole to be drilled in the wall of limited liability erected by corporate form in order to permit a particular debt to be collected, for all purposes other than that for which the hole was drilled, this wall still stands.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Alter ego doctrine did not place corporate shareholders in fiduciary capacity to corporate creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Jarrett v. Dillard
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Where the shareholders are the only officers of the corporation, they necessarily control prior litigation, and a plaintiff may enforce a judgment obtained against a corporation against those officer shareholders, even if they were not named as parties.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Corporation's president was individually liable for workers' compensation benefits.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, alter ego will not be applied absent evidence that an injustice would result from the recognition of separate corporate identities, and difficulty in enforcing a judgment or collecting a debt does not satisfy this standard.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Author's amended complaint failed to allege plausible claims against entertainment corporation on successor-in-interest theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Hurtado
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Principal and 49% owner of defunct construction company could not be held personally liable, on alter ego theory, for company's debt to would-be homeowner in connection with abortive home construction contract, either based on company's failure to properly segregate funds received from would-be homeowner from company's other funds or based on evidence of funds transfers between construction company and other entities in which principal had interest, where there was no evidence that funds were transferred other than for lawful purpose, insufficient evidence was presented of unity of interest between company and principal, as minority stakeholder, and company carried out a legitimate business and was not created only as instrument to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. False representation of licensure precluded discharge of debt in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Bank of America v. WS Management, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: Judgment creditor failed to establish that either judgment debtor corporation or property management company, in both of which individual had at various times held an ownership interest, was a sham for individual such that the separate personalities failed to exist; although individual owned the location where companies had their offices and was an officer of companies, she knew little about the companies and was not involved in their day-to-day management, and individual stated that she was given perfunctory explanations of what she was asked to sign.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Finding of a Fraudulent Transfer Act violation was not against the manifest weight of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Bank of America v. WS Management, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: Judgment creditor failed to establish that officer of judgment debtor corporation and property management company was an alter ego of companies, as would support piercing of the corporate veil; although officer diverted assets from one company to the other to avoid paying the judgment, neither company was inadequately capitalized, companies observed basic corporate formalities and maintained various records when required by a third party, explanations were provided for alleged comingling of funds and the companies' interwoven affairs, evidence did not suggest that either entity was purposely kept insolvent while it operated, and the two entities maintained separate identities from officer.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Finding of a Fraudulent Transfer Act violation was not against the manifest weight of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: Fact that principal of home builder and the trustees of his trust shared legal authority to make decisions on behalf of builder and other associated companies did not preclude a finding that principal had dominion and control over builder and the other companies, so as to support piercing of the corporate veil to permit title insurer to execute against the other companies certain consent judgments that were entered against builder; issue was whether principal disregarded the corporations' existence and treated them as an extension of his own personal mind or will with respect to the underlying transactions giving rise to the consent judgments.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: CADC/RADC Venture 2011-1 LLC v. Bradley
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Guarantors were not the primary obligors on loan secured by deed of trust on basis that they were alter ego of shell borrower, and thus guaranties were not sham guaranties and lender could pursue post-foreclosure deficiency action against guarantors; borrower was without an owner at the time the loan agreement was executed and lender's vice-president believed guarantors owned borrower directly, documents executed day after loan was made indicated that exchange accommodation titleholder (EAT) was to take ownership of borrower, and EAT later transferred to a corporation owned by guarantors, that corporation, rather than guarantors, made loan payments for borrower, and that corporation also observed the necessary formalities, including passing corporate resolutions, holding corporate meetings, and maintaining separate bank accounts and assets, such that it was legally distinct and could not be considered guarantors' alter ego. Cal. Civ. Proc. Code § 580d(b).
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Guaranties for loan secured by deed of trust were not sham guaranties which precluded any post-foreclosure action to recover deficiency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: TradeWinds Airlines, Inc. v. Soros
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, purported controllers of corporation involved in aircraft leasing business did not operate as a single economic entity with the corporation, as required to pierce corporate veil to hold them liable for a default judgment entered against corporation; even if corporation was undercapitalized and disregarded formalities with respect to board meetings and minutes, there was no evidence that the purported controllers comingled their own money with the corporation or siphoned money from it, and fact that other entities involved in the leasing business and indirectly owned by the controllers may have been treated as a single economic entity with the corporation did not support veil-piercing with regard to the controllers themselves.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditors could not pierce veil to hold purported controllers of aircraft leasing corporation liable for default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Powertrain, Inc. v. Ma
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Aberdeen Division.
Headnote: A pierce-the-corporate-veil theory brought under Mississippi law generally applies to two broad categories of cases: (1) those in which a third party seeks to hold shareholders individually liable for corporate debts, and (2) those in which a shareholder utilizes a corporation to perform indirectly acts which the shareholder could not legally perform as an individual.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Defendant's sole employee did not engage in fraud, precluding piercing of corporate veil on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Clark
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Ordinarily, "piercing the corporate veil" allows a creditor of a corporation to ignore the corporate form and seek recovery from the corporation's principals.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Substantive consolidation of debtor with trust and limited liability company (LLC) created by debtor was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Kurtz Bros., Inc. v. Ace Demo, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Portage County.
Headnote: Landscaping company, which filed action against demolition corporation and its owner-shareholder for failure to pay account, stated claim for piercing the corporate veil against owner-shareholder by alleging that owner-shareholder's control over corporation was so dominant that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own separate from owner-shareholder, that owner-shareholder used his dominion and control over corporation to commit an illegal act by taking or stealing funds belonging to corporation and using them to pay his own personal expenses, and that owner-shareholder's use of his dominion and control over corporation to steal its funds resulted in corporation's inability to pay landscaping company the amount due on the account.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Landscaping company stated claim for piercing the corporate veil against owner-shareholder of demolition corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Geer
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, the alter ego and veil piercing doctrines are used as remedies for inequitable conduct which allow corporate creditors to pursue individual shareholders on corporate debts; the doctrines do not invalidate the corporate existence except for purposes of a particular creditor's debt collection.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's transfer of interest in house to QRPT did not warrant denial of his discharge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Flame S.A. v. Industrial Carriers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: A shipping company, a shareholder, and related corporate entities were alter egos of one another, and thus each was liable for each others' debts, where the shipping company's funds were siphoned through cash conversion companies to related corporate entities, the shareholder used assets of the related corporate entities for his personal expenses and enjoyment, the shareholder controlled all of the entities, and the entities failed to observe corporate formalities.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Defendants lacked minimum contacts with forum for exercise of personal jurisdiction in admiralty action involving attachment of a vessel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Intelligent Direct Marketing
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Corporation was alter ego of debtor corporation under California law, where there was a unity of interest and ownership because corporation held title to certain real property but debtor purchased it under corporation's name by directly transferring $1,779,039 into the escrow for the property, prepaying rent, and paying for tenant improvements, and failure to disregard the corporate entity would promote injustice because debtor was depleted of all cash to purchase and improve the property, which was sold and resulted in a $2,650,000 payment to shareholders of corporation rather than to debtor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Corporation was alter ego of debtor corporation under California law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: U.S. v. Boyce
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, there are three ways to pierce the corporate veil: (1) when a shareholder is held liable for the debts or conduct of the corporation; (2) in reverse, so that a corporation may be held liable for the debts or conduct of an inside shareholder; and (3) outside or third party reverse piercing, which occurs when a third party outsider seeks to reach corporate assets to satisfy claims against an individual shareholder.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. Transferee was nominee of taxpayer, for purposes of enforcing federal tax lien.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Apace Communications, Ltd. v. Burke
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, company's secured creditors were not liable under alter ego doctrine for investor's loss of funds, even though creditors were involved in sale of 60% company stock to investor, where there was no evidence supporting investor's claim that company had no existence separate from creditors, and investor was elected chairman of company's board of directors, and had complete access to all of its financial information before deciding to loan additional funds to company.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Secured creditors' statements about company's financial condition and outlook did not fraudulently induce investor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Buckley v. Abuzir
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Judgment creditors were not required to show that purported controller of judgment debtor corporation was a shareholder in order to pierce the corporate veil and hold purported controller liable for the judgment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditors were not required to show that controller was a shareholder in order to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Webmediabrands, Inc. v. Latinvision, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Corporation and its principal were liable as alter egos of related corporation on veil piercing claim for judgment against related corporation, where corporations had overlapping owners and directors, they all commingled assets, principal used corporate funds for personal purposes, corporation used related corporation's Internet domain name, and corporation and principal did not hold any corporate meetings and did not keep any corporate records.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation and its principal were liable as alter egos of related corporation for judgment against related corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re JMK Construction Group, Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: President-sole shareholder's ownership of corporation, standing alone, was not enough to satisfy domination component of alter ego claim by corporation's customer seeking to hold president-shareholder liable for corporation's alleged debts under New York law; customer had to show that president-shareholder actually exercised control over corporation, specifically with respect to its contracts with customer or customer's funds.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Debtor's customer had standing and could assert claims for conversion and unjust enrichment against debtor's president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Washington Cty. Bd. of Dev. Disabilities v. United Re AG
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Fourth District, Washington County.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support trial court's decision to pierce the corporate veil and hold president of company that was supposed to procure a reinsurance policy personally liable for the compensatory and punitive damages entered in judgment in action by state agency for unpaid claims; evidence indicated that president operated company as part of a Ponzi scheme, using the employer contributions to fund the stop-loss claims for the other employers, president had complete control over company since its inception, company had no employees, only a few "independent contractors" who worked from home to process claims, and president had authority to write checks from company's accounts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to support piercing the corporate veil to hold company president personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: North American Steel Connection, Inc. v. Watson Metal Products Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, steel importer could not pierce corporate veil to hold metal products marketing corporation's principal personally liable for corporation's debt to importer, even though principal had obtained personal loan to help satisfy corporation's debt, where there was no evidence that principal dominated corporation, did not observe corporate formalities, or was using corporation as facade for his personal operations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. President of corporation that was member of LLC did not breach any fiduciary duties to other LLC member.

Title: Delta Development Corp. v. F. Fani Gulf Intern.

Headnote: Individual shareholder's wrongdoing and disregard of borrower corporation's corporate form, alone, was not sufficient to impose liability against other shareholders, even though the corporate veil was pierced with regard to individual shareholder, absent any active culpability by the other shareholders. West's T.C.A. § 48–16–203(b).

Title: Delta Development Corp. v. F. Fani Gulf Intern.

Headnote: Noncontrolling shareholders of borrower corporation could not be held personally liable for the controlling shareholder's improper use of corporate funds, even if the noncontrolling shareholders signed boilerplate language in shareholder minutes indicating they had ratified and approved all actions taken by the controlling shareholder, absent a showing that the noncontrolling shareholders were actually apprised of, and acquiesced in the controlling shareholder's use of corporate funds for personal reasons in disregard of corporate form.

Title: Delta Development Corp. v. F. Fani Gulf Intern.

Headnote: Conduct of two noncontrolling shareholders of borrower corporation in forgiving the interest owed on a note from the borrowing corporation to a management company owned by the two shareholders was insufficient to merit the imposition of personal liability on the two shareholders, even if it reduced the value of the only asset of the borrowing corporation, where the two noncontrolling shareholders, through the management company, paid off each of the creditors of the borrowing corporation.

Title: A.P.I., Inc. Asbestos Settlement Trust v. Home Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, parent corporation did not abuse corporate form by creating subsidiary to manage insurance company it had acquired, and thus policyholders could not pierce corporate veil to hold parent liable for subsidiary's purported mismanagement of company, even though some of subsidiary's employees involved in handling company's claims attended parent's claims handling conferences, subsidiary communicated with parent about insurer's reorganization, and some corporate officers and directors had positions in both companies, where companies maintained separate corporate existences, parent never attempted to direct subsidiary's claim handling or otherwise interfere with its management of insurer, and there was no evidence that subsidiary was insolvent or undercapitalized when formed, or that leaving subsidiary's corporate form intact would result in unfairness.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation did not abuse corporate form by creating subsidiary to manage insurance company it had acquired.

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: District court did not clearly err in finding that corporation was inadequately capitalized, in support of determination that unity of interest and ownership existed between corporation and insiders as required for brokerage firm to pierce corporate veil under Illinois law and hold corporate insiders personally liable for $2.4 million judgment obtained against corporation for failing to pay debt arising out of margin transactions; even if at certain times corporation had assets in addition to its $1,000 in paid-in capital, those assets were encumbered by a line of credit, and corporation held itself out as thinly capitalized.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court did not clearly err in finding adherence to separate identities of corporation and insiders would sanction fraud.

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: District court did not clearly err in finding that corporation diverted assets to corporate insiders or related entities after incurring margin debt to brokerage firm, in support of determination that unity of interest and ownership existed between corporation and insiders as required for brokerage firm to pierce corporate veil under Illinois law and hold insiders personally liable for $2.4 million judgment against corporation for failing to pay margin debt; corporation paid nearly $1.2 million to insiders or related entities after stock purchased on margin collapsed, and also paid abnormal, off-the-books compensation to officers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court did not clearly err in finding adherence to separate identities of corporation and insiders would sanction fraud.

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.

Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court did not clearly err in finding adherence to separate identities of corporation and insiders would sanction fraud.

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.

Headnote: District court did not clearly err in finding that corporation failed to maintain arm's-length relationship among related entities, in support of determination that unity of interest and ownership existed between corporation and insiders as required for brokerage firm to pierce corporate veil under Illinois law and hold insiders personally liable for $2.4 million judgment against corporation for failing to pay margin debt; corporation received loan, from entity controlled by dominant insider, that was structured to avoid corporation's creditors by ensuring that its assets were fully encumbered by blanket lien in favor of dominant insider, and corporation also shared office facilities with, and moved employees between, related entities.

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: District court did not clearly err in finding that adherence to separate identities of corporation and insiders would sanction fraud or promote injustice, as required for brokerage firm to pierce corporate veil under Illinois law and hold insiders personally liable for $2.4 million judgment against corporation for failing to pay margin debt; insiders used web of related entities to create false appearance that corporation could cover potential losses on margin account when in fact corporation's assets were encumbered by loan from insider-controlled entity, and insiders diverted corporate assets to themselves once corporation incurred margin debt.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court did not clearly err in finding adherence to separate identities of corporation and insiders would sanction fraud.

Title: Prestige of Beverly Hills, Inc. v. Weber
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that companies were alter egos of defendant owner such that owner could be held liable for damage to adjacent property from encroaching roots from trees located on companies' property; owner was the lone decision-maker for companies, he transferred property and assets from one company to the other without recordkeeping, used company's money to pay personal debts, and neither entity abided by corporate formalities.

Court: United States District Court, W.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Royalty owner stated claims for alter ego liability, under Oklahoma law, against well operators for alleged underpayment or non-payment of royalties through improper accounting methods, by alleging that operators' parent company acquired operators and merged their management into its own, that parent company used operators as conduits as essentially one company, that parent company paid salaries of operators' employees, and that losses or profits of all of the subsidiaries were ultimately paid or owned by parent company.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Oil and Gas. Royalty owner stated a claim for breach of fiduciary duty against operators of gas and oil wells.

Title: Nippert v. Jackson
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Borrower company was not subsidiary of insurance agency, even though both company and agency were controlled by same principal, shared office space, and shared employee, precluding lender's Tennessee–law claim for reverse piercing of corporate veil to hold agency accountable for principal's actions in relation to loans, where agency never owned any shares of company stock. West's T.C.A. § 48–11–201.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Transfers from borrower company to agency with same principal were not fraudulent, barring lender's civil conspiracy claim.

Title: In re Adler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Domination and control of five corporations by their principal, who was their sole shareholder, officer, and director, was sufficient, under New York law, to satisfy domination prong of test for piercing of the corporate veil; corporations failed to exercise even most basic corporate formalities, corporations were inadequately capitalized and likely insolvent at all times, principal's system of using his wife's credit for corporate purposes and repaying her from corporate funds appeared to be for his benefit, principal, through his domination and control, created network of entities that were not intended to be independent profit centers, and principal promised to pay creditors seeking to pierce the corporate veil the debts owed by corporations.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor's domination of corporations and use of those corporations to commit wrong permitted piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Adler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: As required to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, sole shareholder, officer, and director for five related corporations used his domination and control over corporations to commit fraud or wrong against corporations' judgment creditors, who had worked with corporations to import garments from Hong Kong to United States, where shareholder, as sole actor on behalf of corporations, employed scheme designed to deflect onto judgment creditors financial responsibility for goods that were shipped to corporations; corporations, at shareholder's direction, entered into transactions with judgment creditors which shareholder knew, or should have known, that corporations could not honor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor's domination of corporations and use of those corporations to commit wrong permitted piercing corporate veil.

Title: ARB Upstate Communications LLC v. R.J. Reuter, L.L.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Radio tower business stated a cause of action against business consultant entity's owner individually, for the obligations of his corporations, piercing the corporate veil, by alleging that owner managed or owned the three corporate defendants, that owner provided business advice to radio tower business to cancel its options to purchase parcels of land where radio towers and equipment were located and allow the parcels' lessor to sell the sites to the business consultant entity and its owner, and that owner purchased the sites and formed two entities to directly compete against the radio tower business.

Title: Brennan's Inc. v. Colbert
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate shareholders never agreed to bind themselves personally for any debt incurred by corporation in connection with legal services provided by law firm with regard to corporation's intellectual property lawsuit, and thus, law firm could not pierce the corporate veil and hold shareholders personally liable for the debts of the corporation to law firm for legal services rendered, absent a written guarantee or promise from any of the shareholders, or any showing of fraud, malfeasance or criminal wrongdoing on the part of the shareholders. LSA–C.C. art. 1953.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Law firm could not pierce the corporate veil and hold shareholders personally liable for the debts of the corporation.

Title: Fernbach, LLC v. Calleo
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate judgment debtor's corporate veil could not be pierced to hold brother of judgment debtor's sole shareholder personally liable for judgment; brother exercised no control or dominion over judgment debtor and was not judgment debtor's alter ego.

Title: Magnolia North Property Owners' Ass'n, Inc. v. Heritage Communities, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Record supported a determination that vendor, general contractor, and corporate parent of vendor and general contractor were amalgamated, so as to blur the legal distinction between the three corporations and their activities, in an action brought against them by association of property owners for defects in the construction of a condominium complex; vendor, general contractor, and corporate parent shared a location, telephone number, board members, and employees, and corporate parent held itself out in its warranty as the corporation responsible for construction defects.

Title: Newcrete Products v. City of Wilkes-Barre
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: City, as an outside third party, was not capable of being an equity interest holder in redevelopment authority, and thus, could not be liable for authority's debts under a theory of piercing the corporate veil, even if city had a pervasive influence over the authority by appropriating funds necessary for authority to operate; redevelopment authority was not authorized to sell ownership interests, and was required to be funded through bonds rather than stock. 35 P.S. §§ 1714, 1718, 1746.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Municipalities. City could not be liable for redevelopment authority's debts under a theory of piercing the corporate veil.

Title: Christopher v. Sinyard
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that home builder corporation's two sole officers abused corporate form and disregarded separateness of corporate entity by commingling or confusing corporate property with other entities, as grounds for ignoring corporate status of home builder and piercing corporate veil to permit client's recovery against officers on default judgment entered against corporation; officers ignored corporate formalities required by law, corporation was undercapitalized, lots on which home was built was owned by officer, who then deeded property to client at closing, and officer executed false affidavit at closing that it had completed all work under contract and satisfied all debts and obligations to subcontractors.

Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported determination that facts did not warrant piercing corporate veil to hold defendant personally liable for corporation's debts to plaintiff.

Title: Ramlall v. MobilePro Corp.
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Securing payment of bonus fee by consultant for work on previous litigation was not a paramount equity that justified piercing corporate veil of corporation that merged with client of consultant; although a court could have potentially pierced the corporate veil to enforce a paramount equity, the corporate veil had never been pierced for a reason other than fraud.

Title: Ramlall v. MobilePro Corp.

Headnote: Fraud did not exist so as to warrant piercing of corporate veil of corporation that merged with client of consultant in action by consultant to secure payment of bonus fee from previous litigation; the mere fact that corporation created an acquisition subsidiary to effectuate a forward triangular merger did not constitute fraudulent action.

Title: Dowlings, Inc. v. Homestead Dairies, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil could not be pierced, and thus creditor could not recover against principal on claim against corporation for account stated, where principal did not use corporation as mere device to further his personal, rather than corporate, business or otherwise fully dominated corporation's activities and principal did not personally committed fraud.
Document Preview: TORTS - Damages. Punitive damages were not available on creditor's fraudulent conveyance claim against debtor's principal.

Title: In re Thompson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, creditor of automobile sales and leasing company could not pierce the corporate veil to hold debtors, who jointly owned and operated company, liable for its alleged nondischargeable debt; although debtors admittedly held ultimate control over company, bankruptcy court could not find that their control was so complete that corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, as required to apply alter ego doctrine, given that company had multiple levels of management, managers made many important company decisions, two other employees had banking authority, company had separate bank accounts, there was no indication that debtors used the accounts as their own private sources of funds or otherwise diverted corporate funds, and debtors observed corporate formalities, and, despite fact that company lacked funds to pay all of its debts, there was no evidence that debtors used company for wrongdoing, such as to commit fraud or other illegal or unlawful acts. 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debt arising from purchase of car by debtors' company was not obtained through false pretenses, false representation, or actual fraud.

Title: In re Thompson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, creditor of automobile sales and leasing company could not pierce the corporate veil to hold debtors, who jointly owned and operated company, liable for its alleged nondischargeable debt; although debtors admittedly held ultimate control over company, bankruptcy court could not find that their control was so complete that corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, as required to apply alter ego doctrine, given that company had multiple levels of management, managers made many important company decisions, two other employees had banking authority, company had separate bank accounts, there was no indication that debtors used the accounts as their own private sources of funds or otherwise diverted corporate funds, and debtors observed corporate formalities, and, despite fact that company lacked funds to pay all of its debts, there was no evidence that debtors used company for wrongdoing, such as to commit fraud or other illegal or unlawful acts. 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a)(2)(A).

Title: Estate of Bishop v. Mulholland
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court's decision to pierce corporate veil of debtor company, operating a vending machine business, and direct that two company owners were personally liable for money judgment obtained by creditors against company; the two owners of company governed all aspects of company's business, company did not have an operating bank account in its own name, owners operated business as a sole proprietorship with income and assets belonging to company without any compensation to the company, owners used company funds to pay personal expenses, company was operating at a loss and had filed for bankruptcy on three occasions, company's assets were misrepresented as owners' personal assets to prevent collection of judgment, and creditors would have been able to collect on judgment if not for owners' misrepresentation.

Title: Wolters v. Lakey
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Assuming Missouri law applied, construction company's apparent undercapitalization, in the accounting sense, did not establish improper motive element of claim by company's judgment creditors to pierce the corporate veil to hold shareholders liable; company was formed for legitimate business purpose and had sufficient funds to operate for eight years, shareholder-principal enjoyed good reputation in his field for more than 30 years and homes he build consistently sold for over appraised value due to their quality, company's shareholders personally guaranteed millions in corporate loans as a matter of course, and shareholders' companies had experienced only typical disputes routinely faced by builders until judgment creditors' large, unforeseen arbitration award against company occurred.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Finding that debtors did not intend to hinder, delay, or defraud a creditor in acquiring homestead was not clearly erroneous.

Title: Wolters v. Lakey
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Assuming that Missouri law governed claim for piercing of the corporate veil by construction company's judgment creditors, bankruptcy court's finding that company's shareholders did not engage in improper siphoning of funds or assets from company supporting improper motive element of claim was not clearly erroneous; court found that company's assets were not traced to shareholders' homestead, shareholders did not use corporate funds to pay personal debts, and net effect of loans between company and shareholders was six-figure loss by shareholders.
