Title: In re Arnette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, principal for real estate rehabilitation companies, one organized as corporation and other as limited liability company (LLC), was liable for debts of companies under alter ego theory of piercing the corporate veil; principal and companies had blended finances, principal was sole owner/member and officer of both companies and exclusively controlled their operations, principal occasionally used his personal credit cards for corporation's purchases and comingled companies' funds with his personal funds without proper documentation, and principal, acting through companies, defrauded investor, yet companies were out of business and had no assets to satisfy judgment in investor's favor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Expert South Tulsa, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, alter ego remedy against principals of corporate debtor belongs to creditors generally, and should not inure to the benefit of a single creditor to the prejudice of others.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Debtor Protections. Postpetition actions taken against debtor's principals in state court violated automatic stay, and were void.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Lind Stoneworks, Ltd. v. Top Surface, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to impose individual liability on countertop fabricator's sole corporate shareholder by piercing the corporate veil, in action by countertop fabricator to collect on unpaid invoices, absent any showing that shareholder exercised control over the corporation in a way that constituted fraud or an illegal act.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Incorporation. Evidence was insufficient to support finding that counter top installation company was not a valid corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Sharif
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Property of debtor in possession, custody, and control of alter ego comprises "property of the estate" as of commencement of case, and bankruptcy courts have power to disregard separate corporate entities so as to reach assets of non-debtor alter ego to satisfy debts of debtor. 11 U.S.C.A. § 541(a)(1).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Judgment. Any legal error by bankruptcy court did not provide basis for relief from its judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Molinos Valle Del Cibao, C. por A. v. Lama
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law, as predicted by Court of Appeals, buyer under foreign currency exchange agreement could not pierce the corporate veils of two corporations that wrote bad checks in connection with transaction to hold seller under agreement liable under Florida's worthless check statute where seller was a director, not shareholder, of corporations, and corporations were owned by another corporate entity. West's F.S.A. §§ 68.065, 673.4021(3).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Under Florida law, as predicted by Court of Appeals, plaintiff could not pierce corporate veil to hold director liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Whitely v. Moravec
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Indiana does not require corporate investors to make good the firm's debts unless the conditions for piercing the corporate veil have been satisfied. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Employer's shareholders guaranteed only employees' wages, not payment of penalties for delayed remittance of wages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Antone's Records, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, corporate veil could not be pierced on "sham to perpetrate a fraud" theory, in order to hold principals of recording companies liable for not making timely royalty payments to musician, given lack of evidence that recording companies were used as sham to perpetuate fraud, either generally with respect to all recording artists, or even specifically with respect to payments owed to musician, given that royalty payments were eventually tendered, albeit eight days beyond 30-day "cure" period specified in musician's contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Showing of actual fraud was necessary to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Antone's Records, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, corporate veil could not be pierced on "alter ego" theory, in order to hold personally liable for royalty payments not timely tendered to musician an individual who was owed over $400,000 on loans which he had made to recording companies, who did not appear to have derived any direct personal benefit from companies' alleged misconduct, and who was not involved in companies' day-to-day decisions.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Showing of actual fraud was necessary to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Automotive Finance Corp. v. Joliet Motors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, automobile dealership and dealership's sole owner had unity of interest and ownership, as required to pierce dealership's corporate veil and hold owner personally liable for judgment obtained against dealership; dealership had failed to keep general ledger during its first five months of operation, owner did not know how she incorporated dealership or if she filed any papers or paid any fees to incorporate dealership, owner did not know value of her shares in dealership or how many shares of dealership's stock were issued, and owner commingled her funds with dealership's funds, used dealership's funds to pay ex-husband's mortgage obligations, and used dealership funds to pay personal bills.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of dealership's corporate veil to hold its sole owner personally liable for judgment obtained against dealership was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Automotive Finance Corp. v. Joliet Motors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence for automobile dealership would have sanctioned fraud, promoted injustice, or promoted inequitable consequences, and thus piercing of dealership's corporate veil to hold its sole owner personally liable for judgment obtained against dealership was warranted; dealership collected predecessor corporation's accounts receivable and forwarded money to predecessor corporation's owner, dealership's owner knew that dealership collected money that predecessor corporation's secured creditors were attempting to recover, and dealership's owner used corporate funds to pay her personal expenses.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of dealership's corporate veil to hold its sole owner personally liable for judgment obtained against dealership was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: MMG Financial Corp. v. Midwest Amusements Park, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Lender, which financed borrower's purchase of 24 go-karts for borrower's racetrack, was not responsible for seller's alleged breaches of warranty, even though lender and seller shared an ownership interest; lender and seller were distinct corporations and were not responsible for each others' liabilities merely because they shared a corporate relationship, and borrower offered no reason why the corporate form should be disregarded.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Evidence. Borrower's breach-of-contract evidence was correctly excluded as hearsay.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Atateks Foreign Trade, Ltd. v. Private Label Sourcing, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Liability in amount of $1.5 million could be imposed on dominating corporation under New York law for being dominated corporation's alter ego, although only $306,000 in commissions that should have been paid to dominated corporation had been paid to dominating corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego could be jointly and severally liable for all damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Ahcom, Ltd. v. Smeding
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: California law does not recognize an alter ego claim or cause of action that will allow a corporation and its shareholders to be treated as alter egos for purposes of all the corporation's debts.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Parties. Judgment creditor, rather than corporation's Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee, had standing to assert claim against corporation's shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: King v. Emerald Energy, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Owner of a corporation was using the business as an alter ego and was therefore liable for the debts of the corporation. Creditor loaned the corporation money on four occasions and sought to recover the money from the owner of the corporation, who was the sole member of the business. The owner admitted he had used the corporation for his personal benefit and that he failed to adequately capitalize the company. The owner used the loans for his personal benefit and did not pay them back.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Owner of a corporation was using the business as an alter ego and was therefore liable for the debts of the corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Motorola Credit Corp. v. Uzan
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, Cypriot company was judgment debtors' alter ego, and thus was liable to judgment creditors to same extent as judgment debtors, where company was owned by judgment debtor and another company owned by judgment debtor, company had previously asserted claims against Turkish government based solely on injuries sustained by companies owned by judgment debtors, and judgment debtor had publicly declared that he formed company and transferred his shares in other companies to it to ensure security of his shares.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Cypriot company was judgment debtors' alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: A.M. Buckler & Associates, Inc. v. Sanders
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: There was some evidence to support trial court's finding that sole proprietorship was separate and distinct business entity from closely held family corporation against whom judgment was obtained, for purposes of determining whether judgment creditor could garnish funds on contract that was originally with corporation but then modified to name proprietorship as contractor, where proprietorship had its own tax identification number and liability insurance, and proprietor's sons, who were sole shareholders of corporation, did not have ownership interest in proprietorship. West's Ga.Code Ann. § 18–4–1 et seq.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Garnishee assented to substitution of sole proprietorship for closely held corporation, against whom judgment had been entered, as contractor for construction of golf course, for purposes of sole proprietor's traverse in garnishment action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Tyson
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under English law, corporate form of Gibraltar shell corporation assigned international distribution rights for boxing match could not be pierced to hold liable for corporation's obligations parties that were legally unrelated to corporation, even if such unrelated parties used corporation as facade concealing true facts, in the absence of statutory authority authorizing such relief.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Under English law, corporate form of Gibraltar corporation could not be pierced to hold others liable for its obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Tyson
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under English law, corporate form of Gibraltar shell corporation assigned international distribution rights for boxing match initiated by Kentucky promoters could not be pierced to hold liable for Gibraltar corporation's obligations a British boxing promoter, his partnership and corporate minority partner, and partnership's chief executive officer (CEO) where, at the time Gibraltar corporation was introduced to transaction, such parties had not yet incurred any legal obligations to boxer or Kentucky promoters with respect to sale of international rights and existence of Gibraltar corporation was not concealed from boxer or Kentucky promoters.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Under English law, corporate form of Gibraltar corporation could not be pierced to hold others liable for its obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Popowich v. Korman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Wife's loans made from her brokerage account, in which her separate property was commingled with marital property, to corporation formed by husband and partially owned by both husband and wife, were not required to be repaid by husband, under doctrine of piercing corporate veil, on grounds that he allegedly ran corporation and related entity as his alter ego while disregarding corporate forms, where neither corporation nor related entity were made parties to former wife's action for repayment of loans.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Equitable Distribution. Former wife's right to repayment of loans made to corporation partially owned by husband and wife was marital property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Hollybrook Cottonseed Processing, LLC v. Carver, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Louisiana, Monroe Division.
Headnote: Entity was a division of corporation and was therefore not a separate legal entity subject to liability regarding a suit filed by company that purchased cotton gin equipment from corporation. Company alleged that the cotton gin equipment it purchased from the corporation never operated properly and caused lost profits, wages and repair costs.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Entity sued by company was a division of a corporation and was therefore not a separate legal entity subject to liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re St. John
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Michigan.
Headnote: While general rule in Michigan is that corporation is separate legal entity from its directors and shareholders, in extraordinary circumstances, separate identities of corporation and those behind it may be disregarded, with the result that the individuals will be liable for corporation's debts.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. There was no underlying debt to support corporate creditor's nondischargeability complaint against debtor-officer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: 17315 Collins Ave., LLC v. Fortune Development Sales Corp.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Parent company used subsidiary for an improper purpose as required to pierce corporate veil when parent placed funds in subsidiary's operating accounts so that judgment creditor, who had judgment against parent, could not reach those funds, and caused those funds to be depleted by subsidiary without paying the obligation to judgment creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent company used subsidiary for an improper purpose as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Carlson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Under Idaho law, court would pierce corporate veil of transmission business and hold its sole shareholders liable for its debts where, although certain corporate formalities were followed, shareholders did not always treat company as a separate legal entity, shareholders purported to assign stock to themselves but no stock certificates were ever issued, regularly scheduled annual corporate shareholder meetings were not held after initial meeting, no voting or elections were held during company's business meetings and no minutes were kept, shareholders entered into a number of contracts in their personal capacity for corporation's benefit, when corporation ceased operation and its assets were sold, proceeds were deposited into shareholders' personal account, which was either an impermissible distribution prior to payment of creditors or another example of shareholders' intermingling of assets, and it would have been inequitable to recognize company as an independent legal entity. West's I.C.A. § 30–1–701.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Creditor did not justifiably rely on manager's misrepresentation concerning replacement of pick-up truck's converter.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re England Motor Co.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Mississippi.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, bank would not be allowed to pierce the corporate veils of a parent company to which it had loaned money and the parent company's two subsidiaries, so that it might set off the funds on deposit in subsidiaries' bank accounts against the outstanding balance owed by parent company on the loans; although there was evidence that entities' president disregarded their corporate forms, the evidence did not show either that bank actually believed that the deposit accounts of either subsidiary collateralized the loans made to the parent company or that bank would have been justified in holding such a belief, and, more importantly, there was no evidence whatsoever that president formed any of the subject entities for fraudulent or wrongful purposes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Substantive consolidation of parent company's case with those of its subsidiaries did not create setoff mutuality.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Apollo Real Estate Inv. Fund, IV, L.P. v. Gelber
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fifth Division.
Headnote: A judgment creditor may initiate an action to pierce the corporate veil to enforce a judgment against a corporation's shareholders.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Judgment. Assignee of judgment creditor had standing to enforce judgment against non-parties to the underlying litigation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: ASKM, LLC v. Fry
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: A creditor was able to obtain a prejudgment writ of attachment to seize various assets of a debtor's property under Utah law because it showed a substantial likelihood that it would be able to pierce the corporate veil. Defendant's deposition testimony showed that he did not observe corporate formalities, and his various entities assumed obligations for each other without consideration, documentation, oversight, or accountability. In addition, the evidence suggested that the defendant used the corporate form to enrich himself rather than repay the corporations' creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A creditor was able to obtain a prejudgment writ of attachment under Utah law because it showed a substantial likelihood that it would be able to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Gluth Bros. Const., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Western Division.
Headnote: Single debtor rule generally means that senior creditor cannot be forced by marshalling to resort to fund that is in hands of corporate debtor's shareholder or of surety or guarantor, except: (1) when corporation is alter ego of guarantor and court pierces corporate veil; (2) when the guarantor/shareholder has committed fraud or some other inequitable conduct; or (3) when pledged asset is found to be contribution to capital of corporation.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Loans. Trustees failed to state deepening insolvency claim against bank under Illinois law based on bank's forbearance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Fischer Inv. Capital, Inc. v. Catawba Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Lender sufficiently alleged that majority shareholder and director, a guarantor of a debt to lender, controlled corporation in order to defraud lender, as required to state a claim for piercing corporate veil to allow lender to reach corporation's property to satisfy debt; lender alleged that shareholder completely dominated corporation, that corporation failed to comply with corporate formalities, and that shareholder caused corporation to become undercapitalized by selling property, in order to avoid debt from being satisfied from shareholder's interest in property.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lender sufficiently alleged claim to pierce corporate veil of corporation of which guarantor was majority shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: McCallum Family L.L.C. v. Winger
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. VII.
Headnote: The mere fact that corporate creditors would go unsatisfied because they cannot reach a shareholder's personal assets does not, alone, justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The burden of proof in an action to pierce the corporate veil is by a preponderance of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Hecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, when the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil applies, a creditor that is nominally a creditor of a corporation or limited liability company (LLC) can collect its debt from an individual personally.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor could not reverse-pierce corporate veil to claim Minnesota homestead exemption in property owned by LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: While, as result of financing and "lockbox" arrangement between corporate parent and its subsidiaries, pursuant to which parent alone obtained credit facility sufficient to fund operations of itself and its subsidiaries, disbursed funds to subsidiaries as needed, and later swept subsidiaries' accounts, debtor-subsidiary was never permitted to accumulate cash independently of parent, and while debtor, its corporate parent and affiliated entities shared common directors and officers and filed consolidated financial statements, debtor's operations were sufficiently separate to prevent trustee from piercing corporate veil and holding parent and affiliated entities liable for debtor's debts on alter ego theory, where debtor owned its own property, entered into its own facilities lease, maintained its own bank account, and was not shown to have misrepresented its financial condition or engaged in any other misconduct.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. Auginaush v. Medure
Court: White Earth Band of Chippewa Tribal Court, Civil Division.
Headnote: The practice of "piercing the corporate veil" is generally a creditor's remedy used to reach an individual who has used a corporation as an instrument to defraud creditors.
Document Preview: NATIVE AMERICANS - Gaming. Tribal court had jurisdiction over tribe's claims against non-member gaming corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: John Daly Enterprises, LLC v. Hippo Golf Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced under Florida law so as to subject wholly owned United States subsidiary liable for default judgment obtained against English parent in a prior action where plaintiff failed to demonstrated that parent and subsidiary existed as separate corporate entities for an improper purpose.
Document Preview: TORTS - Privacy. Use of professional golfer's name and likeness of company's website violated Florida statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Smith v. Simmons
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, corporation's sole shareholder was not liable under alter ego theory for corporation's debts, even though corporation had only shareholder and one part time employee operating its business, where corporation maintained separate financial existence from shareholder, maintaining separate bank accounts, paying its employees out of corporate funds, keeping corporate office, and not commingling debts, various individuals took officer roles within corporation, board meetings were conducted with requisite formality, and there was no evidence that corporation engaged in any bad faith conduct.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Guaranty. Buyer corporation's vice president did not personally guarantee its obligations under asset purchase agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Tredit Tire & Wheel Co., Inc. v. Regency Conversions, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, supplier of specially designed and manufactured tires and wheels stated a claim against secured lender that had obtained an interest in conversion van manufacturer through foreclosure, seeking to recover against lender for manufacturer's delinquent payments under theory of piercing the corporate veil, by alleging that manufacturer became a mere instrumentality of lender, that lender caused manufacturer to breach its contractual obligations to supplier, and that manufacturer ceased paying down its outstanding debt after lender became involved in its business operations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff stated a claim against defendant under theory of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Equity Trust Co. Custodian ex rel. Eisenmenger IRA v. Cole
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Principals were personally involved in the ownership, management, and operation of corporate entities involved in a large-scale real estate fraud scheme, and principals were alter egos of the entities, and thus corporate veil could be pierced so as to make principals personally liable for default judgment entered against entities; principals had oral agreement dividing ownership shares in the entities, were treated as officers or directors of the entities with equal authority to act on behalf of the entities, were actively involved in managing the entities and marketing entities' investment schemes, principals did not observe corporate formalities, entities were undercapitalized and not financially independent, and principals transferred and withdrew large sums of money between and from entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of entities involved in real estate fraud could be pierced under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Holme v. Global Minerals and Metals Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In judgment creditor's action seeking to collect judgment against corporate debtor, its shareholders, and other related corporate entities, allegations that corporation's individual shareholders caused corporation to cease doing business, stripped it of assets, and left it a "moribund shell" in order to avoid payment of contractual obligation underlying creditor's judgment, but continued to operate corporation's business through other entities showed continuity, domination, and fraudulent transfers by defendants that were sufficient to state causes of action seeking to hold corporation's individual shareholders liable for creditor's judgment against corporation on theory that they were corporation's "alter egos," and to impose same liability on related corporate entity on theory that it succeeded to corporation's obligations pursuant to de facto merger.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor sufficiently pleaded alter ego claim against corporate shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Peyton Place, Condominium Associates, Inc. v. Guastella
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Condominium owner and his related corporate entities were not liable in solido to condominium association for unpaid condominium fees and assessments under alter ego or single business enterprise theories, as none of owner's associated entities was ever undercapitalized and each maintained a separate bank account, each entity's corporate books and records were separately maintained, a corporate tax return was filed for each entity, and each entity was properly formed under state law.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Attorney Fees. Court did not abuse it discretion in assessing attorney fees to unit owner on condominium association's principal demand against owner.

Title: In re Two Springs Membership Club
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Newly formed entity that was established by principal of corporate judgment debtor solely for purpose of accepting gratuitous transfer of real property owned by corporation, so as to protect property from liability on judgment debt, had to be regarded as corporation's alter ego, regardless of whether court applied Delaware, Nevada, or federal veil-piercing law, where this newly formed entity, after succeeding to corporation's interest in property, continued to use it to operate campground just as corporation had done prior to transfer, neither the members of campground nor employees who worked there were informed about, or would have noticed, this change in ownership, and entity's formation and transfer of property to it were both motivated by desire to defraud corporate judgment creditor and to work an injustice.

Title: Greiling v. Zahoudanis
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: A third party creditor's outside reverse piercing theory, alleged as an alter ego theory, in a fraudulent transfer claim failed as a matter of law. Although the creditor attempted to apply an alter ego theory, the factual scenario called for application of the outside reverse piercing theory. The third party creditor sought to pierce the corporate veil from the outside, attempting to have the Corporate Defendants satisfy the claims against Individual Defendants. While some courts have applied outside reverse piercing, California courts recognize that such a remedy is "an unacceptable shortcut" because "conversion and fraudulent conveyance already afford judgment creditors [an adequate remedy]."
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A third party creditor's outside reverse piercing theory, alleged as an alter ego theory, in a fraudulent transfer claim failed as a matter of law.

Title: In re LMcD, LLC

Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, even assuming that veil could be pierced to hold bankrupt limited liability company's (LLC's) member personally liable for its debts, corporate veil that existed between member and closely-held corporation through which he operated well known restaurant could not be reverse pierced in order to hold corporation liable for LLC's debts, where no evidence was presented that corporation failed to keep records or to observe corporate formalities, where corporate assets were not siphoned away for benefit of stockholders, and where no evidence was presented of any use of corporate form to perpetrate fraud.

Title: Monteleone v. The Leverage Group
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: The corporate defendants were liable jointly and severally for the conduct of their shareholder based on a reverse veil piercing theory. The corporate defendants and their shareholder were sued on several counts based on an investment scheme. In their motion for summary judgment, the plaintiffs alleged that the corporate defendants should be held liable for the conduct of their shareholder. The evidence indicated that none of the corporate defendants has any manager, director, or owners other than the defendant shareholder. Also, bank records indicated that the shareholder used funds from the corporate defendants for his personal expenses. Finally, there was no evidence that any corporate defendant operated independently of the shareholder in any way.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The corporate defendants were liable jointly and severally for the conduct of their shareholder based on a reverse veil piercing theory.

Title: MM Arizona Holdings LLC v. Bonnano
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary's motion to dismiss a guarantor's counterclaims was granted where the guarantor's brief in opposition made clear that the wrongs alleged were committed, if at all, by the subsidiary's parent corporation, and the guarantor's allegations were insufficient to warrant corporate veil piercing. The guarantor contended that the subsidiary and its parent corporation were not distinct entities. However, if that were true, then the automatic stay in bankruptcy granted for the parent corporation would necessarily extend to claims against the subsidiary, and the court would therefore not be able to take any action regarding the counterclaims. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rules 13, 19, 20, 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Evidence supported the dismissal of a guarantor's counterclaims against a subsidiary because the guarantor's claims were against the parent corporation.

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Jahelka

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Jahelka

Title: In re Freier
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, corporate veil of company of which Chapter 7 debtor was sole shareholder, officer, director, and employee would be pierced to hold debtor personally accountable for debt owed to concrete supplier; debtor operated company fraudulently and in breach of fiduciary duties owed supplier, company had no apparent capitalization, corporate formalities were not observed, of substantial amounts taken by debtor from company over two years for his personal benefit, only distribution of certain retained earnings were accounted for as taxable income to him, and all remaining payments to him or on his behalf were treated as legitimate corporate expenses, company was insolvent, and debtor's creation of second corporation, abandoning first company for same type of work with first company's assets, showed that both corporations were merely facades for debtor's individual dealings.

Headnote: Under Illinois law, judgment creditor failed to demonstrate that judgment debtor was an alter ego of parent company, as required to pierce the corporate veil and hold parent liable for judgment debtor's debt; judgment creditor provided no evidence that judgment debtor maintained a lower capitalization than the law required, the only evidence that debtor failed to observe corporate formalities was its failure to file tax returns for a few years, which was not enough to justify treating judgment debtor as a mere shell, and although parent company used a cash management system, judgment creditor did not cite any evidence to counter parent company's assertions that it maintained a strict accounting of each subsidiaries' balance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, judgment creditor failed to provide any evidence that either the secretary/treasurer or vice president of sales of judgment debtor exercised ownership control over judgment debtor to such a degree that the separate personalities of the judgment debtor and its secretary/treasurer and vice president of sales did not exist, and that judgment debtor was a business conduit of its secretary/treasurer and vice president of sales, as required to hold either the secretary/treasurer or the vice president of sales liable for judgment debtor's debt under a veil-piercing theory.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor failed to demonstrate that debtor was alter ego of parent company, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Taurus IP, LLC v. DaimlerChrysler Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Absent showing that corporation was not likely to satisfy a judgment against it for breach of contract, justice could be served without establishing manager's alter ego liability by piercing the corporate veil under Texas law; there was no evidence that manager had ever before directed any of his entities to avoid paying debts or satisfying judgments.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Injunction. Defendants were not entitled to injunction against persons who acted in concert with party which breached settlement agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Postal Instant Press, Inc. v. Kaswa Corp.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Even if the theory of outside reverse piercing of the corporate veil was available for use by creditors to reach corporate assets to satisfy a shareholder's personal liability, judgment creditor could not use it to reach assets of corporation in which judgment debtor was formerly a shareholder, where debtor was not the sole shareholder, absent evidence that innocent creditors would be adequately protected and that judgment creditor's legal remedies were inadequate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Third party creditors may not pierce corporate veil to satisfy a shareholder's personal liability from corporate assets.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Michigan Elec. Employees Pension Fund v. Encompass Elec. & Data, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Veil piercing and alter ego concepts are separate and distinct; in general, efforts to "pierce the corporate veil" ask court to hold one entity vicariously liable for another's debts, whereas contention that one entity is the other's "alter ego" asserts that they are the same entity and liability then is not vicarious but direct.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Electrical contractor whose president signed letters of assent was bound by CBAs expressly incorporated by reference therein.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Novae Corporate Underwriting Ltd. v. Atlantic Mut. Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: British indemnitor of foreign judgment creditor lacked basis to enforce underlying United Kingdom judgment, in suit seeking payment from Pennsylvania parent corporation of insolvent British judgment debtor, parent's insurer, and parent's principal client, under Pennsylvania's Uniform Foreign Money Judgment Recognition Act, authorizing transfer and enforcement of judgment for named parties, since parent, insurer, and client were not named in judgment, mere status as parent corporation did not require payment of insolvent subsidiary's obligations as separate entity, and allegations that parent and subsidiary were one and same company with profits flowing directly to same principal did not warrant piercing corporate veil. 42 P.S. §§ 22003, 22004(1), 22005(2, 3).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Indemnity. Indemnitor of foreign judgment creditor lacked basis for enforcement against parties not named in judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Anderson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, piercing of the corporate veil, so as to make companies' principal liable for their debts to creditor, was not warranted, given that one company had adequate capital at the time principal took loan for another business from it, that principal annually filed franchise tax reports and federal and state income tax returns, even though he did not maintain good minute books for companies or adequately document loan, that businesses were profitable for considerable period of time, and that principal's actions respecting companies' assets did not amount to promotion of fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 7 debtor did not made transfers of non-exempt funds to his home mortgage lender with fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Pamperin v. Streamline Mfg., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee. Western Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: A "corporate veil" may be pierced, that is, the legal entity disregarded and the true owners of the entity held liable, when the corporation is liable for a debt but is without funds due to some misconduct on the part of the officers and directors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Hot tub buyer established that it was necessary to pierce corporate veil to reach shareholder of insolvent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Pamperin v. Streamline Mfg., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee. Western Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: Shareholder, who was one of two sole shareholders of corporation that sold hot tub products, and who was removed as director and officer from the corporation pursuant to court order in underlying litigation with the other shareholder, did not receive any of the corporation's assets or funds and did not otherwise engage in any misconduct that would justify piercing the corporate veil to hold him individually liable to a hot tub buyer for the corporation's acts, resulting from the underlying litigation, in failing to deliver a hot tub it sold to a buyer, and in failing to return buyer's deposit money on the hot tub; the other shareholder approved all the corporation's expenditures, and a receiver was appointed to oversee the corporation's finances during the litigation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Hot tub buyer established that it was necessary to pierce corporate veil to reach shareholder of insolvent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: ColtTech, LLC v. JLL Partners, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: District court would not pierce subsidiary's corporate veil to hold parent company liable for subsidiary's acts, absent evidence of wrongful conduct allowing the court to disregard subsidiary's corporate form and impose liability on parent for subsidiary's debt.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Sole member of second limited liability company (LLC) was not liable for LLC debt arising of purchase orders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: American Heritage, Inc. v. Nevada Gold & Casino, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Owner of casino development corporation was not personally liable for satisfaction of judgment against corporation, on grounds that corporation was owner's alter ego, even though owner had advertised himself as corporation's boss, Subchapter S tax treatment applied, owner had personally guaranteed loans, corporation had issued stock warrants to owner, and corporation had paid insurance on owner's luxury cars; there was no undercapitalization, commingling of assets, or acts leading judgment creditor to believe it was dealing with owner individually, rather than corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Representative of repudiated contract partner could testify regarding lost profits.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Cadle Co. v. Zubretsky
Court: Superior Court of Connecticut, Judicial District of Hartford.
Headnote: The plaintiff qualified for a reverse piercing of the corporate veil in order to satisfy debts owed to it. The defendants were the parents of the debtor. The parents dominated the corporation, which was really the asset of the son, in order to shield the son from creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The plaintiff qualified for a reverse piercing of the corporate veil in order to satisfy debts owed to it when the parents of the debtor ran his corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Massey v. Conseco Services, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation that loaned money to directors of parent corporation in order to purchase stock of parent corporation was not an alter ego of the parent corporation, and thus, corporate director that participated in loan program could not pierce the veil of subsidiary corporation to hold it liable for parent corporation's actions, where there was no evidence that the corporations abused the corporate form or that such abuse resulted in a fraud or injustice to directors that participated in loan program.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subsidiary corporation that loaned money for purchase of parent corporation stock was not alter ego of parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Greater St. Louis Const. Laborers Welfare Fund v. Mertens Plumbing and Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: A creditor's bill in equity under Missouri law enables a judgment creditor to trace the value of the goods and services rendered to an empty-shell corporation to the parties behind such a corporation who have received and benefited from the property or services.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. LLC and corporation were alter egos of judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Lollis v. Turner
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Georgia did not recognize cause of action for outsider reverse piercing of corporate veil, and thus, judgment creditor who had obtained default judgment against Florida defendant had no cause of action against court clerk for alleged failure to provide judgment creditor with notice of release of funds paid into court registry in unrelated lawsuit to codefendant corporation for which defendant was officer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Georgia did not recognize cause of action for outsider reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Fletcher-Harlee Corp. v. Szymanski
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Concrete company against which general contractor had obtained a judgment was undercapitalized, which was factor considered in determining whether piercing company's corporate veil to hold shareholder liable for judgment was justified; when company was faced with mere prospect of defending company in arbitration against allegations raised by general contractor, company decided not to defend itself, to cease doing business, and subsequently to file for bankruptcy.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil to hold sole shareholder of company personally liable for judgment against company was justified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Fletcher-Harlee Corp. v. Szymanski
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: General contractor, which had obtained judgment against concrete company and sought to pierce company's corporate veil and hold company's sole shareholder liable for judgment, failed to sufficiently demonstrate that shareholder used company to make a knowing misrepresentation which induced contractor to act or fail to act, as necessary to establish that shareholder perpetrated a fraud upon contractor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil to hold sole shareholder of company personally liable for judgment against company was justified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Fletcher-Harlee Corp. v. Szymanski
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil to hold sole shareholder of concrete company against which general contractor had obtained judgment personally liable for the judgment was justified; company was undercapitalized, shareholder failed to adhere to corporate formalities, he intermingled his personal and corporate affairs, at least to some extent, he disregarded the separate legal status of company, which further rendered company's corporate form to be a sham, and it was clear that separate legal statuses of shareholder's businesses in general, and of company in particular, were, at best, ephemeral.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil to hold sole shareholder of company personally liable for judgment against company was justified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Sudamax Industria e Comercio de Cigarros, Ltda v. Buttes & Ashes, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky, Bowling Green Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, a corporate veil may not be pierced without a showing of fraud or injustice separate and apart from the corporation's failure to pay its debt.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Evidence did not warrant piercing veil of limited liability company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Coppola v. Bear Stearns & Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under traditional principles of lender liability, a creditor that has not assumed the formal indicia of ownership may become liable for the debts of its borrower if the lender's conduct is such as to cause it to become the debtor's agent, partner, or alter ego.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Employer's creditor was not itself an employer within under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Priskie v. Missry
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Chairman of board of directors did not act improperly in obtaining corporate loan from shareholder, as required to pierce the corporate veil and hold chairman personally liable for the debt, even though chairman told shareholder he would repay the loan from proceeds of a personal real estate venture and chairman failed to obtain permission of board for the loan, given that the loan was used for corporate purposes and not for chairman's personal use, unauthorized act of obtaining corporate loan was later ratified by the board, and chairman wanted loan to reduce the need to use his own personal funds for corporate purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Chairman of board of directors was not personally liable for a corporate loan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Priskie v. Missry
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: It is not improper for a shareholder or officer of a corporation, with the corporation's knowledge and consent, to loan his personal funds to the corporation for payment of corporate debts nor does it give rise to personal liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Chairman of board of directors was not personally liable for a corporate loan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Semande v. Estes
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District.
Headnote: Director of corporation, as judgment creditor of corporation, was not entitled to invoke the equitable doctrine of piercing the corporate veil, to collect the judgment from majority shareholder; director had an obligation to obtain information about the corporation that he served, and he therefore did not stand in position of innocent third-party creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Director could not pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Mid-South Mgt. Co. Inc. v. Sherwood Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: General partnership that brought suit against corporation and its parent companies, seeking to recover corporation's portion of a settlement in action brought by homeowners' association against corporation and general partnership, who had formed a joint venture to develop a multi-unit condominium complex, failed to prove the necessity for piercing the corporate veil of corporation; corporation observed corporate formalities, and even assuming corporation failed to observe corporate formalities, general partnership failed to prove that failure to pierce the corporate veil would result in fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Partnership failed to prove sufficient number of Sturkie factors to justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Mid-South Mgt. Co. Inc. v. Sherwood Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Alter-ego theory, which required a showing of total domination and control of one entity by another and inequitable consequences caused thereby, was inapplicable to hold corporation's parent companies liable in lawsuit brought by general partnership against corporation and its parent companies, seeking to recover corporation's portion of a settlement in action brought by homeowners' association against corporation and general partnership, who had formed a joint venture to develop a multi-unit condominium complex; while corporation's officers also held positions in the parent companies, corporation maintained separate corporate records, and there was nothing inappropriate about corporation's transfer of money to its parent companies to repay a debt.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Partnership failed to prove sufficient number of Sturkie factors to justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Mid-South Mgt. Co. Inc. v. Sherwood Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Amalgamation of interest theory was inapplicable to hold corporation's parent companies liable in lawsuit brought by general partnership against corporation and its parent companies, seeking to recover corporation's portion of a settlement in action brought by homeowners' association against corporation and general partnership, who had formed a joint venture to develop a multi-unit condominium complex; there was no evidence that general partnership could have confused corporation with its parent companies.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Partnership failed to prove sufficient number of Sturkie factors to justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re B.L. Jennings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: It is not a sufficient basis for piercing the corporate veil under California law merely to show that creditor will remain unsatisfied if corporate veil is not pierced.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfer of unencumbered property for no consideration after debtor was named as tort defendant was fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Trossman v. Philipsborn
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Sixth Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil of partners' corporation could not be reverse pierced to allow payments made by corporation pursuant to guaranty to be treated as being made by partners individually, and therefore partners were not entitled to contribution from limited partner, as co-guarantor, pursuant to guaranty; reverse piercing could not be used to benefit partners in their status as corporation shareholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Partner was not equitably estopped from changing his reasons for not paying pro rata share of loan under guaranty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Mosaica Education, Inc. v. Pennsylvania Prevailing Wage Appeals Board
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Management company for charter school was not an instrumentality of the school and thus was not subject to the Prevailing Wage Act under a piercing the corporate veil theory for purposes of school renovation contract between company and general contractor, although company assisted school in preparing its charter school application and was sole shareholder of school building's owner; there were no public funds expended and there was no public project, management company was not a shell corporation but rather was a separate entity that dealt with the school as such, and management company and building owner did not act on the school's behalf in a manner legally binding on the school.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Labor and Employment. Charter school management company was not a contractor under the Charter School Law's Prevailing Wage Act requirements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Jamuna Real Estate LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, there was no basis for piercing corporate veil to hold debtor corporations' principals personally liable for corporations' debts, despite evidence of undocumented lending, absent allegation that principals took advantage of their corporations and harmed creditors thereby, or that corporations were undercapitalized.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Professionals. Doctrine of in pari delicto did not bar Chapter 7 trustees from asserting RICO claims against debtor corporations' principals

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Nimbus Technologies, Inc. v. SunnData Products, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, creditor of defunct corporation could not be held liable for corporation's debts under veil-piercing theory.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. Creditor of defunct corporation could not be liable for intentional interference with business relations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Parmalat Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Subsidiaries of Italian company in reorganization proceedings were not liable under a theory of reverse veil-piercing for acts of Italian company, for purposes of claims brought by bank that acted as private placement agent for company, alleging that company and subsidiaries structured transactions that permitted corrupt insiders to loot the companies with impunity, where subsidiaries were incorporated in Italy, the Netherlands, or Luxembourg, and the laws of those countries did not provide for liability under a reverse veil-piercing theory.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Corporations were not vicariously liable for the acts of their officers and directors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Seghers v. El Bizri
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, lender's allegations that borrower was corporation's majority shareholder, commingled his assets with those of corporation, used corporate funds for personal use, conducted business without holding either directors' or shareholders' meetings, and maintained few or no records or minutes of any corporate proceedings established prima facie case for reverse piercing of corporate veil and corporation's liability on claims of fraud and breach of contract by shareholder.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court had personal jurisdiction over corporation based on reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, corporate form of Illinois subsidiary would not be disregarded and its parent corporation would not be held liable for judgment against subsidiary; notwithstanding parent's stock control and common officers and directors, both corporations respected the corporate form and also engaged in the legitimate collaboration expected between a parent and a subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not liable for judgment against subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Purchaser of portion of Illinois corporation's assets was not liable under Illinois law for corporation's judgment as corporation's alter ego or successor corporation; outside of the fact that purchaser operated in the same location as that previously occupied by corporation, there was no evidence that purchaser failed to maintain adequate corporate records, had commingled funds or assets with corporation, was undercapitalized, or treated corporation's assets as its own, the unity of ownership required to pierce the corporate veil was not present, and there was no evidence which would indicate that corporation's sale of its assets to purchaser was anything other than a legitimate transaction.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not liable for judgment against subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Regardless of whether parent corporation and its sole shareholder were alter egos, shareholder could not be held liable under Delaware law for judgment against subsidiary since parent was not alter ego of subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not liable for judgment against subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Sunset Hollow Properties, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: There are three widely-held exceptions to the "common debtor" requirement for marshaling, which apply (1) when the nondebtor, typically a corporate debtor's controlling shareholder who has guaranteed the debt and secured the guaranty with his or her own property, is the alter ego of the debtor, (2) when the nondebtor's property should equitably be deemed a capital contribution to the debtor, and (3) when the nondebtor has engaged in inequitable conduct.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Entirety of first mortgage had priority over second mortgage.
