Title: Stanley v. Mississippi State Pilots of Gulfport, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Corporate veil would be pierced to allow individual personal liability of corporate directors who admittedly conveyed corporate assets to themselves as "salary" in order to avoid corporate obligations to a judgment creditor; the directors knowingly defrauded a legitimate creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Successor corporation was liable for predecessor corporation's debt to judgment creditor after fraudulent conveyance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Stanley v. Mississippi State Pilots of Gulfport, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Directors may not violate their fiduciary duties to the corporation and prefer themselves over other legitimate creditors, and doing so may allow courts to pierce the corporate veil to hold directors personally liable for their acts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Successor corporation was liable for predecessor corporation's debt to judgment creditor after fraudulent conveyance.

Title: Stanley v. Mississippi State Pilots of Gulfport, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: When corporate officers participate in illegal diversions of corporate assets, the corporate veil may be pierced, allowing officers to be personally liable therefor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Successor corporation was liable for predecessor corporation's debt to judgment creditor after fraudulent conveyance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Meredith
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil, so as to hold sole shareholder liable for corporation's debts, was not warranted under Virginia law, inasmuch as there was no evidence that shareholder commingled her personal assets with those of corporation or that she disregarded corporate form, even though shareholder might have derived some benefits from corporation in terms of salary, and there was no evidence that shareholder knowingly participated in scheme to defraud creditors of her husband's accounting firm, from which assets were transferred to corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfers of assets of Chapter 7 debtor were made with fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: State ex rel. Neidig v. Superior Nat. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil of an insolvent corporation, a plaintiff must prove that (1) the defendant controlled the debtor corporation, (2) the defendant engaged in improper conduct, and (3) as a result of that improper conduct, plaintiff either entered into a transaction that it otherwise would not have entered into or plaintiff was unable to collect on a debt against the insolvent corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil requires some moral culpability of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, "unity of interest" prong of test for piercing corporate veil was satisfied as to successor construction business, as required for predecessor's liabilities to attach to company that coordinated predecessor's dissolution and successor's incorporation; successor was undercapitalized, there was no evidence that anyone ever held any actual ownership interest in successor, company was given final say in successor's cash or asset transfers, and two of successor's three director positions were filled by company's officers and directors.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Company was successor to dissolved entity, and bound by its union agreements, given identity of successor's operations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Soberg
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Individual Chapter 7 debtors who had carried out a dry wall installation business through their wholly owned corporation could not be held personally liable for corporation's debt, on theory that they had used their control over corporation to commit fraud by effectively stripping corporation of its assets for their personal benefit, where check that debtors had received from creditor seeking to pierce corporate veil was deposited in corporate account and used to purchase drywall for project at creditor's home, and where debtors, far from stripping corporation of assets, had infused money into corporation in unsuccessful attempt to preserve its business.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Individual debtors could not be held liable for corporate debt on veil-piercing theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: S.Z.S. Consultants, Inc. v. Howard
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Owner of family-owned company that was developing subdivision was personally liable to engineering consulting firm for unpaid balance on open account; owner did not maintain the identities of his family-owned corporations separate from him and neither he nor his corporations entered into a written agreement with consulting firm establishing the fact that he was acting on behalf of a particular corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Development company owner was personally liable for unpaid balance on open account.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Scully's Aluminum Crafts, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Louisiana's single business enterprise doctrine could not be applied to hold newly created corporate entities liable for defunct corporation's debts, where defunct corporation never did any business with, and was never associated in business enterprises with, any of these newly created corporate entities, but ceased operating shortly after these new corporations were formed, when defunct corporation's assets were transferred, first to its principal in repayment of prior advances, and then to these new corporate entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Trustee could not hold new corporations liable for debtor-corporation's debts on theory of successor liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: LM Ins. Corp. v. SourceOne Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, professional employer organization's (PEO) parent corporation did not act as PEO's alter ego, and thus could not be held liable for premiums PEO allegedly owed to insurer, even though both corporations were wholly owned by same individual, and parent's stock was offered as security for subsidiary's premium payments, where there was no evidence that PEO did not keep separate records, was undercapitalized, or that other monies were commingled, and individual was acting in his capacity as PEO's employee in his dealings with insurer.
Document Preview: TORTS - Conversion. Insurer failed to establish conversion claim against insured.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: LM Ins. Corp. v. SourceOne Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, professional employer organization's (PEO) sister corporation did not act as PEO's alter ego, and thus could not be held liable for premiums PEO allegedly owed to insurer, even though both corporations were wholly owned by same company, corporations shared office space and some employees, and some PEO employees fraudulently held themselves out as having positions or levels of authority in sister corporation that they did not have, where there was no evidence that PEO did not keep separate records, was undercapitalized, or that other monies were commingled, and PEO employees made statements without knowledge of sister's management.
Document Preview: TORTS - Conversion. Insurer failed to establish conversion claim against insured.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re WorldClass Processing, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The existence of a debtor-creditor relationship is not a basis, in and of itself, to find control required to establish lender liability of controlling corporation under total control test; rather, there must be actual, participatory, total control of the debtor corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Plans. Confirmed Chapter 11 plan barred debtor's assertion that creditor was undersecured as of petition date.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re WorldClass Processing, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under total control test for imposing lender liability on controlling corporation, a showing that debtor corporation has no separate independent corporate existence is required, and debtor corporation must be shown to have been used to further the purposes of the controlling corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Plans. Confirmed Chapter 11 plan barred debtor's assertion that creditor was undersecured as of petition date.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re WorldClass Processing, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Debtor corporation's allegations that corporate creditor had ability to appoint some of debtor's board members and refused to support certain board members, due to desire to begin new project that would require creditor to participate in refinancing plan, did not establish creditor's control over debtor to debtor's detriment, and thus did not support lender liability on part of creditor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Plans. Confirmed Chapter 11 plan barred debtor's assertion that creditor was undersecured as of petition date.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Blair v. Robinson
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: The existence of possible alternate remedies to satisfy judgment obtained against corporate vendor of manufactured home did not preclude purchasers from pursuing action against directors, seeking to pierce the corporate veil and hold them personally liable for judgment against vendor. West's N.C.G.S.A. § 1-352.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Directors of corporate vendor were not necessary parties to purchasers' original action against vendor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Tamko Roofing Products, Inc. v. Smith Engineering Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, an inequitable result would not occur based on failure to hold parent corporation liable for judgment obtained against wholly owned subsidiary, in action for fraudulent misrepresentation, breach of contract, and breach of warranty, and thus, alter ego doctrine would not be invoked against parent corporation; there was no showing that parent corporation was involved with any fraud against judgment creditor, or that parent corporation knew what representations that subsidiary made to judgment creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Alter ego doctrine would not be invoked against parent corporation for conduct of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Verestar, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, unsecured creditors committee pleaded allegations of misuse of corporate form with sufficient specificity to state claim against Chapter 11 debtor's parent corporation for alter ego liability, given committee's assertions that parent operated debtor as mere facade, manipulated debtor's board, stripped debtor of assets, and manufactured promissory note from debtor, that parent controlled debtor's core corporation functions, business, and cash, and that debtor failed to maintain its own employee records.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Committee stated claims for constructive fraudulent transfers, but not actual fraudulent transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: P.H.T. Systems, Inc. v. Tropical Flavors, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: After Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and majority shareholder of judgment debtor company fraudulently transferred restaurant that was the company's sole asset to a second company run by the same CEO, the trial court was warranted in piercing the corporate veil to hold the CEO and shareholder personally liable for the debt; CEO and shareholder abused the corporate form. M.S.A. § 513.47(a)(3)(iii).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's transfer of restaurant was fraudulent and in violation of state Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Smith
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: An alter ego finding in a post-judgment net worth proceeding, even if it is relevant to determining the maximum amount of security that judgment debtor can be required to post to obtain suspension of enforcement of money judgment during pendency of debtor's appeal from judgment, cannot be used to enforce the judgment against the unnamed alter ego or any other nonjudgment debtor. V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 52.006(b); Rules App.Proc., Rule 24.2(a)(1), (c)(3).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Appeals. Alter ego theory was relevant to security requirement for suspending judgment during pendency of appeal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Bridas S.A.P.I.C. v. Government of Turkmenistan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Intentionally bleeding a subsidiary to thwart creditors is a classic ground for piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Government of Turkmenistan could be liable for arbitration award as alter ego of its wholly-owned oil company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Holland v. Alker
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Sole shareholder of professional corporation could not establish that property owned by the corporation was his own personal property, and therefore, such property was not exempt from judgment creditors' turnover order requiring seizure of the property; sole shareholder was attempting to pierce his own corporate veil. V.T.C.A., Property Code §§ 42.001(a), 42.002 (a)(4).
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Debtor and Creditor. Judgment debtor's beneficiary was not entitled to homestead exemption to protect against turnover.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Bank One, NA v. Dunn
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Defendant was personally liable for judgment rendered against company in favor of bank, for overdrafts written on checking account, although company was incorporated, where account was opened up under defendant's name "d/b/a" the company, and bank account continued to list account owner under dba name.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Banks. Bank did not owe account holder a duty to protect him from Nigerian fraud scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Mitchell v. TAM Equities, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A parent corporation will not be held liable for the torts or obligations of a subsidiary unless it can be shown that the parent exercised complete dominion and control over the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent corporation was not putatively liable for employer's alleged discrimination against employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Douglas v. Bigley
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Investor in one litigation funding company failed to establish a basis for holding second litigation funding company liable on her claims against first company, despite investor's contention that second company merged with first company; there was no evidence in the record to support a finding of merger, and no evidence that the companies commingled assets, records or property, and principal of both companies testified that the companies maintained separate offices, kept separate records, and filed separate tax returns.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Issue of whether litigation funding company and its principals breached their fiduciary duties to investor was for the jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Riddle v. Simmons
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: "Reverse piercing" occurs when, through a legal action, assets of the corporate entity are reached to satisfy the obligations of a controlling alter ego; the alter ego may be a corporate shareholder or officer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Joint Ventures. Joint venturer who agreed to run gas pipeline business on co-owned property breached fiduciary duties to co-venturers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Dishon v. Ponthie
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court's finding that corporation was not shareholder's alter ego, and thus piercing of corporate veil was not warranted in concrete contractor's action to recover for allegedly unpaid concrete work; evidence indicated that shareholder followed all corporate formalities and had minimally kept records of shareholder or board of director meetings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Single-business-entity exception applied to first corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Dishon v. Ponthie
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil is allowed in certain exceptional instances in order to hold shareholders liable for corporate debt.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Single-business-entity exception applied to first corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Dishon v. Ponthie
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Single-business-entity exception applied to first corporation, which failed to pay concrete contractor, and thus piercing of corporate veil would be allowed so that contractor could recover from shareholder's second corporation, although corporations complied with corporate formalities and kept separate books; shareholder effectively owned and operated both corporations, first corporation's sole purpose was supplementary to operation of second corporation as holding company for owning and leasing post office buildings, and corporations were operated out of same office and used same phone numbers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Single-business-entity exception applied to first corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Rapid Displays Inc. v. Gorder
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Court of Appeals would not consider the extreme remedy of piercing the corporate veil, where corporation's judgment creditor was likely to receive adequate, if not full, satisfaction for its claims under the alternative theories of recovery.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Judgment. Loan to judgment debtor from shareholder was capital contribution subject to judgment creditor's claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Mobius Management Systems, Inc. v. West Physician Search, L.L.C.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: "Control" requirement for piercing the corporate veil was satisfied, where individual sought to be held liable for corporate debt owned 80 per cent of the company, often paid employees with his personal funds, failed to provide for any corporate resolution authorizing entry of consent judgment against company, and signed sublease, under which landlord sought rents, in his own name.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation was undercapitalized shell company, operated as such with intent to avoid legal obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Trust v. Kummerfeld
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Judgment creditor alleged facts sufficient to survive motion to dismiss veil-piercing action for failure to state a claim and creditor showed, as a matter of law, that sole officers and shareholders dominated closely-held corporation. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 12(b)(6), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Remand was required to consider whether shareholder used his domination to cause corporation to default on note.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Lindell
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Corporate veil could be pierced, for purpose of avoiding, as constructively fraudulent transfer of "interest of the debtors in property," a sale of promissory note by debtors' wholly owned corporation, given testimony that debtors had commingled personal and corporate funds, used corporate funds to pay their personal expenses, and otherwise disregarded corporate formalities and used corporation as a facade for their individual dealings. 11 U.S.C.A. § 548(a)(1)(B).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtors did not receive reasonably equivalent value for promissory note.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Shisgal v. Brown
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Creditors' allegations that owners of corporate debtors falsely represented that the loans were to be used for working capital or to purchase additional garages, that owners used money from loan for their personal benefit, that owners ran debtors without regard for corporate and bookkeeping formalities, that debtors were undercapitalized, and that commingling of corporate and personal funds was a regular and continuous practice supported creditors' claim to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Conduct of corporate owners warranted piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Association Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Seller of metals, seeking to pierce corporate veil of buyer in order to hold principals liable for debts, including a judgment confirming arbitration awards against corporation, demonstrated that principals disregarded separate existence of buyer and used buyer as their alter ego; corporate bookkeeping was not observed, government filings were not made, and millions of dollars worth of transactions were not reflected in financial records, which showed direct involvement of principals.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would be pierced in breach of contract case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Association Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Seller of metals, seeking to pierce corporate veil of buyer in order to hold principals liable for debts, including a judgment confirming arbitration awards against corporation, made necessary showing that domination of corporation by principals caused injuries; seller presented evidence that diversions of revenue for principals' own uses left buyer with insufficient funds to pay for metals.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would be pierced in breach of contract case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Brandon v. Anesthesia & Pain Management Associates, Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation was alter-ego of its shareholders, allowing corporate creditor to pierce corporate veil, so that shareholders were jointly and severally liable to creditor for judgment creditor had against corporation, under Illinois law, where corporation had practices of distributing all its profits as they accumulated in the form of bonuses to shareholders, and of deeming the corporation's accounts receivable as owned by the shareholders.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Payments made by corporation to shareholders and employees were fraudulent conveyances.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Taylor Steel, Inc. v. Keeton
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether the corporation is the alter ego of an individual, as required to pierce the corporate veil in an action to collect a debt, Ohio courts consider the following factors: (1) grossly inadequate capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time the debt is incurred, (4) shareholders holding themselves out as personally liable for certain corporate obligations, (5) diversion of funds or other property of the company property for personal use, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) the fact that the corporation was a mere facade for the operations of the dominant shareholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil to make sole shareholder liable in action on account was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Taylor Steel, Inc. v. Keeton
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Fact that steel brokerage corporation operated on a cash flow basis, with inadequate capitalization, was not determinative of whether brokerage was alter ego of sole shareholder, for purpose of piercing corporate veil, in action on an account against brokerage.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil to make sole shareholder liable in action on account was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Taylor Steel, Inc. v. Keeton
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, steel brokerage corporation was alter ego of sole shareholder, supporting the piercing of the corporate veil, so that sole shareholder of steel brokerage corporation would be liable to steel manufacturer for brokerage's failure to pay for steel shipments, in manufacturer's action on an account; shareholder exercised complete dominion over the brokerage, she alone decided to withhold payment for the steel after brokerage resold steel to another buyer, shareholder alone decided to refuse any phone calls or other attempted contacts from manufacturer, and she had sole control over movement of the brokerage's funds.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil to make sole shareholder liable in action on account was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Taylor Steel, Inc. v. Keeton
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Sole shareholder of steel brokerage corporation exercised her control over brokerage to commit an unjust act against manufacturer, supporting the piercing of the corporate veil, under Ohio law, as predicted by the Court of Appeals, so that sole shareholder of steel brokerage corporation would be liable to steel manufacturer for brokerage's failure to pay for steel shipments, in manufacturer's action on an account; shareholder not only refused to pay manufacturer the $88,345.78 the brokerage owed for the steel, even though it sold the steel to a third party and was paid by that third party, but also refused to negotiate with manufacturer and cut of all communication with manufacturer, and shareholder subsequently prevented manufacturer from recovering the debt from the brokerage by closing the brokerage's bank accounts, and setting up a new corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil to make sole shareholder liable in action on account was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Taylor Steel, Inc. v. Keeton
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, as predicted by the Court of Appeals, piercing of corporate veil to make sole shareholder of steel brokerage corporation liable to steel manufacturer for brokerage's failure to pay for steel shipments was warranted, in manufacturer's action on account; evidence established that shareholder was alter ego of brokerage, shareholder exercised her control over brokerage to commit an unjust act against manufacturer, and manufacturer was never paid for the steel it shipped to brokerage.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil to make sole shareholder liable in action on account was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Nursing Home Group Rehab. Servs., Inc. v. Suncrest Health Care, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Summit County.
Headnote: Creditors of a corporation may "pierce the corporation's veil" and hold individual shareholders liable only when the following three conditions are present: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiffs from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of nursing home owner would not be pierced.

Title: Mohammadpour v. Thomas
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Principal shareholder of corporation and successor corporation was not personally liable, under piercing corporate veil principle, to certified public accountant (CPA) for accounting debt incurred by corporation; corporations had mind, will, and existence of their own because all work CPA performed was for corporations, and fact that principal shareholder was only individual CPA had contact with at corporation, and fact that principal shareholder was only person individually charged by Internal Revenue Service (IRS) when IRS charged corporation with civil tax liabilities, were facts indicative of closely held corporation, but not necessarily of being able to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal shareholder was not personally liable for accounting debt incurred by corporation.

Title: U.S. v. Mountzoures
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced, so as to apply statute giving federal government priority when there was assignment for benefit of creditors of assets of subsidiary, which collected revenue from collect long distance telephone calls made by inmates and paid over sums to Bureau of Prisons (BOP), after parent which was signatory of monitoring and accounting contract with BOP became unable to perform contract; while there was some disregard of corporate informalities, on part of attorney supervising assets assignments, there was neither knowledge of existence of preference statute on part of attorney or BOP, or any attempt to use corporate form to avoid making required payments to government. 31 U.S.C.A. § 3713(a)(1)(A)(i).
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - United States. Statutory United States creditor benefit did not apply in absence of contractual relationship.

Title: In re Bridge Information Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, any alter ego action that attempts to hold controlling shareholders liable for specific transaction, rather than for corporation's debts generally, belongs to corporation and not to third-party creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Fraud claim was one for direct injury to debtor-corporation and included in bankruptcy estate.

Title: Boles v. National Development Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: Discarding the fiction of the corporate entity, or piercing the corporate veil, is appropriate when the corporation is liable for a debt but is without funds to pay the debt, and the lack of funds is due to some misconduct on the part of the officers and directors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of corporate developer that breach contract to build lake in recreational development was alter ego of developer.

Title: Boles v. National Development Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: When a corporation is liable for a debt but is without funds to pay the debt due to some misconduct on the part of the officers or directors, courts may pierce the corporate veil to find the true owners of the entity, or to impose liability against a controlling shareholder who has used the corporate entity to avoid his legal obligations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of corporate developer that breach contract to build lake in recreational development was alter ego of developer.

Title: Boles v. National Development Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: Once a trial court has determined that an individual is a corporate entity's other self and a judgment against the corporate entity is in place, then there is also in place a judgment against the individual who is the corporate entity's other self, because the individual is no longer a legally separate entity from the corporate debtor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of corporate developer that breach contract to build lake in recreational development was alter ego of developer.

Title: Baillie Lumber Co. v. Thompson
Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: Where the corporate entity is disregarded, a principal found liable under an alter ego theory should be liable for the entirety of the corporation's debt.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation may bring action against principal of corporation to recover on alter ego theory.

Title: In re Adelphia Communications Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Sole owner of limited partnership's corporate general partner did not dominate and control general partner so as to support piercing of the corporate veil under New York law to make owner individually liable for general partner's purported liability to limited partner, under contribution and indemnification theories, for any amounts owed to limited partnership's successor on claims alleging, inter alia, preferential and fraudulent transfers, given absence of factual allegations suggesting disregard of corporate formalities, or that owner used her alleged domination and control over general partner to benefit herself or general partner to limited partner's detriment.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Pleading. Debtor's motion for leave to file third-party complaint in avoidance adversary proceeding against it was untimely.

Title: In re Adelphia Communications Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, single instance of attempted self-dealing by sole owner of limited partnership's corporate general partner, in which owner allegedly sought amendment to limited partnership agreement that would have provided her with cash windfalls, did not support piercing of corporate veil, so as to make owner individually liable for general partner's purported liability to limited partner, under contribution and indemnification theories, for any amounts owed to limited partnership's successor on claims alleging, inter alia, preferential and fraudulent transfers, given that amendment was never executed by limited partner and its negotiation did not benefit owner, and that amendment was negotiated after transactions underlying successor's claims against limited partner and lacked requisite connection to those transactions and to limited partner's alleged harm.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Pleading. Debtor's motion for leave to file third-party complaint in avoidance adversary proceeding against it was untimely.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Adelphia Communications Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Wrongdoing in which sole owner of limited partnership's corporate general partner allegedly participated personally, including alleged preferential and fraudulent transfers of limited partnership's property to limited partner and limited partner's alleged breaches of contract, did not involve wrongdoing in contravention of rights of limited partner, but rather of interests of limited partnership, and therefore alleged wrongdoing did not support piercing of the corporate veil under New York law so as to hold owner individually liable to limited partner on its proposed claims for contribution and indemnification; only if limited partner actually paid judgment for which owner was liable could it make viable veil-piercing argument under contribution theory.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Pleading. Debtor's motion for leave to file third-party complaint in avoidance adversary proceeding against it was untimely.

Title: In re Adelphia Communications Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In light of the strong preference in favor of limiting shareholder liability under New York law, party seeking to bypass corporate formalities must actually have paid a portion of a judgment that is properly shareholder's liability before party's contribution claim may be the foundation for a veil-piercing argument.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Pleading. Debtor's motion for leave to file third-party complaint in avoidance adversary proceeding against it was untimely.

Title: Bank of Belton v. Bogar Farms, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to prove that asset transfers between husband's corporation and wife's corporation were the proximate cause of insolvency of husband's corporation and bank's inability to collect on judgment against husband and his corporation, and thus, bank was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil of wife's corporation on an alter ego theory to hold her corporation jointly liable for the judgment; although corporations made several financial transfers during relevant period, transfers resulted in husband's corporation receiving more money than it had paid out for the benefit of wife's corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations' financial transfers were not proximate cause of bank's injury of uncollectible judgment.

Title: Cementos de Chihuahua, S.A. de C.V. v. Intermodal Sales Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Evidence was legally insufficient to establish that sister corporation of manufacturing corporation was liable to shipping corporation for debts owed by import services corporation; there was a lack of privity between the parties, shipping corporation had no contact with sister corporation until import services corporation defaulted on its obligations, sister corporation paid all of its debts and obligations owed, there was no evidence that sister corporation functioned as the "alter ego" of manufacturing corporation, and there was no evidence that a corporate fiction was maintained to evade legal obligations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Evidence was legally insufficient to establish that sister corporation was liable to shipping corporation.

Title: Rimade Ltd. v. Hubbard Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Finding that corporate shareholder had not used corporation to commit fraud for his personal benefit, based on his conduct in not informing suppliers that sold merchandise to his corporation on credit that their bank had caused letter of credit securing corporation's debt to be cancelled, did not rise to level of clear error, given that shareholder was under no obligation to inform suppliers of cancellation of letter of credit that was caused by their own bank, and given that, after letter was cancelled, shareholder had caused corporation to pay down its outstanding debt to suppliers by amount that was more than four times amount of cancelled letter of credit, so as to undercut any suggestion that his nondisclosure was motivated by intent to deceive; thus, shareholder was not liable, on veil-piercing theory based on his nondisclosure, for corporation's debt for merchandise that suppliers thereafter provided and for which they did not receive payment. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subd. A(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil could not be pierced based on shareholder's alleged fraud.

Title: U.S. v. Runnells
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: A corporate veil may be pierced by an outside creditor when there is a showing by clear and convincing evidence that: (1) the entity has been used by the debtor to evade a personal obligation, to perpetuate a fraud or a crime, to commit an injustice, or to gain an unfair advantage, and (2) the unity of interest and ownership is such that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and adherence to that separateness would create an injustice.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Restitution. Restraining order was appropriate to prevent defendants from diverting or concealing assets.

Title: Sunbelt Environmental Services, Inc. v. Rieder's Jiffy Market, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division Two.
Headnote: Evidence that the corporate identity was used to defraud creditors, thereby warranting piercing the corporate veil, is the transfer by the debtor corporation of its property to a second corporation, when both corporations are controlled by the same person or entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil to impose liability on trustee, store, and transferee corporation.

Title: Cambridge Electronics Corp. v. MGA Electronics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Electronics supplier failed to demonstrate unity of interest between corporate customer and its sole shareholder, as required to pierce the corporate veil on grounds that shareholder was customer's alter ego under California law, given that corporate bookkeeper's alleged lack of knowledge as to where corporate records were kept did not establish that records did not exist, that there was no evidence that expenses paid by customer on shareholder's behalf were not ordinary business expenses, and that shareholder deferred his compensation and loaned customer $100,000, which belied allegation that he was siphoning off assets; sole incident in which shareholder allegedly took corporate funds for personal use was insufficient to show that shareholder treated corporate assets as his own.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Fraudulent Transfers. Payment made by corporation to shareholder's father was not fraudulent transfer.

Title: Rymal v. Baergen

Headnote: Traditional basis for piercing the corporate veil has been to protect a corporation's creditors where there is a unity of interest of the stockholders and the corporation and where the stockholders have used the corporate structure in an attempt to avoid legal obligations.

Headnote: In general, a corporation and a shareholder are separate and distinct, and the debts of the corporation are not the debts of the shareholder; however, when the corporate veil is pierced, the corporation and the individual become one and the same.

Headnote: Under Florida law, a corporation's veil will be pierced where the corporation's controlling shareholders formed or used the corporation to defraud creditors by evading liability for preexisting obligations; usual result of piercing the corporate veil is that the controlling shareholder or shareholders become liable for the corporate liabilities.

Headnote: More than a scintilla of evidence supported trial court's conclusion that corporation was alter ego of its principals, for purposes of action by corporation's creditors to pierce the corporate veil and hold principals personally liable for corporation's unpaid invoices; principals disregarded corporate entity by transferring all of corporation's assets to settle claims that were asserted, in part, against them personally, and thus permitting principals to shield themselves from liability to creditors would result in injustice.

Headnote: Foreign corporation's principal could not be held individually liable for corporate debt under alter ego doctrine on paramount equity basis, as there was no claim or evidence of fraud, although principal deliberately permitted corporation to operate without benefit of registration and with knowledge of existence of domestic corporation with identical name, where judgment creditor knew it was dealing with a corporation, and it had satisfied itself that corporation had two business location in state, that it had numerous employees, and that it was not a "one man show."

Title: LaMontagne Builders, Inc. v. Bowman Brook Purchase Group

Title: In re Intelefilm Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, there are circumstances in which court may disregard separate identities of corporation and its shareholders and pierce corporate veil in order to impose liability on shareholders for debt that is nominally that of corporation.

Title: In re Intelefilm Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, second prong of veil-piercing test, which focuses on relationship between claimant and corporation and on whether corporate form was used in unjust manner, may be satisfied on proof of actual false pretense or misrepresentation as to identity of real party with whom creditor was dealing; however, mere channeling of corporation's monies toward favored secured creditor, away from satisfying unsecured creditor-claimant, is not enough in itself.

Title: In re Intelefilm Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Alleged undercapitalization of corporate subsidiary, and corporate parent's use of loans to prop subsidiary up and to permit payment of its other creditors, while subsidiary vigorously, albeit unsuccessfully, disputed its liability to creditor that ultimately obtained judgment against it based on acts occurring before parent acquired its interest in subsidiary was insufficient to establish any misuse of corporate form, of kind required under Minnesota law in order to pierce corporate veil and to hold parent liable on judgment debt.

Title: Dana v. 313 Freemason
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that corporate entity that developed condominium was created to evade any personal liability that shareholders would have for problems with condominium roof, and thus piercing of corporate veil was appropriate, where both shareholders were aware that roof continually leaked from time it was installed and that roof contained major structural defects, but rather than repair roof, shareholders formed corporation and continued to market condominium with defective roof.

Title: State ex rel. Graeber v. Marion County Landfill, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: Compliance with statute requiring a judgment against corporation before piercing corporate veil to hold shareholders liable would have been useless and only have added delay and expense to proceeding, and thus, statute did not apply to preclude action to pierce corporate veil, where corporation was a party and its assets of only $1,000 would be insufficient to satisfy its alleged liability. K.S.A. 17-7101(b).

Title: Gerjets v. Davila
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Judgment creditor was not entitled to proceed against personal assets of corporate judgment debtor's former chief executive officer (CEO) and sole shareholder, without proceeding in a separate action to pierce the corporate veil; underlying judgment was only against the corporation, and thus, the CEO was a mere individual and stranger to creditor's judgment.

Title: Patrick V. Koepke Const., Inc. v. Paletta
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: A plaintiff claiming fraudulent transfer and seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, so that the corporate entity as to the transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) that such control was used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Debtor did not commit fraudulent transfer warranting piercing corporate veil.

Title: Patrick V. Koepke Const., Inc. v. Paletta

Headnote: Undercapitalization or stripping corporate assets to avoid the demands of creditors may justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Debtor did not commit fraudulent transfer warranting piercing corporate veil.

Title: Acree v. McMahan
Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: Georgia does not recognize reverse piercing of the corporate veil, at least to the extent that it would allow an outsider, such as a third-party creditor, to pierce the veil in order to reach a corporation's assets to satisfy claims against an individual corporate insider.

Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: "Outsider reverse veil-piercing," where it is recognized, extends the traditional veil-piercing doctrine to permit a third-party creditor to pierce the veil to satisfy the debts of an individual out of the corporation's assets.

Title: Berg v. Zummo
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation which operated bar, and another corporation, were single business enterprise, and thus, other corporation was liable for judgment against bar operation corporation, relating to personal injuries that pedestrian suffered from minor who was served alcohol at bar; bar operation corporation leased bar premises from other corporation, within days of judgment bar operation corporation terminated lease and relinquished to other corporation bar's equipment and its trade name without consideration, corporations had interlocking directorates, and directors acted in best interest of corporations as a whole.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence established single business enterprise for operation of bar.

Title: National Hotel Associates ex rel. M.E. Venture Management, Inc. v. O. Ahlborg & Sons, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: First corporation was operated as an instrumentality of second corporation, and thus liability for first corporation's judgment debt to property owner rested with the second corporation; although the first corporation's sole stockholder and second corporation scrupulously adhered to the usual corporate formalities to preserve the corporate protections afforded by law, first corporation wound up an empty shell, unable to pay the judgment because its assets were dissipated for the benefit of the stockholder and second corporation.

Title: District Council No. 9 v. APC Painting, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.

Title: Iceland Telecom, Ltd. v. Information Systems and Networks Corp.

Title: Island Seafood Co., Inc. v. Golub Corp.

Title: Island Seafood Co., Inc. v. Golub Corp.

Headnote: Judgment creditor failed to establish that person who owned both judgment debtor and a second corporation used his alleged dominion over second corporation to commit a wrong or injustice against creditor, as would warrant piercing of corporate veil permitting creditor to collect judgment from second corporation as alter ego of debtor, where creditor failed to prove its contention that owner formed corporation to avoid responsibility for paying judgment, and that debtor was using corporation for transaction of its business.

Title: Firstar Bank, N.A. v. Faul Chevrolet, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, automobile dealership's creditor was not entitled to pierce corporate veil to hold holding company that owned all stock in dealership and individual who owned all voting stock in holding company responsible for dealership's debts, even though individual owned dealership's property, dealership shared employees with other affiliated entities, individual spent time working on other affiliate matters while at dealership, individual personally guaranteed dealership's debts to manufacturer, and dealership paid for individual's wife's cellular phone and provided place for individual to park his boat, where dealership maintained adequate corporate records, complied with corporate formalities, did not commingle its funds or assets with those of holding company or individual, and was not so undercapitalized that it was pure shell, and holding company and individual were not unjustly enriched and did not create dealership's liabilities.

Title: In re Foxmeyer Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Fact that a creditor has been misled in some manner into reliance upon the parent corporation for the subsidiary corporation's debts is a basis for veil-piercing under Delaware law because it is but another form of fraud, which fraud goes to the use of a subsidiary's corporate form, but such "misleading and reliance" theory is applicable only if (1) the parent engages in misleading conduct vis-a-vis the subsidiary's creditors, and (2) such subsidiary's creditors act to their detriment because of such misleading conduct.

Title: In re Foxmeyer Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Even if Chapter 7 debtor-subsidiary's trade creditors were misled by debtor-parent corporation into relying on parent for payment of their claims against subsidiary, which inequity would generally have constituted an injustice warranting piercing of subsidiary's corporate veil under Delaware law, such inequity no longer constituted fraud or injustice where it had been fully remedied by the bankruptcy court's order granting substantive consolidation; by virtue of the substantive consolidation, trade creditors were now entitled to share in parent's assets.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Trustee failed to prove that debtor-subsidiary's corporate veil should be pierced.

Title: In re Foxmeyer Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Even if Chapter 7 debtor-subsidiary's trade creditors were misled by debtor-parent corporation into relying on parent for payment of their claims against subsidiary, trustee failed to establish that trade creditors relied upon parent's alleged misleading misconduct, and so piercing of subsidiary's corporate veil was not warranted under Delaware law; trade creditors continued to extend credit even after they were apprised that many of parent's assets had been transferred away for no return consideration.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Trustee failed to prove that debtor-subsidiary's corporate veil should be pierced.

Title: In re Foxmeyer Corp.

Headnote: Even if Chapter 7 debtor-subsidiary's trade creditors were misled by debtor-parent corporation into relying on parent for payment of their claims against subsidiary, parent's conduct was actionable such that veil piercing was compelled under Delaware law only if parent had an intent, by virtue of such conduct, to induce subsidiary's trade creditors to act or to refrain from acting.

Headnote: Customer could not pierce the corporate veil in order to make carpet store's president personally liable for store's failure to return deposit to customer following store going out of business after creditor placed judgment against store, since president testified both that he did not know of judgment until it was placed against store and that store, until placement of judgment, had been operating as it always had.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Customer could not pierce the corporate veil in order to make president personally liable.

Title: KLM Industries, Inc. v. Tylutki

Headnote: Materials supplier was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil for purposes of imposing personal liability on president of corporation that had not paid for materials regarding construction of single-family dwelling, since president did not own any shares, president exercised no more control than that of any other president of a closely held corporation, corporation maintained its returned checks and statements, corporation filed and maintained its corporate tax returns, and corporation filed its biannual reports. Title: Smith v. World Fresh of California, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Judgment against judgment-debtor could be amended to include second corporation, under alter ego and successor corporation liability theories, where same person was sole shareholder of both corporations, corporation had possession of and was utilizing few remaining assets of debtor, corporation did not pay debtor any consideration for assets, corporation was operating substantially the same business as debtor, corporation issued shares of stock to sole shareholder but no consideration was paid for shares, and corporation did not observe corporate formalities.

Title: In re Icarus Holdings, LLC.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Georgia, Macon Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law as predicted by bankruptcy court, debtor-corporation could have asserted alter ego claim to pierce its own corporate veil and to hold its former principal liable for its corporate debts, so that these alter ego claims were included in "property of the estate," and could not be asserted by individual creditors outside bankruptcy, unless claims were first abandoned by debtor-in-possession; debtor-in-possession, rather than individual creditors, had exclusive standing to pursue such claims. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 541(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Alter ego claims were included in property of debtor-corporation's estate.

Title: U.S. Fidelity and Guar. Co. v. Braspetro Oil Services Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Theories of "piercing the corporate veil," joint venture, and agency were not applicable under New York law so as to enable sureties to hold owner's representative liable for indemnification of sureties for their liability under performance bonds issued in connection with two massive naval construction projects; owner's representative maintained an arm's length relationship with contractors, never took over control of the projects, shared bank accounts with contractors, siphoned funds belonging to the contractors, or used the contractors as a facade for its own operations, representative never entered into an explicit or implicit joint venture agreement with contractors and there was never any arrangement for the sharing of profits and losses with respect to either the construction projects or the oil and gas ultimately produced and contractors did not become the agents of representative.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Bonds. Sureties' obligations under performance bonds arose after owner fulfilled conditions precedent.

Title: In re Youngstown Osteopathic Hosp. Ass'n
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, individual shareholders, officers and directors may be held personally liable for debts of corporation if the individual is merely corporation's alter ego and is using corporation to perpetrate fraud to detriment of its creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Court refuses to compress intercompany transfers for avoidance purposes.

Title: In re Youngstown Osteopathic Hosp. Ass'n
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio.
Headnote: Corporate form could be disregarded under Ohio law, in order to hold corporate principals and related corporate entities liable on corporate debt, based upon conduct of principals in using their control over corporations to effect series of fraudulent transfers from debtor-corporation to other corporate entities, with no documentation or memorialization, that were designed to place debtor's assets beyond reach of its creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Court refuses to compress intercompany transfers for avoidance purposes.

Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Owners of modular home failed to establish that manufacturer was alter ego of or successor to builder, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil to hold manufacturer liable for debts of builder, although manufacturer and builder had similar names, a common president and a common shareholder, operated from the same address, and used the same phone number; there were no other common officers or directors, business purposes were not similar, and they did not intermingle assets.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer of modular home was not alter ego of builder for purposes of debt liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Goel v. Anything Yellow, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Court properly pierced corporate veil and found that majority shareholder and his estate were personally liable for repaying corporation's debt to investor, where majority shareholder commingled corporate assets with his personal assets, failed to elect officers or directors, failed to file corporate tax returns, and diverted corporate assets to himself.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Majority shareholder would have been unjustly enriched if he did not repay investor's investment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Virtualmagic Asia, Inc. v. Fil-Cartoons, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Even if the unity of interest and ownership element is shown, the alter ego doctrine will not be applied absent evidence that an injustice would result from the recognition of separate corporate identities; difficulty in enforcing a judgment or collecting a debt does not satisfy this standard.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. California had specific jurisdiction over nonresident film animation provider.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Acciai Speciali Terni USA, Inc. v. Momene
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, distributor was not entitled to pierce corporate veil of its agent in order to hold its sole shareholder liable for agent's debts and liabilities, even if there was commingling of assets between shareholder and corporation, absent evidence of undercapitalization, insolvency, siphoning of funds, lack of corporate formalities, or unfairness.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Distributor was not entitled to pierce corporate veil of its agent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Nat Katz & Associates, Ltd. v. Barber
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: To support an alter ego claim against president of construction company, company's creditor had to show that president abused the corporate form and disregarded the separateness of legal entities by commingling on an interchangeable or joint basis or confusing the otherwise separate properties, records or control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President was not liable for corporation's debts where he and corporation maintained separate bank accounts.
