Title: Dimmitt & Owens Financial, Inc. v. Superior Sports Products, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, creditor of corporations engaged in sporting goods business could pierce corporate veil, to reach assets of corporations' sole principal; no capital was available other than loans and sums from letter of credit provided by creditor, corporate formalities were almost entirely unobserved, corporate records were conspicuously absent and corporate funds were commingled with those of principal.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Circumstances warranted piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Shannahan v. Smith & Dailey
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Legal corporation was not alter ego of its individual members, and thus, they were not liable to pay origination fees to attorney who left corporation, where corporation had sufficient funds, after individual members took bonuses, to pay lawful claims by attorney.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES - Law Firms. Attorney was not entitled to origination fees from former employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re World Vision Entertainment, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Corporate veils would be pierced, resulting in individual becoming personally liable for avoidable transfer of brokerage commissions from Chapter 11 debtor to corporations, since individual absolutely controlled and dominated each corporation, each corporation used same employees and offices, individual was primary, if not exclusive, decision maker for each corporation, and individual, as active participant in debtor's enterprise, used corporate entities for fraudulent sale of debtor's promissory notes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Commission payments to brokers under investment program were fraudulent and would be avoided.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Findell v. Koos
Court: Superior Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Lender of money to corporations was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil as to corporate employees, where it did not allege any independent facts demonstrating the requisite control needed to pierce the corporate veil under the instrumentality test.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Lender of money to corporations had no breach of contract claim against corporate employees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Keener Lumber Co., Inc. v. Perry
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil of a corporation allows a plaintiff to impose legal liability for a corporation's obligations, or for torts committed by the corporation, upon some other company or individual that controls and dominates the corporation.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Creditor's filing of proof of claim in bankruptcy action did not deprive trial court of jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Pabich v. Kellar
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: The courts will not hold individual officers, directors, or stockholders liable on the obligations of a corporation except where it appears the individuals are using the corporate entity as a sham to perpetrate a fraud, avoid personal liability, avoid the effect of a statute, or in a few other exceptional situations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Sole shareholder was not liable for injuries to former shareholder arising from noncompetition agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Kalifa v. Clarke
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Corporation was not alter ego of its majority shareholder, and thus shareholder could not be held personally liable for services and materials supplied to corporation, even if shareholder was corporation's secretary, where shareholder did not participate in corporation's day-to-day operations, and there was no evidence that corporation was undercapitalized.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation was not alter ego of its majority shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Miller v. Harco Nat. Ins. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, insurer which had issued motor carrier's liability policy to sole proprietorship was obligated to pay final judgment which had been entered against corporation controlled by principal of sole proprietorship, on basis that it was the alter ego of principal, in action arising from automobile accident.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Liability. Motor carrier's liability insurer had to pay any final judgment against named insured.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Agway, Inc. v. Brooks
Court: Supreme Court of Vermont.
Headnote: Although shareholders are not generally liable for the debts of the corporation, shareholders can be held liable where the corporate form has been used to perpetrate a fraud or to shield the shareholders' assets against legitimate claims of a creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder of closely-held corporation was personally liable for debts of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Lifshutz v. Lifshutz
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Traditionally, courts pierce the corporate structure to hold an individual officer, director, or stockholder liable for the debts of the corporation only where it appears that the individuals are using the corporate entity as a sham to perpetrate a fraud, to avoid personal liability, avoid the effect of a statute, or in a few other exceptional situations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Wife could not pierce corporate veil as husband's disregard of corporate entity benefited community.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Wilkes Associates v. Hollander Industries Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, theory of recovery under piercing the corporate veil and theory of recovery under precedent, which held that a shareholder of a dissolved corporation holds its assets in trust for corporation's creditors to extent shareholder received distribution of corporate assets, were not coextensive, and thus sales representatives for corporate manufacturer could pursue recovery of their unpaid sales commissions against dissolved manufacturer's shareholders on both theories, as recovery of damages under a piercing of the corporate veil theory would not be as limited as recovery under precedent.
Document Preview: TORTS - FRAUD. There was no novation of company's debt to sales agents who had obtained notes for debt from successor.

Title: Mallard Automotive Group, Ltd. v. LeClair Management Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Under Nevada law, fact that individual and his wife executed post-nuptial agreement giving corporation to wife did not shield corporation's assets from husband's creditors if corporation was in fact alter ego of husband.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issues remained as to whether government could hold corporation liable for individual's taxes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Mallard Automotive Group, Ltd. v. LeClair Management Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Under Nevada law, party seeking to hold corporation responsible for individual's debts and obligations under reverse piercing theory does not have to prove that corporation was set up to be sham corporation, only that adherence to corporate form would perpetuate fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issues remained as to whether government could hold corporation liable for individual's taxes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Moss
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Nevada law, corporate entity set up by debtor was her alter ego, for purposes of determining title to entity's property; when corporation was set up, there was an outstanding judgment against debtor for over $700,000.00, and it already had been determined that proceeds of debtor's settlement were not legally exempt from execution by creditors, and so debtor's claim that corporation was incorporated and used to "protect" and "preserve" her assets was tantamount to an admission that she intended to use it as a vehicle to thwart the collection efforts of her individual, versus corporate, judgment creditors, and debtor admitted that she treated assets that had been "transferred" to corporation as her own personal assets.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor's transfers to trust and to corporation were avoidable as fraudulent conveyances.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Tobin
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Where corporate and individual affairs are badly intermingled and it would be unjust to recognize the distinction between individuals and corporations, courts will hold individuals liable for corporate debts and vice versa.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Imputed fraud would not support finding of nondischargeability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Tobin
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Determination as to whether to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholder personally liable for corporate debts is based upon three factors: amount of respect given to separate identity of corporation by its shareholders, the degree of injustice visited on litigants by recognition of corporate entity, and fraudulent intent of incorporators.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Imputed fraud would not support finding of nondischargeability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: PayPhone LLC v. Brooks Fiber Communications of Rhode Island
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Corporation may not pierce its own veil or apply the alter ego doctrine for its own benefit.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation could not pierce own veil for jurisdiction purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Victory Lake Marine, Inc. v. Velduis
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Court will not pierce the corporate veil simply to ensure that a creditor is paid.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Fact issues regarding corporate tenant precluded summary judgment against officers personally.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Goya Foods, Inc. v. Unanue
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation was effectively alter ego of judgment debtor, so as to permit reverse-piercing of corporate veil in order to permit judgment creditor to reach corporation's assets, where judgment debtor created corporation, initially funded it with his own money, managed it, and paid his own and his wife's expenses with its assets; whether or not corporation was originally created to shield assets from creditors, it was not business separate from judgment debtor, and there was no indication that it had any owners other than judgment debtor.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Spousal Debts. Constructive trust could be imposed to permit husband's creditors to reach transferred assets.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Ag Services of America, Inc. v. Nielsen
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Borrower's business associate could not be found liable to lender, under New Mexico law, on theory of piercing the corporate veil, where no liability of corporate entity existed for which associate could be held liable, given that it was borrower's obligation to repay the loan, not the obligation of the company formed by borrower and associate.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Finding against defendant on equitable theories, after jury found for him on legal theories, violated Seventh Amendment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Hamilton v. AAI Ventures, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Limited exceptions exist to the rule of non-liability of shareholders for the debts of a corporation, whereby the court may ignore the corporate fiction and hold the individual members or member liable, where the shareholders acting through the corporation commit fraud or deceit on a third party and where the shareholders have failed to conduct the business on a corporate footing, disregarding the corporate entity to such extent that they and it become indistinguishable.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported trial court's piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: LFC Marketing Group, Inc. v. Loomis
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: In determining whether corporate veil can be pierced to satisfy debt of individual out of corporate assets, potential harm to innocent shareholders or corporate creditors must be considered.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego doctrine permitted reaching corporate assets to satisfy judgment against controlling individual.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: C.F. Trust, Inc. v. First Flight Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, in order to meet requirement for corporate veil piercing that requires plaintiff to show the use of corporate form to evade personal obligations, perpetuate fraud or a crime, or commit injustice, plaintiffs did not have to prove a legal wrong in the form of conspiracy or racketeering violations to establish that various entities were the alter egos of individual; instead, plaintiffs could satisfy the requirement by showing that transactions in question, which included alleged violations of charging or garnishment orders, were undertaken with a wrongful purpose or to evade creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Predicted Virginia law would recognize reverse piercing action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Sonora Diamond Corp. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine does not guard every unsatisfied creditor of a corporation, but instead affords protection where some conduct amounting to bad faith makes it inequitable for the corporate owner to hide behind the corporate form, and difficulty in enforcing a judgment or collecting a debt does not satisfy this standard.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Canadian parent corporation of Nevada subsidiary was not subject to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Hayes v. Collins
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Lender's widow could not pierce corporate veil and hold corporate president personally liable for repayment of loan that lender made to corporation, absent any evidence that the corporate arrangement was a sham, used to defeat justice, to perpetrate fraud, or to evade statutory, contractual or tort responsibility, even though president was sole shareholder and used and controlled the corporation to promote her own ends.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder could not be held liable for corporate debt despite her adulterous affair with lender.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Sullivan v. Wallace
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: In a few limited situations, a litigant can reach a shareholder by "piercing the corporate veil," rendering the individual liable for the corporation's obligations.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Timber. Whether timber company should have known that tree removal was without consent of one co-owner presented fact issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re AVN Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Tennessee, Western Division.
Headnote: Claimant-indenture trustee, who alleged that Chapter 11 debtor-corporation was liable as a general partner of a joint venture for the obligations of a Nevada corporation, failed to establish that the purported joint venture was liable for the obligations of the Nevada corporation under Nevada law; claimant's bare allegation that debtor's president, acting on behalf of debtor, exercised control over Nevada corporation, did not show that joint venture was the alter ego of the Nevada corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Interests of fairness required court to give claimant chance to amend claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Osloond v. Osloond
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Former wife was not entitled to levy against all corporate assets of former husband's corporation, without piercing corporate veil, in order to collect amounts due to her under parties' judgment and decree of divorce, pursuant to statute permitting party who receives favorable judgment to place levies on property of defendant by executing judgment; nothing in statute allowed levy upon corporate assets other than those in which former husband had a legal interest, unless there was sufficient reason to pierce corporate veil. SDCL 15-18-17.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Former wife was not entitled to levy against assets of former husband's corporation without piercing corporate veil.

Title: Wynn v. Arias
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Project owner could not pierce corporate veil and hold president of corporate general contractor personally liable for breach of contract for failing to return her earnest money, even though president controlled corporation with its office and telephone at his home, and he admitted that corporation did not have funds on hand to repay owner's earnest money, absent any evidence that undercapitalization was intended to avoid future corporate debts or that president used earnest money for improper purpose.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Project owner could not hold president of general contractor personally liable for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Solow v. Domestic Stone Erectors, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Individual, judgment debtor, and two other corporations could be considered a single personality in action to enforce judgment, where the individual dominated and controlled the judgment debtor and the corporations and transferred assets of the debtor to the other two corporations.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Individual, judgment debtor, and two corporations were one entity in action to enforce judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Pere v. 1470-1488 U & R Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Complete disregard of corporate formalities and principal's use of corporate funds entitled creditor of principal to pierce corporate veil to extent of directing that corporation pay debt of principal.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditor of corporate principal was entitled to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Pearson v. Component Technology Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: A lender may be found liable for the obligations of a subservient debtor corporation where it misuses that corporation by treating it, and by using it, as a mere business conduit for the purposes of the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Layoffs. Secured creditor was not liable for failing to inform debtor's employees of plant closure.

Title: Ravens Metal Products Inc. v. McGann
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Sole shareholder's alleged domination of arguably undercapitalized corporation that withheld payment to trailer manufacturer was not wrongful or unjust act, as required to pierce the corporate veil, where there was legitimate dispute concerning amount manufacturer owed corporation for repair and modification of trailers and amount sought by corporation was nearly identical to amount sought by manufacturer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer did not show wrongful act by corporate purchaser.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Strangie
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence did not support piercing corporate veil to find Chapter 7 debtor personally liable for judgment debt obtained against corporation formed by debtor's husband and of which debtor and husband were sole officers and directors, where debtor performed only minor ministerial tasks, such as filling out date, payee name, and amount spaces on some corporate checks at husband's specific direction, she testified without evidentiary contradiction that she signed no corporate checks and that she was never involved in or privy to corporate business, and there was no evidence that debtor directly and knowingly participated in husband's alleged diversion of corporate funds.

Title: Land Ocean Logistics, Inc. v. Aqua Gulf Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, action of corporation in providing funds to assist second corporation in satisfying debt obligations on single occasion is not sufficient to hold corporation accountable for alleged debt owed by second corporation.

Title: Hiller Cranberry Products, Inc. v. Koplovsky Foods, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Although buyer that purchased cranberries and company to which buyer subsequently delivered cranberries were controlled by the same dominant shareholder and shared office space and delivery trucks, this did not warrant piercing the corporate veil, under Massachusetts law, so as to hold transferee company liable for buyer's debt to cranberry supplier; supplier was aware that the two companies and the shareholder were three separate entities, the two companies maintained separate corporate records, filed separate tax returns, and observed corporate formalities, and buyer was not thinly capitalized or insolvent at time of supply agreement.
Document Preview: Cranberry supplier, who had not received payment, brought action against buyer, buyer's controlling shareholder, and company to which buyer had delivered the cranberries, asserting claims under the Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act (PACA), for misrepresentation, and for violations of the Massachusetts Fraudulent Conveyance Act and the Massachusetts Unfair Trade Practices Act.  The District Court, Harrington, J., held that: (1) supplier was not entitled to PACA trust protection; (2) alter-ego theory did not apply, so as to impose liability for debt on either shareholder or transferee company; (3) shareholder was not liable for any misrepresentation; and (4) shareholder's transfers of property were not fraudulent conveyances. So ordered.

Title: NorDar Holdings, Inc. v. Western Securities (USA) Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, debtor corporation's financial statement, which allegedly glossed over debtor's limited liquid assets, was insufficient to establish that corporation and its shareholder perpetrated actual fraud against creditor owed deficiency on promissory note, as required to impose liability on shareholder for such deficiency under single business enterprise or alter ego theory, absent definitive evidence that statement was actually presented to creditor, that statement was false in any material way, or that creditor relied on statement. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.

Ordered accordingly.

Title: MCI Telecommunications Corp. v. O'Brien Marketing, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil of customer was appropriate in proceedings supplementary for enforcement of judgment against customer, in long-distance telephone company's action to recover unpaid charges for services provided to customer and, thus, corporation, as alter ego of customer, was liable for unpaid charges and attorney fees and costs; corporation and its sole shareholder exercised complete domination of finances and policy and business practices of customer, through exercise of such control, customer was able to evade its legal duty to pay charges, there was total disregard of corporate formalities by customer, customer was undercapitalized, and piercing the corporate veil furthered Communications Act purpose of preventing unreasonableness of rates and discrimination in interstate telecommunications charges. Communications Act of 1934, § 1 et seq., as amended, 47 U.S.C.A. § 151 et seq.; West's F.S.A. § 56.29; Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 69(a), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: Long-distance telephone company brought action against corporate customer, which was telemarketer, to recover unpaid charges for interstate telecommunication services provided to customer.  After entry of judgment for company and award of attorney fees to company, company moved to institute proceedings supplementary, and order was issued requiring corporation to show cause why it should not be impleaded as party, as alter ego of customer.  Upon corporation's failure to respond to show cause order, corporation was impleaded as party.  The District Court, Highsmith, J., held that: (1) federal law, rather than state law, applied to issue of piercing the corporate veil, and (2) piercing of the corporate veil of customer was appropriate and, thus, corporation was liable, as alter ego of customer, for final judgment for unpaid charges and for attorney fees and costs. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Alberto v. Diversified Group, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, parent corporation of developer could not be held liable as alter ego for judgments obtained by homeowners against developer in suits alleging that foundations of their homes failed as a result of soil subsidence, absent showing that recognition of corporations as separate entities would result in unfairness or injustice; although developer was undercapitalized from time it was purchased until it went bankrupt, parent and other investors attempted to resuscitate developer by funnelling millions of dollars of capital into the struggling company, and there was nothing improper, much less unfair or unjust, in parent's inclusion of subsidiary's losses in consolidated tax returns to offset income from other, profitable corporations owned by it.

Title: Pel-Star Energy, Inc. v. U.S. Dept. of Energy
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Louisiana, Shreveport Division. .
Headnote: In determining propriety of Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's (FERC) decision to pierce the corporate veil so as to find partial owner of crude oil reseller personally liable for crude oil overcharges by reseller under crude oil antilayering regulations, the following two-pronged test was applicable: first, was there such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and controlling individual no longer existed and, second, would adherence to corporate fiction or failure to disregard corporate form result in fraud or injustice, i.e., if acts were treated as those of corporation alone, would inequitable result follow. 10 C.F.R. § 212.186 (1981).
Document Preview: Corporate crude oil reseller and partial owner of reseller brought action seeking judicial review of Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) order finding owner personally liable, through piercing the corporate veil, for $4,663,852.89 in crude oil overcharges by reseller plus interest under crude oil antilayering regulations.  The District Court, Stagg, J., held that: (1) it would review order de novo, rather than under substantial evidence test; (2) Commission had jurisdiction to impose personal liability on owner for crude oil overcharges, despite fact that Commission was not Article III court; (3) federal law, rather than state law, governed its determination of propriety of Commission's decision to pierce the corporate veil; and (4) piercing of the corporate veil was improper. Reversed.

Title: Bingham v. Goldberg. Marchesano. Kohlman. Inc.
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: There was no basis to pierce corporate veil and hold corporate president liable for corporation's debt under contract for advertising and marketing services; numerous documents indicated corporation's observance of corporate formalities, including articles and certificate of incorporation, resolution for bank accounts, minutes of meetings of board of directors and shareholders, corporate by-laws, and stock certificates, final decision making authority rested with board, there was no evidence that president's personal funds were commingled with corporate assets or that corporation made preferential payment to her, and there was no evidence that corporation was undercapitalized or formed in attempt to defraud creditors.

Headnote: For purposes of determining whether corporate fiction should be disregarded and shareholder be held liable, requirement that unfairness result from maintaining of corporate fiction was satisfied by evidence that shareholder continued to make credit purchases even though corporation was insolvent, that he transferred automobile which was corporation's primary asset to himself and that undercapitalization worked injustice on creditors.

Title: Ross v. Playle
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: Corporation's failure to follow corporate formalities when executing purchase orders and its payment of rent to its owner did not warrant piercing corporate veil and holding owner personally liable in action brought by supplier to recover on purchase orders; supplier knew of corporation's existence, and there was no evidence that owner intended to defraud creditors, or that rental payments were excessive.

Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Ordinarily, courts are called upon to apply alter ego doctrine in cases where party seeks to hold individual liable for business entity's debts.

Title: In re Newtowne, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, court should consider various factors in deciding whether to ignore formal corporate structures in order to hold third parties liable for corporate debt, including: whether domination and control over corporation by those to be held liable is so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will or existence of its own; whether domination and control was used to commit fraud or wrong or other dishonest or unjust act; and whether injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Corporate veil was properly pierced to hold sole proprietor of defunct business liable for its debts and, thus, second corporations's bank account was properly garnished, even though it was formed after debts were incurred and even though proprietor was not its record owner; record revealed that proprietor exercised dominion and control over second corporation, of which he was secretary and director, and second corporation's record owner was proprietor's girlfriend, who claimed no experience in construction industry, in which second corporation was directly involved.

Title: O'Hazza v. Executive Credit Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: Ignoring separate existence of corporation and imposing personal liability on shareholders for debts of corporation is extraordinary act to be taken only when necessary to promote justice.
Document Preview: Veil of corporation which installed sound equipment was pierced and personal liability for debts of corporation imposed upon shareholders by the Circuit Court, Fairfax County, Johanna L. Fitzpatrick, J. Shareholders appealed.  The Supreme Court, Lacy, J., held that: (1) fact that $10,000 was contributed in initial capital did not establish that corporation was undercapitalized; (2) subsequent loans by shareholders to corporation were not grounds for piercing corporate veil; (3) the fact that shareholders organized business to employ their son and received personal tax advantages was not basis for piercing corporate veil; and (4) shareholders did not breach fiduciary duties. Reversed and final judgment.

Title: Multimedia Pub. of South Carolina, Inc. v. Mullins
Court: Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Headnote: Knowledge of newspaper advertising account gained by individual in his capacity as director of grocery store corporation was sufficient to put him on inquiry which, if pursued with reasonable diligence, would have led to knowledge that account was unpaid and therefore, individual was "aware" of newspaper's claim against corporation for purposes of fundamental unfairness prong of test to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Newspaper brought breach of contract action to recover balance due on grocery store corporation's advertising account.  The Circuit Court, Horry County, Edward B. Cottingham, J., pierced corporation's corporate veil, and sole director of corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals affirmed, and certiorari was granted.  The Supreme Court, Harwell, C.J., held that: (1) knowledge of advertising account gained by individual in his capacity as director of corporation was sufficient to put him on inquiry, such that he was aware of newspaper's claim against corporation for purposes of fundamental unfairness prong of test for piercing corporate veil, and (2) any knowledge imputed to individual in his capacity as director could be charged to him as individual. Affirmed.

Title: AYR Composition, Inc. v. Rosenberg
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Imposing personal liability on principals who fraudulently transfer corporate property in face of known legal action satisfies purpose of doctrine of piercing corporate veil, which is to prevent independent corporation from being used to defeat ends of justice, to perpetrate fraud, to accomplish a crime, or otherwise to evade the law.
Document Preview: FRAUDULENT TRANSFER - Liability. Personal liability of former directors, officers, and principals of corporation, which was based on fraudulent transfer of corporate assets, was limited to fair market value of assets at time of transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: AYR Composition, Inc. v. Rosenberg
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Whether judgment creditor of corporation was granted remedy against directors, officers, and principals of corporation in their personal capacity on basis of fraudulent conveyance or on basis of piercing corporate veil, defendants' personal liability was limited to fair market value of transferred assets as of date of transfer, even if this was less than corporate debt owed creditor; principals would be responsible only for effects of their actions.
Document Preview: FRAUDULENT TRANSFER - Liability. Personal liability of former directors, officers, and principals of corporation, which was based on fraudulent transfer of corporate assets, was limited to fair market value of assets at time of transfer.

Title: U.S. v. Clinical Leasing Service, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, shareholders are generally not held individually responsible for debts of corporation; however, where corporation is merely the alter ego of the shareholder, court may ignore the corporate form and hold individual shareholder or shareholders liable.
Document Preview: Government brought suit against corporate officers seeking to hold them personally liable for fines imposed against their corporation, for violations of the Federal Controlled Substances Act (FCSA).  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, Adrian G. Duplantier, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of government, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Emilio M. Garza, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) jury was properly instructed on alter ego theory under Louisiana law; (2) it was not inequitable for government to pierce corporate veil after defendants had made offer of settlement; (3) district court did not err in terminating direct examination of defendant during trial; and (4) it was not plain error for district court to warn jury on several occasions to disregard fact that defendants operated an abortion clinic. Affirmed.

Title: Morris v. New York State Dept. of Taxation and Finance
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Controlling shareholder may be held responsible for corporation's obligations when corporation is being operated by that shareholder in such a manner as to render the corporate form a fiction.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ENTITIES - Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced in order to hold nonshareholding president personally liable for corporate tax.

Title: Pulte Home Corp., Inc. v. Ply Gem Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, parent corporation did not exercise sufficient control over subsidiary to require subsidiary's corporate entity to be disregarded in strict liability action brought against it; subsidiary's management and staff remained intact after it was acquired by parent, parent and subsidiary had no common operating officers or common employees, separation of funds was strictly maintained, and subsidiary was fully capitalized.
Document Preview: Builder brought action against manufacturers and sellers of allegedly defective plywood used in builder's homes.  On motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Kovachevich, J., held that: (1) fact issues precluded summary judgment on builder's claim for punitive damages; (2) builder had standing to sue defendants for damages; (3) Florida law applied to builder's contract claim; (4) fact issues precluded summary judgment on builder's fraud claim; (5) builder was required to identify source of plywood to recover on strict products liability claim; (6) economic loss doctrine did not preclude builder from recovering on its tort claims; and (7) parent corporation could not be held vicariously liable for actions of subsidiary. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Title: Vero Group v. ISS-International Service System
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, acquisition referral service was not required to pierce corporate veil, and thus was not required to show actual fraud, in order to hold parent corporation liable for compensation to which service became entitled under acquisition referral agreement upon acquisition by subsidiary of referred corporation, which was de facto acquisition by parent, given parent's participation in negotiations and provision of cash for acquisition; parent corporation could not duck itsresponsibility to referral service simply by arranging unilaterally for title to acquired corporation's stock to be taken in name of one of its many subsidiaries.
Document Preview: Acquisition referral service brought action against alien corporation and its domestic subsidiary for breach of contract, alleging that it was entitled to compensation under acquisition referral agreement for acquisition of referred corporation by alien corporation's alien subsidiary.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, James DeAnda, Chief Judge, awarded damages to service in accordance with findings of jury.  Alien corporation and its domestic subsidiary appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Wiener, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) evidence supported finding that service furnished written referral to alien corporation concerning acquired corporation; (2) application of alter ego analysis was not necessary to hold alien corporation liable under agreement for acquisition; and (3) fact that service was not licensed dealer under Texas securities law did not preclude its recovery of compensation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Carte Blanche (Singapore) PTE., Ltd. v. Diners Club Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil could not be pierced to make parent corporation liable for judgment against subsidiary for subsidiary's breach of franchise agreement which occurred while subsidiary was wound down since subsidiary was established for proper corporate purpose, assets of subsidiary were not switched around or put to improper use by parent, assets were properly taken from subsidiary by parent to repay lawful outstanding corporate debt, and subsidiary functioned as separate entity with its own personnel and separate office space.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor brought suit to compel parent corporation to satisfy judgment obtained against subsidiary for breach of franchise agreement. Following bench trial, the District Court, Whitman Knapp, Senior District Judge, held that piercing corporate veil was not proper under New York law where subsidiary was properly established and later wound down. Judgment for defendants.

Title: Mid-Century Ins. Co. v. Gardner
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Mere fact that debt will remain unsatisfied unless corporate veil is pierced is not sufficient reason to disregard existence of corporate entity; purpose of alter ego doctrine is not to protect every unsatisfied creditor, but rather to afford him protection where some conduct amounting to bad faith makes it inequitable for equitable owner of corporation to hide behind its corporate veil.
Document Preview: Automobile insurer sued for declaratory judgment regarding coverage provided by policy.  The Superior Court, Sacramento County, Richard C. Creeggan, J., entered judgment in favor of insurer, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeal, Sparks, J., held that: (1) corporation's principal shareholder and chief executive officer was not owner of corporate vehicles, within meaning of exclusion from uninsured motorist coverage for owned vehicles not listed in policy; (2) corporate veil could not be pierced to permit insurer to treat corporate vehicles as vehicles of principal; and (3) other insurance exclusion could not be interpreted to preclude coverage. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Shailam
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: While doctrine of piercing corporate veil is most often used to hold individual principals liable for corporate debt, there is no impediment to utilizing alter ego theory in order to reach corporate assets for satisfaction of individual debts, under New York law.
Document Preview: Trustee objected to debtors' schedules claiming as exempt the debtors' interest in pension and Keogh plans valued at $421,000.  The Bankruptcy Court, Justin J. Mahoney, Chief Judge, held that: (1) ERISA does not preempt trustee in bankruptcy from raising argument that funds deposited into qualified ERISA plan are avoidable as fraudulent conveyances under New York law; (2) trustee failed to establish that debtor's transfer of large amount of funds to his professional corporation's defined benefit pension plan was with intent to perpetrate fraud upon creditors, and thus failed to satisfy requirements for piercing corporate veil under New York law; and (3) permitting trustee to avoid as fraudulent conveyances under New York law transfers by one debtor into defined benefit plan would violate antialienation provision of ERISA. Objections overruled.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Chase Manhattan Bank, N.A. v. J & L General Contractors, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veils of general contracting corporation and trucking corporation was not appropriate where family, which had previously owned stock in general contracting corporation, regained stock at time that general contracting corporation was "broke" and then formed trucking corporation to purchase general contracting corporation's equipment and carry on same business previously conducted by general contracting corporation; family had no knowledge of, and was not responsible for, fact that general contracting corporation's equipment was pledged to creditor and family had not intended to avoid general contracting corporation's creditors.
Document Preview: Lender brought action against general contracting company and trucking company and family which had owned both companies alleging default on promissory note and conversion, and requesting piercing of corporate veils.  The 253rd District Court, Liberty County, rendered judgment and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Walker, C.J., held that: (1) lender's financing statement was insufficient to perfect security interest as to any of general contracting company's equipment and fixtures; (2) purchase of general contracting company's equipment and fixtures by trucking company cut off lender's claimed security interests; and (3) it was not appropriate to pierce corporate veil to hold trucking company liable for general contracting company's obligations to lender or to hold family liable for both corporations' obligations to lender. Reversed and rendered in part and affirmed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Fuda v. Kroen
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: No basis existed for piercing of corporate veil, so as to impose liability on officers of bankrupt corporation to repay amounts advanced by employee; there was no evidence that employee had been induced to make loans to corporation based on fraudulent representations by officers and money was lost simply because corporation's business ventures were not successful.
Document Preview: Former employee of corporation which had become bankrupt sued corporation officers, seeking to recover amount loaned to corporation.  The State Court, DeKalb County, McLaughlin, J., entered judgment for former employee and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Sognier, C.J., held that evidence did not support piercing of corporate veil, so as to allow recovery against officers. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Fuda v. Kroen
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Fact that money loaned to corporation, which subsequently became bankrupt, had been used to pay travel, dry cleaning, telephone and housing expenses of corporate officers, did not support piercing of corporate veil so as to impute corporation's debt to officers; complainant adduced no evidence that these were not legitimate business expenses or authorized by corporation as part of officers' compensation packages.
Document Preview: Former employee of corporation which had become bankrupt sued corporation officers, seeking to recover amount loaned to corporation.  The State Court, DeKalb County, McLaughlin, J., entered judgment for former employee and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Sognier, C.J., held that evidence did not support piercing of corporate veil, so as to allow recovery against officers. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Fuda v. Kroen
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence that officers of corporation had applied proceeds of loan made to corporation by employee to expenses of other corporations controlled by them did not provide basis for piercing corporate veil so as to make officers liable to employee for amount of loans; while evidence might be usable for disregarding corporate entity as between various corporations, it did not establish unity of interest between corporation and officers.
Document Preview: Former employee of corporation which had become bankrupt sued corporation officers, seeking to recover amount loaned to corporation.  The State Court, DeKalb County, McLaughlin, J., entered judgment for former employee and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Sognier, C.J., held that evidence did not support piercing of corporate veil, so as to allow recovery against officers. Reversed.

Title: Dannasch v. Bifulco
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Judgment creditor stated actionable claim for piercing corporate veil of judgment debtor remodeling service corporation; by the time arbitration award against corporation was confirmed, corporation had become defunct, discovery showed corporation had no corporate officer, no books of account, inventory valued at only $179, and was out of business, and creditor alleged that debtor's sole shareholder intentionally undercapitalized company, appropriated its assets for his personal use, drained income from the corporation, and conducted business in disregard of corporate formalities.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor of defunct remodeling service corporation filed action against corporation's sole shareholder officer and director, seeking to pierce the corporate veil.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Schoenfeld, J., granted summary judgment dismissing the complaint, and judgment creditor appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) treating motion to dismiss as motion for summary judgment was improper, and (2) allegations of complaint adequately stated cause of action for piercing corporate veil. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Custom Lighting and Decorating, Ltd. v. Hampshire Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Owners of closely held corporations either used the corporations as mere instrumentalities for their personal acquisition of cabinets and residence in which they were installed, or there had become such a unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of the corporations and the owners as to the cabinet transactions ceased to exist, and, thus, corporate veil would be pierced and the owners held liable to the seller of the cabinets; cabinets purchased by one of the corporations were installed in a residence that had been given to the owners by the other corporation, and the owners did not devote any of their personally held funds to payment for the cabinets.
Document Preview: Company which sold cabinets to a closely held corporation brought action on open account for failure of the closely held corporation to pay for the cabinets.  Owners of the closely held corporation were added as party defendants, as well as another corporation owned by the owners.  The Hall County State Court, Gosselin, J., entered summary judgment in favor of company, holding the owners personally liable for the debt, but finding that material issues of fact remained as to amount owed on the account.  Defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Beasley, J., held that corporate veil would be pierced and owners held personally liable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Chateaugay Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts are generally more reluctant to pierce corporate veil for voluntary or contract creditor, than for involuntary or tort creditor.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtor objected to proofs of claim.  The Bankruptcy Court, Burton R. Lifland, Chief Judge, held that: (1) debtor was not liable for subsidiary's breach of contract, and (2) claims against third party were subject to indemnification by debtor. Motion granted in part and denied in part. See also 126 B.R. 165.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: H.H. Robertson Co., Cupples Products Div. v. V.S. DiCarlo General Contractors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, judgment creditor moving for creditor's bill in equity to enforce judgment against judgment debtor was entitled to pierce judgment debtor's corporate veil and hold related corporations liable on judgment, upon showing that corporations represented almost indistinguishable corporate entities and that judgment debtor used alleged separateness of corporations as subterfuge to defraud judgment creditor from collecting on its judgment.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor filed motion for creditor's bill in equity to enforce judgment against corporations related to judgment debtor.  The District Court, Gunn, J., held that judgment creditor was entitled to pierce corporate veil and hold related corporations liable on judgment on basis that judgment was subterfuge and alter ego of related corporations. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Travel Committee, Inc. v. Pan American World Airways, Inc.
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Trial court could not pierce corporate veil to enforce paramount equity, where there was no evidence that corporations involved failed to observe corporate formalities or pay dividends, officers and directors were involved in corporate activities, and corporate records were not absent.
Document Preview: Airline brought action against travel agency and its corporate and individual owners seeking to recover on note executed by agency and to recover funds representing ticket sale proceeds.  The Circuit Court, Baltimore County, Joseph F. Murphy, Jr., J., entered judgment in favor of airline, and agency appealed.  The Court of Special Appeals, Alpert, J., held that: (1) jury's verdict was not hopelessly irreconcilable; (2) piercing travel agency's corporate veil was improper; (3) agency did not have fiduciary obligation to hold and preserve ticket sale proceeds for airline's benefit; (4) evidence created jury issue as to whether airline's breach of marketing cooperation agreement resulted in damages; (5) issue of whether airline's tariffs violated Federal Aviation Act could not be addressed by state court; (6) airline's statements to agency were not actionable misrepresentations; (7) airline did not breach agreement to sell...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Cumberland Wood Products, Inc. v. Bennett
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Corporate veil would be pierced, and corporation's president and majority shareholder would be held personally liable on indebtedness to corporate supplier, based on evidence that corporation was grossly undercapitalized, failed to observe corporate formalities such as holding board of directors' meetings, failed to declare dividends on its outstanding stock, and paid salary to its president, not pursuant to any properly endorsed resolution, but based entirely on what president needed to meet his household expenses; failure to pierce would result in unfairness, as president continued to receive salary knowing that this would not leave funds sufficient to pay supplier's claim.
Document Preview: Supplier brought breach of contract action against corporate debtor and also sought to pierce corporate veil to hold debtor's majority shareholder personally liable.  The Circuit Court, Richland County, Joseph M. Strickland, Master-In-Equity, entered judgment in favor of supplier and pierced corporate veil, and majority shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Littlejohn, Acting J., held that corporate veil could be pierced based, inter alia, on evidence that corporation was grossly undercapitalized. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co. v. Whiteford Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, prejudgment attachment of assets belonging to individual who was alleged alter ego of insured corporations was not warranted in insurer's action to recover unpaid insurance policy deductible amounts, though certain of defendants' actions during pendency of action hinted at fraudulent intent, where there were countervailing considerations including voluntary tender of substantial portion of original claim and, in winding up the affairs of an insured corporation, provision of orderly and equitable procedure in the form of independent escrow arrangement. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 64, 28 U.S.C.A.; Ohio R.C. § 2715.01.
Document Preview: In action by insurer to recover unpaid insurance policy deductible amounts, insurer sought prejudgment attachment of assets belonging to individual who was alleged alter ego of insured corporations.  The District Court, George C. Smith, J., held that prejudgment attachment was not warranted. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Gurnik v. Lee
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Second District.
Headnote: Former travel agency president was not entitled to pierce corporate veil to obtain judgment for unpaid bonus from shareholders, even though shareholders loaned money to travel agency, given that travel agency had board of directors and had regular meetings during which minutes were kept, agency maintained its own separate bank accounts and filed separate tax returns, and loan made to travel agency by shareholders were reflected in accounting records of all affected entities.
Document Preview: Former travel agency president filed suit against travel agency and its shareholders to collect unpaid bonus.  The Superior Court,Marion County, Gerald S. Zore, J., entered partial summary judgment in favor of defendants and, after bench trial, entered judgment in favor of president against travel agency.  President appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Buchanan, J., held that: (1) bonus was wage in meaning of statute allowing treble damages and attorney fees award, and (2) merely loaning funds to travel agency by shareholders was not sufficient to justify piercing corporate veil. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Sullivan, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: United Elec. Contractors, Inc. v. Progress Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Corporate veil would be pierced, and president and director of corporations which owned property and which acted as general contractor would be held personally liable for money owing to electrical subcontractor and for fraudulent conveyance designed to defeat contractor's rights, where neither corporation had separate mind, will or existence of its own but conducted joint meetings at which no minutes were taken and only corporate president was present.
Document Preview: Electrical subcontractor brought suit to recover money owing for electrical work performed on construction project, as well as to set aside alleged fraudulent conveyance to wife of president of corporation that owned land.  The Superior Court, Judicial District of Waterbury, Pellegrino, J., entered judgment in favor of subcontractor on suit against corporations which owned property and which acted as general contractor on project, but refused to pierce corporate veil and to impose liability on either president or his wife.  Subcontractor appealed.  The Appellate Court, Norcott, J., held that: (1) president's wife was bound, no less than other defendants, by admission in answer, and (2) corporate veil should have been pierced to hold president personally liable on debt. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Canario v. Lidelco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Even if principle shareholder purchased airplane using corporate funds and took personal income tax deductions for its depreciation while corporation paid for its upkeep, those actions were not sufficient to allow piercing of corporate veil, absent suggestion of lack of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, or perpetration of fraud.
Document Preview: Trustees of labor management pension fund brought action against corporate employer seeking recovery of withdrawal liability.  The District Court, Amon, J., held that principal shareholders in corporation were not employers of pension plan participants and could not be held liable for withdrawal liability of corporation. Motion for summary judgment denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Canario v. Lidelco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Evidence showed that principal shareholders subjected themselves to potential liability by guaranteeing corporation's loans, and were not attempting to use corporation to avoid personal liability, and, thus, shareholders were not liable for withdrawal liability under alter ego fraudulent conveyance theory.
Document Preview: Trustees of labor management pension fund brought action against corporate employer seeking recovery of withdrawal liability.  The District Court, Amon, J., held that principal shareholders in corporation were not employers of pension plan participants and could not be held liable for withdrawal liability of corporation. Motion for summary judgment denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Bergman v. Nicholson Management and Consultants, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation's shareholders are not liable for its debts and only in exceptional circumstances is shareholder's limited liability disregarded.
Document Preview: Vendors of apartments and furnishings brought action against corporate buyer and its sole shareholder which had guaranteed notes given in connection with sale to enforce mortgage and for money judgment for corporate waste and for past-due rent.  Claims were consolidated and the Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Louis A. DiRosa, J., denied claim for waste of property against sole shareholder and denied claim against sole shareholder on continuing guaranty.  Vendors appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Williams, J., held that: (1) when sole shareholder as guarantor paid total sum due after primary obligor's notice to vendors that it was unable to timely pay balance due under note but before vendors made forced collection on it, payment satisfied shareholder's obligation to vendors, and (2) sole owner could not be held liable for corporate waste of property. Affirmed. Schott, C.J., and Armstrong, J., concurred in the result.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: Tri-State Refining and Inv. Co., Inc. v. Opdahl
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: In actions involving invalid trusts, fraudulent conveyances and piercing corporate veil, judgment creditor may look beyond sham transaction or entity to find judgment debtor's assets.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor brought action to enforce South Dakota judgment by levying upon Iowa farm which had allegedly been fraudulently conveyed to trust by judgment debtor.  The District Court for Sioux County, Edwin L. Mitchell, J., granted summary judgment for creditor and debtor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Habhab, J., held that: (1) creditor was not required to obtain certificate of authority in order to bring present suit; (2) creditor had standing to raise invalidity of trust agreement; and (3) debtor's claims involving validity of trust agreement and transfer of property to trust were barred by doctrine of res judicata. Affirmed. Sackett, J., specially concurred without opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Golden Distributors, Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, debtor could not pierce creditor's corporate veil and hold supervisor of corporation's operations personally liable for corporation's debts, even though there was complete disregard of corporate formalities in operation of corporation, where supervisor was only employee of corporation authorized to sign checks and not officer or shareholder. N.Y.McKinney's Business Corporation Law §§ 701, 715.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtor sued to collect monies owed by creditor-corporation for goods sold and delivered to creditor seeking to hold corporate employee personally liable for entire debt as well as for 12 corporate checks returned for insufficient funds.  The Bankruptcy Court, Howard Schwartzberg, J., held that: (1) debtor could not pierce corporate veil and hold employee, who was neither director nor officer of corporation, personally liable for corporation's debts; (2) under New York law corporate employee was not personally liable for dishonored checks he drew on corporation's account due to fact that he signed them without indicating he was acting on behalf of corporation, in light of course of dealing between parties; and (3) fact that employee postdated some of corporation's checks in question had no bearing on disposition of case. Judgment for employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: McLean v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under doctrine of "piercing the corporate veil" shareholder may be liable for debts of corporation because of failure of shareholder to substantially comply with legal requirements of corporate entity; doctrine may be imposed even in absence of fraud where there has been disregard of corporate entity to such extent that corporation is indistinguishable from shareholders. LSA-R.S. 12:93-12:95.
Document Preview: After homeowner obtained judgment against corporation which performed various renovations to his home, homeowner sued principal shareholder of corporation.  The Nineteenth Judicial District Court, Parish of East Baton Rouge, Leo P. Higginbotham, Jr., J., sustained shareholder's exception of res judicata and deferred ruling on exception of no cause of action.  Homeowner appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Watkins, J., held that: (1) action was not barred by res judicata, and (2) petition stated claim for piercing corporate veil. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Vermont Toy Works, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Vermont.

Title: LeRoux's Billyle Supper Club v. Ma
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Lucas County.
Headnote: Facts that corporation failed as business venture, sole shareholder borrowed large sums of money and made substantial loans to corporation to keep it afloat, shareholder was president and supervised management of corporation, and initial capitalization of corporation was only $200 did not permit finding that corporation was alter ego of sole shareholder so as to pierce corporate veil and impose liability upon shareholder for corporate debt.

The Court of Appeals held that evidence did not support piercing corporate veil so as to make sole shareholder liable for corporate debt. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Sea-Land Services, Inc. v. Pepper Source
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: For purposes of determining whether corporation's veil could be pierced by creditor and money owed recovered from corporation's owner and other corporations he owned, there was such a unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of debtor corporation no longer existed; owner was the sole shareholder of all but one of those corporations, only one of which had held even one corporate meeting, ran all corporations out of the same office with the same phone line and expense accounts, and borrowed substantial sums from those corporations and used their bank accounts to pay personal expenses.

Reversed and remanded with instructions.

Title: Bado Equipment Co., Inc. v. Bethlehem Steel Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Where constructor of offshore drilling rig into which cranes were incorporated had prior perfected security interest in cranes, it had superior rights to cranes and owed no legal or equitable duty to seller of cranes, which allegedly had not been paid for them; thus, constructor's organization of corporation and subsequent transfer of cranes to corporation were not breaches of any legal or equitable duty owed to seller, and could not be basis for constructive fraud claim.

The Court of Appeals, Cannon, J., held that: (1) claims against constructor for conversion and conspiracy to commit conversion were barred by statute of limitations; (2) constructor had perfected security interest in cranes superior to that of seller; and (3) second corporation's statements that seller could not retake possession of cranes were not actionable as tortious interference with seller's contractual relationship with purchaser. Affirmed.
