Title: Evans v. Multicon Const. Corp.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Hampden.
Headnote: Contract between subcontractor and corporation and manner in which corporation functioned did not justify piercing corporate veil and looking beyond corporation to its parent or to controlling officers, directors, or shareholders to satisfy judgment for subcontractor, notwithstanding common ownership, pervasive control, nonpayment of dividends, and use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholder; subcontractor took no protective steps, such as obtaining lien for labor or material furnished or attachment against assets not susceptible to execution. Affirmed.

Title: Coastal Shutters and Insulation, Inc. v. Derr
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Corporate fiction could be disregarded and corporation's president held liable for corporation debt on basis of "alter ego" theory, in light of evidence that no corporate formalities were followed, that funds and assets of corporation were substantially commingled with those of other entities owned or controlled by its president, and that corporation was inadequately capitalized and was operated as mere tool of its president and other entities he owned or controlled.

Affirmed. Murphy, J., concurred in part and dissented in part and filed opinion.

Title: K.C. Roofing Center v. On Top Roofing, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Evidence that shareholder would cease doing business as one corporation when he became unable to pay corporation's creditors and would then form another corporation in order to get "fresh start," continuing to use same business premises and equipment, supported decision to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholder personally liable for unsecured debt that shareholder incurred while corporation was insolvent and was paying only its secured creditors.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against corporation and shareholder, seeking to recover on corporate debt and to hold the shareholder personally liable.  The Circuit Court, Jackson County, John I. Moran, J., entered judgment in favor of creditor and pierced the corporate veil.  Shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Kennedy, J., held that: (1) the evidence supported the findings that the shareholder dominated the corporation's activities, and that he organized series of corporations when he became unable to pay one corporation's creditors and, therefore, the evidence supported piercing the corporate veil, and (2) evidence of the shareholder's activities with respect to the multiple corporations was relevant and admissible. Judgment affirmed.

Title: Kvassay v. Murray
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: Seller was entitled to pierce corporate veil of buyer so that principals of buyer could be held personally responsible for corporate debts when sales contract was breached; corporation was undercapitalized, corporation failed to observe corporate formalities, there was no payment of dividends, principals siphoned off corporate funds, there were no corporate records, and corporate entity was used in promoting injustice.
Document Preview: Seller of baklava brought action against buyer alleging breach of contract.  The Sedgwick District Court, Nicholas W. Walker, District Judge, assigned, held that: (1) lost profits were recoverable for goods that had not been produced; (2) seller did not have to prove record of profitability to claim lost profits; and (3) corporate veil of buyer could be pierced to hold principals liable for corporate debt. Reversed and remanded in part, and affirmed in part.

Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: Creditor was not entitled to pierce corporate shield of home building corporation, even though only small portion of investments or contributions was represented by shares as opposed to loans to corporation, where there was nothing to demonstrate that corporation was sham, that director made false or misleading misrepresentations, or that director seized assets in order to foreclose on loans with purpose of stripping corporation of assets necessary to pay existing debts, or that corporate form was otherwise disregarded.

Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced so that sale of stock of corporation by sole shareholder would result in entity being altered triggering successor corporation analysis, where to do so would allow corporation to escape its obligations and would not protect interest of third parties.

Headnote: New corporation that leased premises and commenced operations after different corporation failed was not alter ego of failed corporation, and thus, new corporation was not liable for attorney fees under settlement agreement entered into by failed corporation; although sole owner of new corporation was substantial creditor of and consultant to failed corporation, he did not own shares in or manage or control failed corporation.

Dismissed.

Title: Matter of Velis

Title: Alpine Packing Co. v. H.H. Keim Co., Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Idaho.
Headnote: There was not such "unity of interest and ownership" between debtor corporation that owed business money and creditor corporation that was owed money by business that would allow reasonable inference of control and disregard of debtor corporation's status as corporation separate from creditor corporation, and would enable business to set off amount it was owed by debtor corporation against its debt to creditor corporation, despite familial relationship of corporate shareholders, creditor corporation's financing of debtor corporation, and purported knowledge of business that both corporations were owned by same family, where creditor corporation never owned any stock in debtor corporation, corporations did not have common shareholders or officers, and there was no evidence that creditor corporation exercised any control over debtor corporation.
Document Preview: Creditor corporation brought action against business to collect open account.  Business asserted it was entitled to set off against amounts owed to creditor corporation amounts that business was owed by debtor corporation, owned by members of same family as majority shareholders of creditor corporation.  The District Court, Third Judicial District, Canyon County, James R. Doolittle, J., entered summary judgment for creditor corporation, and business appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Walters, C.J., held that there was not such unity of interest and ownership between creditor corporation and debtor corporation that would allow reasonable inference that creditor corporation controlled debtor corporation and would allow disregard of debtor corporation's status as separate entity. Affirmed.

Title: Omaha Indem. Co. v. Royal American Managers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Although shareholders ordinarily are not liable for corporate obligations, when corporation is alter ego or instrumentality of shareholder, judgment against corporation also establishes personal liability of shareholders under Missouri law.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporations and shareholders alleging breach of contract, and breach of fiduciary duty, negligence, fraudulent misrepresentation, prima facie tort, civil conspiracy and equitable relief. Claims against one corporation were submitted to arbitration and corporation was found liable.  Plaintiffs moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Bartlett, J., held that: (1) corporate officers and shareholders were personally liable for tortious conduct of their corporation, and (2) corporations controlled by shareholders were also liable. Motion granted.

Title: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. v. Intersteel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Voluntary creditor which had observed financial statement of corporation was not entitled to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Henry J. Mills Co., Inc. v. Crawfish Capitol Seafood, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Corporator's personal use of crawfish cooking facility as restaurant business for two to three weeks did not represent commingling of assets to extent required to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholders individually liable for corporate debts, nor did other relevant circumstances; inter alia, statutory formalities required for incorporation and transaction of corporate affairs were met, and corporation was not undercapitalized.

Simon, J., rendered judgment against corporation but absolved incorporators from any personal indebtedness and refused to recognize materialman's lien as untimely filed.  On appeal, the Court of Appeal, Domengeaux, C.J., held that trial court properly refused to pierce corporate veil and hold incorporators personally liable for corporation's debts, in light of totality of circumstances. Affirmed.

Title: Schwartz v. Spectratech Ink Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fifth District.
Headnote: Discrepancy between corporate name on corporate checks and name on other business forms was insufficient basis to ignore corporate form and hold individual defendants liable for goods sold to corporation.

Angel, J., entered a final judgment in favor of the seller.  Appeal was taken.  The District Court of Appeal held that a discrepancy in the corporation's name on corporate checks and the fact that the closely held corporation did not hold formal annual shareholders' meetings were not adequate to justify piercing the corporate veil and holding individual defendants liable for goods sold to the corporation. Reversed with instructions.

Title: Christensen v. Intelligent Systems Master Ltd. Partnership
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Even if promises parent relied upon to advance operating funds to wholly owned subsidiary while purchase of subsidiary was being negotiated were those of corporate buyer, buyer's corporate veil could be pierced to find its principal individually liable for corporation's obligations, where corporation was merely a shell.
Document Preview: Seller/parent brought suit against buyer and its principal for breach of contract to purchase parent's wholly owned subsidiary, and parent also alleged cause of action based on promissory estoppel.  The Gwinnett Superior Court, Henderson, J., awarded parent $1 verdict against buyer for breach of contract and $166,666.66 against its principal on promissory estoppel claim.  Principal appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Pope, J., held that: (1) principal could be found individually liable pursuant to doctrine of promissory estoppel, and (2) parent's damages under promissory estoppel claim was amount advanced for operating funds in reliance on principal's promise to execute sale agreement and reimburse parent. Affirmed.

Title: Wright v. Alan Mills, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Sole shareholder who was in charge of day-to-day operations of corporation would not be held personally liable for corporate obligations absent evidence that she had used corporation as device to defraud others or to circumvent requirements of Alabama corporation law.
Document Preview: Action on promissory note was brought against corporation and its sole shareholder.  The Circuit Court, DeKalb County, No. CV85280, David A. Rains, J., entered judgment against corporation, and creditors appealed.  The Supreme Court, Kennedy, J., held that sole shareholder who was in charge of day-to-day operations of corporation would not be held personally liable for corporate obligations absent evidence that she had used corporation as device to defraud others or to circumvent requirements of Alabama corporation law. Affirmed.

Title: Sea Tang Fisheries, Inc. v. You'll See Sea Foods, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Six shareholder meetings and five board of director meetings in approximately five years were not an insufficient number of meetings such as to justify piercing the corporate veil to hold a majority stockholder liable for a corporate debt on an open account.
Document Preview: Seller of shrimp brought action on open account against buyer of shrimp and stockholders of the buyer.  The Thirty-Second Judicial District Court in and for the Parish of Terrebonne, Wilmore J. Broussard, Jr., J., denied the declinatory exception of lack of venue, and rendered judgment on open account debt against buyer and pierced the corporate veil of buyer to hold majority stockholder personally liable, dismissed the suit as to other stockholders, and dismissed the defendants' reconventional demand.  The Court of Appeal, Crain, J., held that: (1) court would presume that trial court was correct in overruling defendant's exception of improper venue; (2) evidence did not support piercing corporate veil and holding majority stockholder liable for the debt on open account; and (3) trial court's decision to dismiss reconventional demand was not manifestly erroneous. Affirmed in part; reversed in part.

Title: N.L.R.B. v. Fullerton Transfer & Storage Ltd., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Employer's inability to pay debts at time of ceased operations, one shareholder's failure institute bankruptcy proceedings when winding up employer's affairs and failure to set aside money for back pay award, and shareholders' receipt of salaries and rents, rather than dividends, did not indicate injustice that would support piercing of corporate veil under alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) sought to enforce back pay order against employer's shareholders and related corporation owned and operated by shareholders.  The Court of Appeals, Kennedy, Circuit Judge, held that related corporation and shareholders were not alter egos of employer and were not liable for back pay award. Enforcement denied. Engel, Senior Circuit Judge, concurred and filed opinion.

Title: Itel Containers Intern. Corp. v. Atlanttrafik Exp. Service Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Foreign corporation did not exercise sufficient control over holding company formed to purchase shipping line to justify piercing holding company's corporate veil and hold corporation liable for holding company's debts; holding company's subsidiary was responsible for everyday affairs of shipping line and corporation did not interfere, holding company observed corporate formalities, and corporation did not dominate either holding company or subsidiary and did not use its position to have its loans to holding company repaid in preference to those of other creditors.
Document Preview: Cargo container lessors brought action against foreign corporation and related corporations seeking recovery under the leases.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Robert L. Carter, J., entered judgment in favor of defendants, 725 F.Supp. 1303, and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Kearse, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporation was not joint venturer with holding company formed to purchase shipping line; (2) holding company was not actual or implied agent of corporation; (3) corporation did not exercise sufficient control over holding company to warrant piercing of corporate veil; but (4) dismissing lessors' maritime lien claims against vessels without making findings of facts and conclusions of law, required vacation of judgment dismissing the claims. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Title: Harper v. Delaware Valley Broadcasters, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, corporation was not mere alter ego of its majority shareholder absent allegation of any unfairness or injustice which would justify disregarding its separate legal existence; consultant seeking unpaid wages from majority shareholder was director and officer of corporation, and thus was aware of corporate structure and operations.
Document Preview: Consultant hired by managing partner of limited partnership sought to hold general partners liable for unpaid wages.  On cross motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Murray M. Schwartz, Senior District Judge, held that managing partner's corporate signature made employment contract an obligation of limited partnership. Summary judgment for employee.

Title: Skidmore, Owings & Merrill v. Canada Life Assur. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Architectural firm, subsidiary corporations' judgment creditor, was not entitled to pierce subsidiaries' corporate veil to obtain payment from parent corporations under Colorado law, even though parents and subsidiaries possibly used poor judgment in not advising firm of financial condition of subsidiaries, and even if firm had difficulty in enforcing judgment against subsidiaries.
Document Preview: Architectural firm, judgment creditor of subsidiary corporations, brought action to collect debt from parent corporations.  The United States District Court for the District of Colorado, 706 F.Supp. 758, Lewis T. Babcock, J., entered summary judgment in favor of parent corporations.  Firm appealed. The Court of Appeals held that firm was not entitled to pierce subsidiaries' corporate veil. Affirmed.

Title: Rothermel v. Ermiger
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Shareholder may be held liable for corporate debts upon showing that he exercised complete dominion and control over corporation, or used corporation to transact his personal business; corporate entity may also be disregarded upon showing of fraud, illegality or wrongdoing.
Document Preview: Creditors of corporation brought action against shareholder. The County Court, Warren County, Moynihan, J., affirmed town court judgment in favor of creditors, and shareholder appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Kane, J., held that shareholder was improperly held liable for corporate debt absent evidence of shareholder's control over corporation or that any fraud or misrepresentation was perpetrated. Reversed.

Title: Buffalo Structural Steel Corp. v. Elsand Steel, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate creditor did not assume sufficient control over corporation's business operations to be liable for corporation's debts, simply because it assumed authority to approve corporation's contracts and projects; corporation retained control over its day-to-day operations.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor sued to foreclose on mortgage.  The County Court, Broome County, Monserrate, J., granted creditor's motion for summary judgment, and corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Mahoney, P.J., held that: (1) mortgagor could not defeat mortgagee's motion for summary judgment in mortgage foreclosure proceeding with unsupported, conclusory allegations that mortgagee acted fraudulently or in bad faith, and (2) corporate creditor did not assume sufficient control over corporation's business operations to be cast into liability for its debts. Affirmed.

Title: In re Bailey
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, corporation created to carry on business of preexisting corporation and to avoid cease-and-desist order issued by federal agency to the preexisting corporation and persons involved with it would be disregarded and personal liability for corporate debts would be imposed upon individual who acted as president and sole shareholder of the later formed corporation due to improper conduct in forming corporation with specific intention of circumventing law.
Document Preview: In Chapter 11 case of individual debtors, claims were asserted by entities with claims against corporation that was owned entirely by one of the debtors. The Bankruptcy Court, Alexander L. Paskay, Chief Judge, held that corporate entity would be disregarded and personal liability imposed upon debtors due to improper conduct of debtors in forming corporation with specific intention of circumventing cease-and-desist order issued by federal agency to preexisting corporation and persons involved with it. Claims allowed.

Title: Nelson v. Schanzer
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil of moving and storage company in order to hold its president personally liable for judgment rendered in favor of bailor was not an abuse of discretion in view of evidence showing that company was president's alter ego.
Document Preview: Tenant whose goods were given to moving and storage company pursuant to forcible entry and detainer action brought action against company and its president under Deceptive Trade Practices-Consumer Protection Act after some of his property was lost and damaged.  The 333rd District court, Harris County, Davie L. Wilson, J., rendered judgment for tenant and president appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Junell, J., held that: (1) piercing corporate veil was proper; (2) filing of action against company tolled running of limitations against president; (3) tenant was a consumer under Consumer Protection Act; (4) contract of bailment existed between tenant and company; and (5) award of attorney fees was not warranted. Modified, and as modified, affirmed.

Title: In re Rodriguez
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced, so as to allow parent holding company to be held liable for debt of subsidiary, whose sole asset was corporate jet, in that parent was itself a shell corporation which exercised no control over subsidiary, and there was no evidence that subsidiary's creditor had relied upon assets of parent when making loan to subsidiary.
Document Preview: Chapter 7 trustee brought action to recover payments made by debtor on behalf of subsidiary. The United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of Florida, Thomas C. Britton, Chief Judge, 77 B.R. 939, held for trustee, and appeal was taken. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, No. 87-2310-CIV-TES,Thomas E. Scott, J., affirmed. The Court of Appeals, Edenfield, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that corporate debtor did not receive reasonably equivalent value for payments made on behalf of subsidiary. Affirmed.

Title: William L. Comer Family Equity Trust v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether to disregard corporate entity for purposes of ascertaining debt liability, courts look to amount of respect given to separate entity of corporation by its shareholders, degree of injustice visited on litigants by recognition of corporate entity, and fraudulent intent of incorporators with factors to be considered including undercapitalization, maintenance of separate books, separation of corporate and individual finances, use of corporation to support fraud or illegality, honoring of corporate formalities, and whether corporation is merely a sham; the factors are not all inclusive and entire spectrum of relevant facts forms basis for an inquiry, and facts are to be assessed in light of corporation's economic justification to determine if corporate form has been abused.
Document Preview: Trusts purportedly holding assets of taxpayers brought action asserting that Internal Revenue Service in attempting satisfaction of income tax deficiencies owed by taxpayers levied against property owned by trusts as third parties. The District Court, James Harvey, J., held that trusts lacked standing to challenge Internal Revenue Service levies. Judgment for defendant.

Title: Aries Ventures Ltd. v. Axa Finance S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate shareholder could not be held liable as alter ego of managing corporation on claims for legal services rendered and moneys loaned, where no specific facts were offered to support claim that assets and liabilities were freely shifted among related corporations, and plaintiff attorney's testimony bolstered assertion that corporate manager was entity independent from successor corporate property owner whose investments were managed and acquired with loan support.
Document Preview: Attorney and president owner of lender that allegedly performed legal services and made loans in connection with property purchase brought action against successor corporate property owner and individual who was director and shareholder of property purchaser and shareholder of successor.  On defendants' motions for summary judgment and to dismiss claim against corporate owner for improper service of process, the District Court, William C. Conner, J., held that: (1) no direct contract between attorney or lender and successor or individual existed for legal services or loans, but piercing of corporate veil of purchasing corporation with respect to individual might be justified; (2) alleged creditor lacked standing to sue former corporate director based upon his voting for dissolution of corporation and distribution of corporate assets without first satisfying corporate debt to the alleged creditor under New York business corporation law; (3) corporate...

Title: Matter of P.R. Hotel Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Principal would not be held personally liable for corporate debts, under alter ego doctrine, though corporation never filed financial report or kept minutes of meetings, absent showing that principal had used corporation as business conduit for improper purpose, that corporation was inadequately capitalized or that agreement giving rise to debt in question was ultra vires act of principal.
Document Preview: Bankruptcy trustee brought action to collect debt.  The Bankruptcy Court, Sara E. De Jesus, J., held that principal would not be held personally liable for corporate debt, under alter ego doctrine, absent showing that principal had used corporation as business conduit for improper purpose, that corporation was inadequately capitalized or that agreement giving rise to debt in question was ultra vires act of principal. Complaint dismissed.

Title: Cab-Tek, Inc. v. E.B.M., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Vermont.
Headnote: Real estate corporation used corporate assets of stereo manufacturer for approximately two years following fire without attempting to compensate manufacturer, and, thus, trial court could reasonably conclude that assets had been transferred for no consideration which allowed court to pierce corporate veil and hold real estate corporation liable for debts of stereo manufacturer.
Document Preview: After receiving judgment against stereo manufacturer, creditor sought judgment against real estate corporation claiming that corporation had taken over manufacturer's operations.  The Superior Court, Windsor County, David A. Jenkins, J., found that real estate corporation was liable for manufacturer's debts under rules of corporate successor liability.  Corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Gibson, J., held that by taking control of all manufacturer's assets without consideration, corporation accomplished de facto merger which resulted in corporation's successor liability for manufacturer's debts. Affirmed.

Title: Newman v. Bartee
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: Principal of corporation formed to produce play would not be held personally liable for corporate debts absent showing that corporation was mere sham or dummy, or was being used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong or protect fraud; corporation was properly formed and capitalized pursuant to all applicable statutes, all parties knew they were dealing with corporation, and there was no evidence of any wrongdoing, misrepresentation or fraud.
Document Preview: Creditors brought action against corporate principal, claiming that corporate shield should be pierced.  The Chancery Court, Davidson County, C. Allen High, Chancellor, granted summary judgment for defendants, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Lewis, J., held that principal of corporation formed to produce play would not be held personally liable for corporate debts absent showing that corporation was mere sham or dummy, or was being used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong or protect fraud. Affirmed and remanded.

Title: In re Streamlight, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Violation of bulk transfer law in transaction pursuant to which debtor's customer transferred its customer lists, catalogs, financing supporting data and all its inventory to unrelated corporation was not "wrong" sufficiently related to relationship between customer and its parent so as to justify piercing of customer's corporate veil to render its parent liable for customer's debts, where under terms of transfer, parent, as well as customer, agree to indemnify purchaser on any matters concerning customer. N.Y.McKinney's Uniform Commercial Code § 6-101 et seq.
Document Preview: Debtor commenced adversary proceedings seeking to recover account receivable. The Bankruptcy Court, David A. Scholl, J., held that: (1) press release announcing merger of debtor's customer with customer's parent was insufficient to establish merger in legal sense of term so as to hold surviving corporation liable for customer's obligations under New York law; (2) parent corporation of debtor's customer was not liable for customer's debts; and (3) violation of New York transfer law entitled debtor to all remedies available to it. So ordered.

Title: Evanston Ins. Co. v. Luko
Court: Intermediate Court of Appeals of Hawai'i.
Headnote: Doctrine known as "piercing the corporate veil" could not be used to establish liability of officers of alleged successor corporation for unpaid balance on deductible for insurance policy since alleged successor corporation was not liable for debt of earlier corporation and record did not contain any evidence that officers were shareholders of alleged successor corporation.
Document Preview: Insurer sued corporate real estate agency firm, and alleged successor, and officers for unpaid balance of deductible on real estate agents and brokers errors and omissions policy.  The District Court of the First Circuit, Honolulu Division, Tany S. Hong, J., dismissed suit, and insurer appealed.  The Intermediate Court of Appeals, Tanaka, J., held that neither officers and directors of alleged successor corporation nor alleged successor corporation itself was liable for debt of firm. Affirmed and remanded with direction.

Title: Smith v. Isaacs
Court: Supreme Court of Kentucky.
Headnote: Shareholder is not liable for corporate debt, except upon proof of circumstances that justify piercing corporate veil or unless there is particular statute imposing liability for corporate debt. KRS 271A.125(5).
Document Preview: Customer of drinking establishment who was shot by second customer sued second customer, corporate owner of establishment, and individual who was officer, director, and principal shareholder of owner.  The Circuit Court, Fayette County, granted shareholder's motion to dismiss, and first customer appealed.  The Court of Appeals affirmed, and first customer sought review.  The Supreme Court, Leibson, J., held that: (1) complaint sufficiently alleged shareholder's personal negligence in first customer's shooting; (2) shareholder's status as officer, director, and principal shareholder did not immunize him from personal liability in tort for his negligence; and (3) complaint properly asserted alternative theories of liability against shareholder. Reversed and remanded with directions. Wintersheimer, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Title: BBCA, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota, Third Division.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, alter ego theory could be used to reach assets of a corporation in satisfaction of debts of individual shareholder; theory was not limited to holding shareholders liable for corporate obligations.
Document Preview: Corporation brought action seeking to quiet title to parcels of real property to which federal tax liens were alleged to have attached.  On corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Devitt, J., held that: (1) corporation could not challenge validity of underlying assessments; (2) alter ego theory could be used to reach assets of corporation in satisfaction of debts of individual shareholders; and (3) genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether shareholder used corporation in attempt to evade collection of tax liabilities by concealing their assets while enjoying use and benefit of those assets, precluding summary judgment. Motion for summary judgment denied.

Title: In re Blanton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, practice of lending of capital among related corporations to fund short-term cash flow needs did not reveal disregard of legal separateness of various corporations which would allow corporate veil to be pierced.
Document Preview: Chapter 7 debtors objected to claim of Arizona Department of Revenue for gross receipt taxes incurred by corporation owned by one debtor while corporation performed two family housing rehabilitation contracts at Air Force base in Arizona. The Bankruptcy Court, Larry E. Kelly, Chief Judge, held that: (1) Texas law applied to determine whether corporate veil should be pierced; (2) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporate form was resorted to as means of invading existing legal obligation, was inapplicable; (3) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporation was mere alter ego of debtor, was inapplicable; and (4) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporate entity of corporation and its related entities were used as means of perpetrating fraud, was inapplicable. Objection granted.

Title: In re Blanton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Ground for piercing the corporate veil under Texas law, that corporate fiction is resorted to as means of evading an existing legal obligation, applies to situation in which individual or existing corporation owes debts and with intent to avoid liability for those debts, creates new corporation and seeks to interpose new corporation between original debtor and preexisting creditor.
Document Preview: Chapter 7 debtors objected to claim of Arizona Department of Revenue for gross receipt taxes incurred by corporation owned by one debtor while corporation performed two family housing rehabilitation contracts at Air Force base in Arizona. Kelly, Chief Judge, held that: (1) Texas law applied to determine whether corporate veil should be pierced; (2) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporate form was resorted to as means of invading existing legal obligation, was inapplicable; (3) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporation was mere alter ego of debtor, was inapplicable; and (4) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporate entity of corporation and its related entities were used as means of perpetrating fraud, was inapplicable. Objection granted.

Title: In re Haugen Const. Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. North Dakota, Southwestern Division.
Headnote: Under North Dakota law, sole shareholder and another of his corporations could be held jointly liable for corporate debt, under alter ego theory; corporation completely neglected any type of corporate formality, and commingled assets of sole shareholder and other corporation without hesitation.
Document Preview: Corporate debtor's creditors brought action to pierce corporate veil.  On report and recommendation of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of North Dakota, William A. Hill, J., the District Court, Conmy, Chief Judge, held that sole shareholder and another of his corporations could be held jointly liable for corporate debt, under alter ego theory. Judgment for creditors.

Title: St. Paul Fire and Marine Ins. Co. v. PepsiCo, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Even if guarantor of former subsidiary's bonds was subrogated to former subsidiary's rights following subsidiary's default on the bonds, former subsidiary did not have sufficiently particularized claim against its purchaser's parent to allow guarantor to bring action in federal court against parent on alter ego theory, where former subsidiary's claim against purchaser's parent was not for default on bonds, but was generalized claim that parent's looting caused its insolvency. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 541, 544, 547.
Document Preview: Issuer of bonds covering debts of guarantor's former subsidiary brought action against guarantor following subsidiary's default, and guarantor brought third-party claim against parent of subsidiary's purchaser.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Kevin Thomas Duffy, J., dismissed third-party complaint, and guarantor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Meskill, Circuit Judge, held that guarantor did not have standing to assert claims against parent outside of former subsidiary's bankruptcy proceeding. Affirmed. See also, Bkrtcy., 100 B.R. 950.

Title: American Hardware Supply v. Alan Supply, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: There was no basis for disregarding corporate fiction to hold sole shareholder of corporation liable for debts of corporation on basis of guaranty he executed as principal for different business; loss caused to creditor was not result of wrongful act by sole shareholder, but rather, resulted from failure of creditor to act prudently and timely in securing personal guaranty in favor of newly formed corporation of which it had notice.
Document Preview: Creditor sued debtor corporation and its sole shareholder for goods sold to corporation.  Creditor alleged that shareholder was personally liable on basis of guaranty he signed as principal for another corporation.  The Frankin County Court of Common Pleas held shareholder personally liable.  Shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Bowman, J., held that: (1) creditor had notice of change in business form, and (2) there was no basis for disregarding corporate fiction. Reversed in part, affirmed in part, and remanded with directions.

Title: Mobil Oil Corp. v. Linear Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under ordinary circumstances, parent corporation will not be held liable for obligations of its subsidiary.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against, among others, parent corporation of subsidiary which manufactured allegedly infringing product. Parent moved for summary judgment and patent holder moved to substitute subsidiary for parent as party defendant.  The District Court, Latchum, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent was not liable for any direct infringement; (2) parent could not be held liable under alter ego theory for infringement of its subsidiary; (3) parent could not be held liable under pure agency theory for infringement of its subsidiary; and (4) subsidiary could not be substituted for parent. Parent's motion granted and patent holder's motion denied.

Title: Board of Trustees of Mill Cabinet Pension Trust Fund for Northern California v. Valley Cabinet & Mfg. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Even if it was shown that sole shareholder had commingled corporate funds, it did not necessarily follow that his estate would be liable for the debts of the corporation.
Document Preview: Pension fund brought action against estate of sole shareholder of employer to recover amounts owed to the fund.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of California, Charles A. Legge, J., denied relief, and fund appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Boochever, Circuit Judge, held that evidence sustained trial court's refusal to pierce corporate veil. Affirmed.

Title: State Bank in Eden Valley v. Euerle Farms, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Family farm corporation was alter ego of its owner occupants, and thus, court properly applied reverse piece of corporate veil to hold that property was entitled to homestead exemption from levy; after incorporation, occupants continued to occupy and use their farm homes as their own and continued to receive real estate homestead tax exemptions on property, occupants did not pay any rent to farm corporation, and occupants did not receive salaries as corporate officers. M.S.A. §§ 510.01, 510.02.

Shareholders also sought a declaration that creditors were not entitled to a deficiency judgment in a replevin action commenced by creditors.  The District Court, Meeker County, Arthur Boylan, J., applied a reverse pierce of the corporate veil, ruled that the real estate conveyances were fraudulent, and held that creditors were entitled to a deficiency judgment.  Creditors appealed and shareholders filed a notice of review.  The Court of Appeals, Parker, J., held that: (1) application of the reverse pierce of the corporate veil was appropriate; (2) the court erred in ruling that the real estate conveyances were fraudulent; and (3) shareholders and corporation waived their...

Title: Bodenhamer Bldg. Corp. v. Architectural Research Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Determination that, under Michigan law, it was proper to pierce corporate veils of two wholly owned subsidiaries in order to enforce state judgment against first subsidiary was supported by sufficient evidence showing that corporate officers were exactly the same, that one individual ran both subsidiaries and parent corporation, that second subsidiary was alter-ego of first subsidiary, and that various employees of parent specifically intended to defraud plaintiff and to prevent plaintiff from collecting its judgment by employing a "fraudulent shell game.".
Document Preview: General contractor brought action against subcontractor, subcontractor's successor corporation, and parent corporation of both subcontractor and successor alleging disregard of corporate entity and violation of Michigan Fraudulent Conveyance Act and Michigan Bulk Transfer Act.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, Lawrence P. Zatkoff, J., rendered judgment for contractor and imposed sanctions against defendants, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Engel, Chief Judge, held that: (1) evidence supported determinations that defendants violated Fraudulent Conveyance Act and that piercing corporate veil was proper, and (2) contractor was not entitled to Rule 11 sanctions. Affirmed in part, reversed and remanded in part.

Title: In re Gherman
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Separate identities of corporations formed by and dominated by individual debtor as mere instrumentalities to hinder, delay, or defraud his creditors or to conceal money he had embezzled, could be disregarded; each corporation was alter ego of the individual debtor.
Document Preview: Trustee for investors from whom debtor embezzled $9.7 million sought denial of discharge and recovery from debtor's family of money transferred to them and imposition of constructive trust upon assets bought with that money.  The Bankruptcy Court, Thomas C. Britton, Chief Judge, held that: (1) debtor was not entitled to discharge, and (2) constructive trust would be imposed. Judgment accordingly.

Title: Arrow Mfg. Co., Inc. v. Levinson
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Circumstances did not warrant piercing of corporate veil, by permitting judgment creditor to collect debt of corporation directly from principal shareholder, following noncompliance with demand for information regarding corporation in connection with execution, where demand was not specifically addressed to shareholder and attorneys for creditor and shareholder had been in touch with each other and shareholder's attorney had indicated shareholder was willing to provide necessary information. N.J.S.A. 2A:17-74, 2A:17-75.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor of corporation sued principal shareholder personally for amount of judgment.  The Superior Court, Law Division, Bergen County, entered default judgment against shareholder, and he appealed.  The Superior Court, Appellate Division, O'Brien, J.A.D., held that default judgment was inappropriate, as there was no evidence demand for information regarding corporation, which must be made before suit against shareholder could be brought, had been addressed specifically to shareholder and there was evidence shareholder's attorney had made some contacts with creditor's attorney indicating willingness to provide information in question, and circumstances did not warrant piercing of corporate veil. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Skidmore, Owings & Merrill v. Canada Life Assur. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Real estate development subsidiaries were not mere instrumentality of corporate parent insurance companies, so that parents were not liable for debt of the subsidiaries to architectural firm, even though parents presented the subsidiaries as the parents' "development arm," chose their own company executives to sit on the subsidiaries' boards, subsidiaries were allegedly undercapitalized, and parents may have made accommodations to the subsidiaries that an ordinary arm's length investor would not, where the subsidiaries transacted all of their own business and had distinct corporate identities, there was never any comingling of funds or other assets, there were no common directors, and the subsidiaries observed the formal corporate legal requirements.
Document Preview: Architectural firm which was creditor of subsidiary corporations brought action to collect the debt from parent corporations.  On parent corporations' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Babcock, J., held that: (1) the subsidiaries were not mere instrumentalities of the parents so as to render parents liable for the debt, and (2) parents had not used the corporate entity to perpetrate fraud so as to allowing piercing the corporate veil, even if there was an issue as to whether parents acted prudently in allowing architectural firm to continue to provide services after the parent corporations were aware of the subsidiaries' financial problems. Motion granted.

Headnote: Parent corporations did not perpetrate fraud so as to permit architectural firm, as creditor of subsidiaries, to pierce the corporate veil and hold the parents liable for the subsidiaries' debts to the firm, even though there may have been an issue as to whether the parents acted prudently in allowing the firm to continue providing architectural services to the subsidiaries after the parents were aware of the subsidiaries' financial problems.

Motion granted.

Title: Carpenter Paper Co. of Nebraska v. Lakin Meat Processors, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Proceedings seeking disregard of corporate entity, that is, seeking to pierce corporate veil to impose liability on shareholder for corporation's debt or other obligation, are equitable actions.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor brought action against corporate debtor and shareholder, seeking to set aside as fraudulent conveyance assignment to shareholder proceeds from sale of substantially all of corporation's assets and to pierce corporate veil to hold shareholder personally liable for judgment debt.  The District Court for Douglas County, Paul J. Hickman, J., dismissed both causes of action following trial, and judgment creditor appealed.  The Supreme Court, Hastings, C.J., held that corporation was mere corporate shell and corporate entity was to be disregarded. Reversed and remanded for further proceedings.

Title: Carpenter Paper Co. of Nebraska v. Lakin Meat Processors, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Corporation was mere corporate shell and alter ego of shareholder, and therefore corporate entity would be disregarded and shareholder would be held liable for debt of corporation, in view of evidence of corporation's inadequate capitalization and insolvency and of shareholder's control over corporation; there was unity of interest between shareholder and corporation.

Title: Boatmen's Nat. Bank of St. Louis v. Smith
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, judgment against debtor, who was sole shareholder, director, president and treasurer of corporation, could be satisfied out of funds of corporation; corporation was alter ego of debtor since assets of debtor and corporation were commingled, debtor did not keep bank account in his own name, and debtor's wife paid household expenses by borrowing money from corporation and other companies controlled by debtor.
Document Preview: Creditor, who obtained judgment against debtor, brought motion for turnover order in order to reach funds held in name of corporation of which debtor was sole shareholder, director, president and treasurer in satisfaction of judgment against debtor. The District Court, Moran, J., held that under Illinois law, judgment against debtor could be satisfied out of funds of corporation. Motion granted.

Headnote: British corporation which contracted to supply fuel oil was controlled by its chairman managing director with respect to oil supply transaction and was used by chairman managing director to commit fraud or wrong, and was accordingly alter ego of the chairman managing director; corporation had 100 pounds of operating capital, but entered into $34 million transaction, corporation was organized solely to conduct the chairman managing director's personal business, and it was misrepresented that British corporation was branch of Saudi Arabian corporation either with intent to deceive or with reckless disregard for consequences of the misrepresentation.

Oil trading company removed state proceeding to federal court and then moved to compel arbitration and for appointment of arbitrator. Title: U.S. v. Golden Acres, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Government was not estopped from arguing undercapitalization of corporation as basis for piercing corporate veil and holding individual shareholders liable on alter ego theory by fact that Department of Housing and Urban Development insured loan to corporation despite knowledge that corporation was financed well below ten percent minimum capitalization usually required for such insurance; corporation continued to be undercapitalized after transfer of control and new owners breached ongoing duty to maintain adequate capitalization, and Department's willingness to relax initial capital investment requirement could not be construed as deceitful. National Housing Act, § 221(d)(4), as amended, 12 U.S.C.A. § 1715l (d)(4).
Document Preview: United States, representing interests of Department of Housing and Urban Development, filed suit against defunct corporation and its former sole shareholders, officers, and directors.  The District Court, 684 F.Supp. 96, granted summary judgment against individual defendants for violation of federal priority statute.  Default judgment was subsequently entered against corporation for breach of HUD security instrument.  In resolving remaining issues, the District Court, Roth, J., held that: (1) corporate veil would be pierced and individuals held liable for default judgment against corporation, and (2) prejudgment interest would be awarded on judgment against individuals from date of last payment on mortgage note, at rate of seven percent per annum. Ordered accordingly.

Title: U.S. v. Golden Acres, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under federal alter ego standard, corporate veil would be pierced and sole shareholders, officers, and directors of corporation that owned apartment complex held liable on default judgment entered against corporation for breach of HUD security instrument; corporation was effectively being used as "incorporated pocketbook" to pay off debt on construction contract owed, individuals who acquired corporation acted with total disregard for corporate formalities, and absence of dividends, along with corporation's insolvency, was further evidence that it was not being operated as viable corporation.

In resolving remaining issues, the District Court, Roth, J., held that: (1) corporate veil would be pierced and individuals held liable for default judgment against corporation, and (2) prejudgment interest would be awarded on judgment against individuals from date of last payment on mortgage note, at rate of seven percent per annum. Title: Gibraltar Sav. v. LDBrinkman Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Holding company and its principal shareholder were not "alter egos" of subsidiaries who obtained loans, and thus were not contractually liable to lender, absent evidence of lack of separateness.

Title: Matter of Estate of Gifford
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil was not pierced to impose personal liability for note on president and shareholder, even though corporation had been foreclosed, where record did not contain any allegations that president misled borrower as to creditworthiness of company, and where it appeared that president respected corporate form to extent that he maintained his own interests and did not commingle corporate funds and assets with his own.

Title: Bergh v. Mills
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: Corporate veil could be pierced so as to render shareholders of saloon owning corporation individually liable on open account established to lodge saloon's entertainers at motel, even though motel was not defrauded in capitalization of corporation, considering that motel would not have entered and continued its contract with saloon owning corporation in absence of shareholders' fraudulent acts.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Headnote: Court may, in its equitable powers, disregard separate legal entity of corporation and individual where separateness is used as subterfuge to defraud a creditor.
Document Preview: Garnishee appealed from final money judgments rendered by the Circuit Court of Clay County, Rollie R. Baldwin, J., in garnishment proceedings.  The Court of Appeals, Gaitan, P.J., held that having determined that separate corporate existence of judgment debtor's closely held corporation should be ignored, trial court properly treated corporation as judgment debtor, lifting corporation from operation and protection of garnishment statute's pay-in provision and proceeding to direct execution on judgment. Affirmed.

Title: Matter of Xonics Photochemical, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Assets of affiliated corporations are not treated as common pool available to creditors of each affiliate unless unusual circumstances are present that would make it inequitable to allow other affiliates to set up the principle of limited liability, the clearest of such circumstance being that creditors of all affiliates had thought they were dealing with unitary enterprise.
Document Preview: Debtor in possession brought adversary proceeding against supplier to set aside two payments as preferences.  The Bankruptcy Court rendered judgment for debtor, and supplier appealed.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division, Brian Barnett Duff, J., affirmed, and supplier appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Posner, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) affiliate derived benefit from its guarantees of another affiliate's debt, as required for guarantee to be enforceable, and (2) right to invoke Bankruptcy Code provisions governing fraudulent conveyances belonged not to particular unsecured creditor, but to trustee or debtor in possession. Affirmed.

Title: Alman v. George Mfg. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Individual might be held liable for debts of corporation if facts are presented to justify piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: Trustee of three union employee benefit funds brought action against corporation and its sole shareholder to collect unpaid pension, health and welfare contributions. Title: Consumer's Co-op. of Walworth County v. Olsen
Court: Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Whether contractual relationship is truly one in which creditor had opportunity to investigate capital structure of corporate debtor and knowingly failed to exercise that right before extending credit, such that the creditor should be precluded from piercing the corporate veil, should be decided with respect to the particular facts of each case rather than by the denial to all contract creditors of resort to equitable remedy of piercing the corporate veil by presumption of assumption of risk.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor brought action against two shareholders, seeking to impose personal liability for an unsatisfied judgment against the corporation.  The Walworth County Circuit Court, Robert D. Read, J., entered judgment in favor of creditor, and shareholders appealed.  Upon certification of action by the Court of Appeals, the Supreme Court, Ceci, J., held that: (1) evidence was insufficient to warrant piercing of corporate veil, and (2) creditor by its actions was precluded from asserting inadequacy of capitalization as basis to pierce corporate veil. Reversed and remanded.

Title: First Federal Sav. & Loan Ass'n of Florida Keys v. St. Laurent

Headnote: Vendor was not entitled to offset commission due real estate broker against unrelated debt owed to broker by corporation related to broker, absent any evidence warranting piercing corporate veil of broker.

Title: Electronic Switching Industries, Inc. v. Faradyne Electronics Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, seller of telephone switching equipment was not entitled to pierce corporate veil of buyer to recover from buyer's parent corporations, absent showing that any control and domination exercise by owners was used to commit wrong, fraud, or breach of legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of seller's legal rights.

Title: In re Ipswich Bituminous Concrete Products, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Former officers were not personally liable for all of corporate debtor's debts absent evidence that company was undercapitalized throughout its history, or that officers had disregarded debtor's separate corporate identity; under Massachusetts law, court was disinclined to pierce corporate veil absent elements of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: Chapter 7 trustee brought adversary complaint against former officers of corporate debtor.  The Bankruptcy Court, James N. Judgment for trustee.

Title: In re Ingersoll
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. North Carolina, Asheville Division.
Headnote: Principal, which formed corporation to obtain benefit of limited liability, could not disregard existence of corporate entity for purposes of obtaining setoff against debt corporation owed debtors against debt that debtors owed principal.
Document Preview: Matter came before court on motion of creditor for relief from automatic stay to offset debt. The Bankruptcy Court, George R. Hodges, J., held that: (1) mutuality required for setoff under Bankruptcy Code was not satisfied where corporation which purchased debtor's travel agencies was indebted to debtors, and debtors were indebted to corporation's principal; (2) fact that corporation's principal was guarantor of corporation's debt to debtors did not satisfy mutuality requirement for setoff of debt owed debtor against debtor's debt to principal; and (3) principal, which formed corporation to obtain benefit of limited liability, could not disregard existence of corporate entity for purposes of obtaining setoff against debt corporation owed debtors against debt debtors owed principal. So ordered.

Title: Hideca Petroleum Corp. v. Tampimex Oil Intern., Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: When corporations are not operated as separate entities, but rather integrate their resources to achieve common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for debts incurred by other component entities in pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: Action was brought for breach of contract arising out of aborted international crude oil transaction.  The 234th District Court, Harris County, Ruby Sondock, J., entered judgment for seller of crude oil and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Levy, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic crude oil company was individually liable on contract because it was acting for undisclosed or partially disclosed principal, and substituted its own responsibility for, or pledged its own responsibility in addition to, that of its principal; (2) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic oil company was alter ego of oil company operating in international markets; and (3) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic oil company was liable for damages for negligent misrepresentation. Affirmed.

Title: Miller & Schroeder, Inc. v. Gearman
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: It would not be unfair or unjust for court to fail to engage in a "reverse piercing of the corporate veil" so as to treat guarantor as the corporate mortgagor on the basis of claim that the mortgagor was merely his alter ego, thus entitling guarantor to claim the advantage of the antideficiency statute, where guarantor had acted through his corporation for over 20 years, held various properties through it, and enjoyed the benefits thereof and was experienced businessman engaged in commercial transactions. M.S.A. § 580.23, subd. 1.
Document Preview: Mortgagee brought action to recover deficiency arising out of foreclosure by advertisement.  The District Court, Hennepin County, Franklin J. Knoll, J., entered judgment in favor of mortgagee on main claim and on guarantor's counterclaim for fraud, and guarantor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Nierengarten, J., held that: (1) court would not engage in reverse piercing of the corporate veil by treating guarantor as the corporate mortgagor on the basis of claim that the mortgagor was merely his alter ego, so as to permit him to take advantage of the antideficiency statute, and (2) mortgagee which had promised to use its best efforts to obtain public funding for development project had not engaged in fraud, even though it was unsuccessful in its efforts. Affirmed. Wozniak, J., dissented and filed an opinion.

Title: Messick v. Moring
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Write off loan of $112,000 to stockholders as bad debt, with no effort to collect, and transfer of money into stock brokerage account without any documentation as to disposition of funds, were insufficient to establish excessive control of corporation by stockholders so as to warrant imposition of personal liability on stockholders for corporation's debts.

The Supreme Court, Shores, J., held that write off of loan of $112,000 to stockholders as bad debt, with no effort to collect, and transfer of money into stock brokerage account without any documentation were insufficient to establish excessive control of corporation by stockholders so as to warrant imposition of personal liability on stockholders for corporation's debts. Affirmed.

Title: Federal Deposit Ins. Corp. v. Martinez Almodovar
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Two corporations did not have separate personalities from individual defendants who controlled them, but were mere extensions of their personalities; pattern of transaction between individuals and corporations, confusing and sketchy records of transactions, failure to suggest any sound business reasons for transactions, and effect of transactions on financial condition of individual defendants, led to conclusion that corporations were used by individuals as repositories for assets of two individuals to protect them from claims of their creditors.
Document Preview: The FDIC brought an action in its corporate capacity seeking to collect certain assets acquired from receiver of closed bank.  The District Court, Perez-Gimenez, Chief Judge, held that: (1) FDIC's action on note was not time barred; (2) borrower's former wife was not released from liability she might have had on borrower's indebtedness to bank absent suggestion in letters by and between bank and borrower of intention to substitute or extinguish obligation; (3) family corporations were alter egos of defendant; (4) daughter and son-in-law of a borrower were liable to FDIC for damages; and (5) former wife's transfer of her shares of preferred stock of family corporation to her granddaughters would be rescinded. So ordered.

The Court of Appeals, Nearn, J., Retired, held that homeowner contracted with renovator in his personal, and not his corporate, capacity. Affirmed.

Title: In re Distrigas Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, debtor corporation and claimant corporation were alter egos, and claim was thus unenforceable as representing at best "debt" that debtor corporation owed itself, where debtor and claimant corporation had same address, directors, officers, telephones answered by same person, and counsel, debtor corporation performed no real business function separate from the other corporation except as holder of Federal Energy Regulatory Commission import license, and allowance of claim would deplete debtor's estate at expense of other real creditor.
Document Preview: Trustee and creditor sought to have claim of corporation against Chapter 7 debtor corporation disallowed.  The Bankruptcy Court, Harold Lavien, J., held that: (1) claimant corporation was alter ego of debtor corporation under Massachusetts law, and claim was thus unenforceable, and (2) even if claimant corporation were not alter ego of debtor corporation, claim arising out of purchase gas cost adjustment credit reflecting rolling adjustment credit that would dissipate when amortized pursuant to Federal Energy Regulatory Commission regulation in process of fixing price for liquified natural gas to be effective for succeeding six-month period would be unenforceable under nonbankruptcy law, and thus had to be disallowed. Claim disallowed.

Title: Phoenix Canada Oil Co. Ltd. v. Texaco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: American oil companies were not responsible under Delaware law for obligations of their Ecuadorian subsidiaries, even though subsidiaries were wholly owned by parents, there were officers and directors common to boards of parents and subsidiaries, and parents were involved in substantial financial decisions of subsidiaries, where subsidiaries kept books and records completely separate from parents, and subsidiaries had their principal places of business in Ecuador and were completely responsible for their day-to-day operations in Ecuador.
Document Preview: Canadian corporation brought action against international oil companies for breach of contract and unjust enrichment in connection with contract assigning two oil companies right to develop petroleum concession in Ecuador. The District Court, Roth, J., held that: (1) corporation could not recover under theory of unjust enrichment under Ecuadorian law for future production rights under assignment contract from oil companies who sold their interests to Ecuadorian government at net book value; (2) oil companies were required to pay royalties in accordance with official Ecuadorian government tax reference price in effect at time production was commenced, and not government royalty valuation in effect at time assignment contract was executed; and (3) Canadian corporation was entitled to prejudgment interest from date of service at legal rate of interest in effect in Ecuador during pendency of action. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Estudios, Proyectos e Inversiones de Centro America, S.A. (EPICA) v. Swiss Bank Corp. (Overseas) S.A.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Corporation's veil will be pierced where corporation's controlling shareholder formed or used corporation to defraud creditors by evading liability for preexisting obligations; remedy is available both to make controlling shareholder liable for corporate liabilities and to hold corporation liable for debts of controlling shareholder where controlling shareholder used corporation to avoid preexisting personal liability.
Document Preview: After debtor defaulted on notes, creditor's assignee brought action against various guarantors and simultaneously filed emergency motion for writ of attachment.  Writ was granted and sheriff seized personal property and business records from horse-breeding farm owned by corporation of which one guarantor was controlling shareholder.  The Circuit Court for Dade County, John A. Tanksley, J., denied corporation's motion for dissolution of writ, and corporation appealed.  The District Court of Appeal held that: (1) evidence supported decision to pierce corporate veil and grant writ of attachment securing corporation's property so as to provide funds to satisfy possible judgment against guarantor, but (2) trial court erred in authorizing attachment of corporation's financial and property records in issuing writ. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Title: Baird Ward Printing Co., Inc. v. Great Recipes Pub. Associates
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation which was incorporated by individual general partner and substituted as general partner to limit individual's personal liability was not merely an undercapitalized shell formed to defraud creditors so as to allow its corporate veil to be pierced in favor of creditor to which partnership was indebted, where individual general partner capitalized corporation with approximately $250,000.
Document Preview: Creditor to which partnership was indebted sought to hold individual general partner personally liable for partnership's debt.  The United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, John T. Nixon, J., entered judgment finding that individual partner was not personally liable, and creditor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Norris, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) individual general partner's substitution of his newly formed corporation as general partner in order to limit his personal liability was not fraud, as creditor was on notice of substitution; (2) corporation was not merely undercapitalized shell formed to defraud creditors so as to allow its corporate veil to be pierced; and (3) creditor lacked standing to complain that individual partner improperly withdrew and substituted his corporation as general partner and that individual was consequently still liable for partnership's debt. Affirmed.

Title: Resorts Intern., Inc. v. Charter Air Center, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Parent corporation may be held liable for acts of its subsidiary when subsidiary is mere instrumentality of parent and is used to mislead parent's creditors or to fraudulently avoid liability.
Document Preview: Airline brought action against offshore casino and its subsidiary for breach of contract to provide air service to casino.  The Circuit Court, Dade County, Richard S. Fuller, J., found in favor of airline, and casino and subsidiary appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Nesbitt, J., held that: (1) finding that casino was liable under contract between subsidiary and airline was supported by evidence that casino intended to fraudulently avoid liability by having airline contract with subsidiary; (2) admission of evidence establishing oral contract between airline and casino for financial guarantee was not barred by statute of frauds; and (3) award of damages for lost profits and expenditures made in reliance on contract was erroneous. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Title: Cattron, Inc. v. Overhead Crane & Hoist, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, First District, Hamilton County.
Headnote: Corporation which was formed by sales manager of former corporation, whose sole shareholder had retired, was separate and distinct corporation and not liable for former corporation's debts, despite second corporation's business in same field, and fact that some employees of former corporation were now employees of second, where no transfer of assets occurred between first corporation and second.
Document Preview: Creditor of former corporation sued corporation and successor corporation for liability on debts.  The Court of Common Pleas, Hamilton County, found successor corporation jointly and severally liable for debt with previous corporation.  Successor corporation appealed. Title: Davidson v. Beco Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Idaho.
Headnote: Controlling shareholders of debtor corporations would not be held personally liable for corporations' debts; though evidence that original corporation had never held director or shareholder meetings and that important business decisions had been unilaterally made by one shareholder supported finding of unity of ownership and interest, evidence did not show that it was necessary to impose personal liability in order to prevent fraud or remedy injustice, as book value of renamed corporation far exceeded amount of judgment eventually entered against it and had not been challenged as unrealistic.
Document Preview: Creditor filed collection suit against corporations and controlling shareholders.  The District Court, Bonneville County, H. Reynold George, J., entered judgment on jury verdict for creditor.  On appeal, the Court of Appeals, Burnett, J., held that: (1) challenge to use of letter of proposed settlement had not been waived through failure to renew objection to that evidence at trial following partial denial of motion in limine; (2) admission of statement contained in that letter, concerning creditor's refusal of earlier offer of property in lieu of cash, was harmless error; (3) shareholders would not be personally liable for corporate debt, despite abundant evidence of unity of interest and ownership; and (4) though attorney fee award was not excessive, creditor had not entirely prevailed and reconsideration of award was warranted. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Title: Sutton's Steel & Supply, Inc. v. Van Stavern
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Sole shareholder of construction company was not personally liable for corporate debt where shareholder did not commingle personal funds with those of corporation, and observed corporate formalities.
Document Preview: Seller of material to construction company brought action on open account against sole shareholder of company.  The 16th Judicial District Court, Iberia Parish, Ann L. Simon, J., held for seller, and shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Domengeaux, J., held that: (1) sole shareholder did not ratify agent's unauthorized agreement absent knowledge agreement held him personally liable for corporate debt, and (2) sole shareholder was not liable for corporate debt where personal and corporate funds were not comingled and corporate formalities were observed. Reversed and rendered.

Title: Curtis v. Lehigh Footwear, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: In absence of bad faith, corporate entity will not be disregarded to extend liability for corporate debt to shareholders.
Document Preview: Employees of subsidiary corporation brought action against parent corporation for severance pay.  The Superior Court, Cumberland County, held that parent corporation was not employer of employees, and employees appealed.  The Supreme Judicial Court, Wathen, J., held that parent corporation was not liable for severance pay of employees of entirely owned subsidiary, as statute mandating severance pay contained no clear expression of legislative intent to extend liability to shareholders of parent corporation. Affirmed.

Title: McCracken v. Olson Companies, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fifth Division.
Headnote: Where such variables as inadequate capitalization, failure to observe corporate formalities, commingling of funds, and absence of corporate records are coupled with some element of injustice or fundamental unfairness, corporation will be considered as an aggregate of persons both in equity and at law, and its officers, directors and shareholders will be held individually liable for corporation's debts and obligations.
Document Preview: Attorney brought action against corporate client and its officer/director to recover attorney fees pursuant to written contract.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, Dean M. Trafelet, J., entered judgment in favor of attorney.  The officer/director appealed.  The Appellate Court, Lorenz J., held that: (1) evidence supported trial court's finding that corporation should not be allowed to shield officer/director from liability; (2) declaration that officer/director promised to pay debt, accompanied by his personal initial, constituted sufficient writing from which trial court could determine his intent to bind himself personally; and (3) trial court's finding that officer/director ratified attorney fee contract was not against manifest weight of the evidence. Affirmed.

Title: Bostwick-Braun Co. v. Szews
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Creditor had right and opportunity to evaluate financial condition of corporation which it granted franchise, and creditor's failure to evaluate financial condition while continuing to do business with corporation estopped creditor from asserting claim against owners of corporation for undercapitalization and waived creditor's right to challenge adequacy of corporation's capital, under Wisconsin law so that creditor would not be permitted to pierce corporate veil of corporation due to inadequate capitalization.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against owners of corporation for debts incurred in their business. The District Court, Shabaz, J., held that: (1) franchise agreement was between plaintiff and corporate entity owned by defendants, not between plaintiff and defendants personally, and (2) creditor would not be permitted to pierce corporate veil of corporation due to inadequate capitalization of corporation, based on theories of estoppel and waiver. Summary judgment for defendants.
