Title: Zarett v. Wasserman
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Whether corporate entity should be disregarded so as to render individuals liable for corporate obligation depends upon particular circumstances of each case.
Document Preview: Purchasers of new home brought action against corporate developer and president of corporation seeking to recover damages for alleged fraud in failing to issue or honor certain written warranties, as well as alleged breach of contractual obligation to complete certain work on property.  The State Court, Fulton County, Cummings, J., granted summary judgment in favor of president, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Banke, C.J., held that: (1) no basis existed for piercing corporate veil so as to hold president personally liable for corporation's debts, and (2) any antecedent agreement or promise involving furnishing of written warranties was extinguished at time of closing. Affirmed.

Title: Ellis v. Edwards
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Mere statement in legal document that defendants were lawful owners and sellers of businesses owned by corporation did not pierce corporate veil and raise issue as to disregarding of separateness of legal entities by commingling and confusion of properties, nor did statement by defendant that he was "good for money" require that defendant answer for debt of corporation.
Document Preview: Creditor sued individual defendants to recover debt owed by corporation.  The Superior Court, Pike County, Miller, J., entered summary judgment against creditor and creditor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Birdsong, P.J., held that: (1) individuals were not liable for corporate debt where statement that individuals were lawful owners and sellers of businesses owned by corporation did not pierce corporate veil nor did statement of individual that he was good for money, and (2) no evidence of abuse of corporate form for purpose of promoting fraud or injustice or evasion of tort or contractual responsibility was demonstrated. Affirmed.

Title: Universal Lending Corp. v. Wirth Companies, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: An officer and shareholder of corporation cannot be held personally liable for obligations of corporation except in certain limited circumstances, where corporate entity is merely alter ego of the shareholder and fundamental unfairness would result if the corporate entity were not disregarded, where an officer or a shareholder personally guarantees obligations of the corporation, or where officer of corporation actually participated in the corporation's conversion of another's property.
Document Preview: Partners owning minority interest brought suit against majority partners for damages resulting from breach of partnership agreement and mismanagement of partnership business.  The District Court, Hennepin County, Eugene Minenko, J., awarded damages and increased to majority the percentage of ownership to original minority partners.  Former majority partners appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Lansing, J., held that: (1) evidence supported findings on value of partnership property and percentage of ownership in interest pursuant to partnership agreement; (2) former majority partner's failure to plead or litigate by consent equitable estoppel defense rendered issue waived in post-trial motions; and (3) sole shareholder and officer of corporate partner was not personally liable for corporate obligations, but was liable for conversion of partnership property. Affirmed in part, reversed and remanded in part.

Title: Almac, Inc. v. JRH Development, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Corporation's creditors will be allowed to "pierce the corporate veil" of shareholder's protection from liability only when corporation was formed either as shareholders' alter ego or as mere instrumentality and if there exists element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: Creditor sued corporation and its president to collect on promissory note backed by mortgage.  The District Court, Scott County, John M. Fitzgerald, J., determined that the president was personally liable.  President appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Crippen, J., held that: (1) the trial court erroneously pierced the corporate veil to hold the president liable; (2) there was no basis for promoter liability where a de facto corporation existed at the time the president executed the note; and (3) the president was not responsible for attorney fees incurred by the corporation. Reversed.

Title: Union Trust Co. of Maryland v. Charter Medical Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Corporation with which debtor was purportedly going to merge could not be held liable to creditor under theories of promissory estoppel, fraud, or piercing corporate veil, based on representations made at meeting between all parties after corporation decided to cancel share tender offer; there was no evidence that any promises made at meeting were not at least eventually performed or that any delay in their performance damaged creditor, and no promise was made at meeting that debtor would merge into corporation.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against corporation which had been involved in merger negotiations with debtor to recover debtor's outstanding obligation after merger was called off.  On corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Motz, J., held that: (1) corporation was not estopped from denying liability as result of representations it purportedly made to creditor during course of merger negotiations; (2) representations purportedly made by corporation could not serve as predicate for claim of fraud under either Maryland or Georgia law; and (3) creditor failed to establish any bad faith on the part of corporation in preventing fulfillment of conditions precedent to merger such that it could pierce the corporate veil to hold corporation liable for debtor's obligation. Summary judgment granted. Judgment affirmed, 823 F.2d 548.

Title: In re B & L Laboratories, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, corporation was "alter ego" or "instrumentality" of shareholders, so that shareholders were personally liable for its debts, where corporation was closely held by three shareholders, failed to obtain minimum capital stated in its charter, failed to receive consideration for stock when issued, failed to hold annual shareholders' meetings, failed to maintain accurate minutes of shareholders' and directors' meetings, made loans to directors and officers without formal shareholder approval, and systematically diverted its assets to shareholders and partnerships in which they were members to detriment of creditors. T.C.A. §§ 48-1-204(2), 48-1-505(f), 48-1-716(a)(2), 48-1-814, 48-1-815(a)(2)(D).

Title: Matter of Reading Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Scrutiny of corporate form by courts may be available not only for purpose of holding corporation liable for debts of its parent or subsidiary, but also to allow creditors of that corporation to reach assets of parent or subsidiary.
Document Preview: Prereorganization petition of reorganized railroad to both disaffirm lease and collect damages for breach of lease came before court. The District Court, Ditter, J., held that: (1) basis for ignoring corporate distinction between reorganized railroad and another railroad which would permit reorganized railroad to reject lease entered into by other railroad did not exist, and (2) reorganization court lacked jurisdiction to consider reorganized railroad's claims that lessee breached provisions of lease of which it was third-party beneficiary. Order accordingly.

Title: George A. Hormel & Co. v. Ford
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Court may ignore corporate fiction, pierce corporate veil, and hold shareholder liable for debts incurred by corporation when shareholder practices fraud or other misconduct upon third person through corporation or disregards corporate entity to such extent that corporation is indistinguishable from its shareholders. LSA-R.S. 12:93-12:95; LSA-C.C. arts. 435, 437.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor brought action against corporation and shareholders for amount due under purchase contract.  The Nineteenth Judicial District Court, Parish of East Baton Rouge, Paul B. Landry, Jr., J., held shareholders personally liable on contract, and shareholders appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Ponder, J., Retired, held that shareholders could properly be determined to be personally liable for debt, where they depleted corporate checking account for specific purpose of avoiding payment of check issued to creditor. Affirmed.

Title: Rose v. Intercontinental Bank, N.A.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Corporate officer/shareholder was properly held liable, on alter-ego theory, for overdrafts on corporate accounts; officer/shareholder knew that bank relied upon his assurance and credit when account was overdrawn, payments on his personal property had been made from corporate account, and there was evidence that, absent his personal use of account, corporation could have successfully wound up its business.
Document Preview: Bank brought action against corporate officer/shareholder, seeking to recover overdraft on corporate account on alter-ego theory.  The 80th District Court, Harris County, Weldon H. Berry, J., entered judgment in favor of bank, and officer/shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Hoyt, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to establish that officer/shareholder showed bad faith such as to render him liable under alter-ego doctrine; (2) evidence of witness' alleged criminal conduct was not admissible; and (3) witness could not give personal opinion as to officer/shareholder's character. Affirmed.

Title: Inryco, Inc. v. CGR Bldg. Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Knowledge of sales representative of creditor that general partnership had incorporated would not be imputed to the creditor, for purposes of determining whether corporate veil should be pierced to permit creditor to recover against partners who became shareholders when the partnership incorporated, where sales representative failed to communicate his knowledge of fact that partnership had incorporated to creditor's credit management personnel, and sales representative had acquired shares in an alter ego of the debtor corporation, as sales representative had interests adverse to those of creditor concerning extension of credit to debtor corporation and had acted adversely to the creditor.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against corporation and its three shareholders for corporate indebtedness.  The United States District Court for the District of Wyoming, Clarence A. Doyle, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Wyoming law, shareholders, who had been general partners in corporation as general partnership before corporation was incorporated remained personally liable for corporate debt; (2) under Wyoming law, individual shareholder defendants were estopped from asserting limited liability; and (3) under Wyoming law, knowledge of sales representative of creditor of the incorporation of the partnership would not be imputed to creditor. Affirmed.

Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Fourth District.
Headnote: Generally, directors and officers of corporation are not individually liable for debts and contracts of corporation except where director or officer has personally guaranteed corporation's obligation so as to assume liability as guarantor and where director or officer has demonstrated disregard of corporate form, treating corporation essentially as conduit for personal business affairs.

Johnson, J., granted judgment against corporate officer individually for unpaid commissions plus costs, and officer appealed. Title: Chase v. Gilbert
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: Court's refusal to pierce corporate veil to impose individual liability for attorney's fees incurred in license application on principal in broadcasting company was proper, where attorney had advised principal to select corporate form to improve likelihood of application approval, and principal claimed he selected corporate form to insulate himself from personal liability.
Document Preview: Lawyer filed action against broadcasting company for fees incurred in representing company in application for radio license.  The Superior Court, District of Columbia, John F. Doyle, J., awarded attorney compensation for services connected with application including ministers' issue, found attorney was not entitled to quantum meruit, and dismissed defendant's counterclaim for legal malpractice.  Both parties appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Rogers, J., held that: (1) attorney was not entitled to recover in quantum meruit for reasonable value of services rendered to corporation; (2) finding that evidence was insufficient to pierce corporate veil and render president of corporation personally liable was proper; (3) there was meeting of minds regarding particular fee agreement for attorney; and (4) dismissal of legal malpractice claim was proper. Affirmed.

Title: Cargill, Inc. v. Hedge
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Family farm corporation was alter ego of its owner-occupants, and therefore owners were entitled to use reverse pierce of corporate entity to assert homestead exemption against judgment creditor of one owner.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from ruling of the District Court, Lyon County, Walter H. Mann, J., that owners had right to exempt acreage constituting their homestead from execution.  The Court of Appeals, 358 N.W.2d 490, affirmed, and petition for review was granted.  The Supreme Court, Simonett, J., held that family farm corporation was alter ego of its owner-occupants, and therefore owners were entitled to use reverse pierce of corporate entity to assert homestead exemption against judgment creditor of one owner. Affirmed.

Title: In re Botten
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Veil of corporate debtor would be pierced to hold individual debtor liable for debts of corporate debtor, under Wisconsin law, where individual debtor was president, director and stockholder of corporate debtor, intermingled corporation's accounts with accounts from other corporations, did not often keep records of delivery, and mixed oil products from separate corporations.
Document Preview: Jobber brought adversary proceeding objecting to debt allegedly owed it by corporate and individual debtors. The Bankruptcy Court, William H. Frawley, J., held that: (1) veil of corporate debtor would be pierced to hold individual debtor liable for debts of corporate debtor, where individual debtor was president, director and stockholder of corporate debtor and intermingled corporation's accounts with accounts from other corporations, and (2) jobber, who contracted with individual debtor to have corporate debtor to become an associate jobber, established that resulting debt was nondischargeable as to both corporate and individual debtors under section which excepts from discharge a debt for money obtained by false pretenses, false representation or actual fraud. Order accordingly.

Title: Raynor v. American States Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Vice-president of corporation could not be held personally liable for the corporation's indebtedness based on "alter ego" doctrine absent evidence that vice-president used corporate entity in such a way as to make it a mere instrumentality for transaction of his own affairs.
Document Preview: Creditors brought action against corporation, its president and its vice-president to recover alleged indebtedness.  The Superior Court, DeKalb County, Weeks, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiffs, and vice-president appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Banke, C.J., held that: (1) vice-president could not be held personally liable for the corporation's indebtedness based on alter ego doctrine, and (2) vice-president could not be held liable to statute allowing judgment creditors to bring action against one or more officers or directors of the corporation to obtain relief for benefit of corporation under certain specified circumstances. Reversed.

Title: West Bldg. Materials, Inc. v. Daley
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Shareholder was not individually liable for obligation of corporation on open account with supplier of building materials, even if shareholder used some building materials for shareholder's personal benefit and corporation failed to hold regular shareholders' meetings, where there was neither commingling of corporate funds with those of any shareholders nor failure to provide separate accounts and records for corporation.
Document Preview: Supplier of building materials brought action against shareholder on open account maintained by corporation.  The Lake Charles City Court, Parish of Calcasieu, Nick Pizzolatto, Jr., J. ad hoc., entered judgment for shareholder, and supplier appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Stoker, J., held that: (1) shareholder's use of materials purchased by corporation to improve shareholder's building which housed corporation did not perpetrate fraud upon supplier; (2) shareholder's use of some of building materials purchased by corporation for shareholder's personal benefit and fact that there were no regular shareholders' meetings of corporation were insufficient to justify piercing corporate veil and holding shareholder liable for corporation's debt; and (3) shareholder's use of building materials purchased by corporation to refurbish shareholder's building did not entitle supplier to recover against shareholder on theory of unjust enrichment. Affirmed.

Title: In re Tampa Chain Co., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate debtor's assets could not be marshalled with assets of shareholders/guarantors of corporate debt on the alter ego theory or the inadequate capitalization doctrine, where books and records distinguished debtor's assets from those of shareholders/guarantors, and where debtor did not remain undercapitalized after one shareholder/guarantor commenced contributing fairly large sums to debtor's capital.
Document Preview: Secured creditor sought order directing trustee to turn over proceeds of debtor's inventory, and trustee sought marshalling order requiring creditor to first proceed against shareholders/guarantors of debt to creditor.  The Bankruptcy Court, Howard C. Buschman, III, J., held that: (1) fraud and inequitable conduct of shareholders warranted treating shareholders and corporate debtor as a common debtor, so as to allow marshalling of assets, where debtor's capitalization was removed and replenished by one shareholder, assets were transferred by shareholders to another family corporation, and corporate funds were used to redeem personal jewelry of second shareholder; (2) trustee failed to establish by preponderance of credible evidence the defense of payment of portion of amount claimed due on loan; and (3) creditor was entitled to attorney fees for action seeking turnover of proceeds of collateral. Order accordingly.

Title: In re Western World Funding, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Agreement between president and vice-president of corporation, and managing director and his partner, who controlled that and several corporations, was merely an agreement to agree some time in future to a sharing of profits; therefore, since there was no present partnership contract, express or implied, there could not be partnership liability on part of president and vice-president on theory that any such partnership was alter ego of corporations and thus was liable for corporations' debts.
Document Preview: Debtor corporations' trustee brought suit against officers and directors of corporations for, inter alia, conversion of corporation funds.  The Bankruptcy Court, Robert Clive Jones, J., held that: (1) officers and directors breached fiduciary duty to corporation by converting corporate funds to their own use; (2) managing director was not entitled to set off against his liability for conversion a credit for the reasonable value of his services; (3) doctrines of ratification, estoppel and waiver did not apply; and (4) evidence supported finding that officers and directors were engaged in a joint venture partnership, and that the partnership, as well as the individual members, were the alter egos of the debtor corporations, and as such were liable for the corporations' debts. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1060 Debts and obligations of corporation in general >
Title: In re Western World Funding, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Officers and directors of five corporations, as well as partnership consisting of each of them, were liable for the corporations' debts as alter egos of the corporations under Nevada law; all of the officers and directors influenced and governed the corporations, there was unity of interest and ownership, in that each freely took funds from the corporations as if the funds were their own, with approval of others, and corporations were never established on an adequate financial basis, so that it would promote an injustice, if not sanction a fraud, if separate existence of the corporations were recognized.
Document Preview: Debtor corporations' trustee brought suit against officers and directors of corporations for, inter alia, conversion of corporation funds.  The Bankruptcy Court, Robert Clive Jones, J., held that: (1) officers and directors breached fiduciary duty to corporation by converting corporate funds to their own use; (2) managing director was not entitled to set off against his liability for conversion a credit for the reasonable value of his services; (3) doctrines of ratification, estoppel and waiver did not apply; and (4) evidence supported finding that officers and directors were engaged in a joint venture partnership, and that the partnership, as well as the individual members, were the alter egos of the debtor corporations, and as such were liable for the corporations' debts. Judgment accordingly.

Title: Mesler v. Bragg Management Co.
Court: Supreme Court of California, In Bank.
Headnote: A judgment obtained against corporation and its alter ego is enforceable against both separately; thus, when a plaintiff settles with only subsidiary, parent's liability continues.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought personal injury action.  The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, John A. Shidler, J., granted defendant's motion for summary judgment, and plaintiff appealed.  The Supreme Court, Mosk, J., held that: (1) trial court should have allowed plaintiff to amend pleading to plead alter-ego theory, and (2) plaintiff's settlement with corporation did not bar plaintiff from proceeding against alter ego of corporation. Reversed. Lucas, J., filed a dissenting opinion.

Title: Oman Intern. Finance Ltd. v. Hoiyong Gems Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Fact that individual owned both Rhode Island corporation and New York corporation did not warrant disregard of separate corporate entities and imposition of liability on Rhode Island corporation for debt allegedly incurred by New York corporation.
Document Preview: Lender brought action seeking to hold Rhode Island corporation liable as guarantor on debt subsequent to default by debtor that was owned by New York corporation.  The District Court, Selya, J., held that: (1) Rhode Island corporation did not guaranty debt; (2) Rhode Island corporation was not liable for debt as mere continuation or extension of New York corporation; and (3) fact that Rhode Island corporation and New York corporation were owned by same individual did not warrant disregard of separate corporate identities and imposition of liability on Rhode Island corporation for alleged debt of New York corporation. Order accordingly.

Title: In re Chism
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Alabama.
Headnote: Debtor, as shareholder of corporation, was not liable as alter ego of corporation for corporation's debts, where no charter provision or statute required debtor to pay corporate debts, agreement under which debtor allegedly guaranteed corporate debts was admitted forgery, debtor only had option to become majority shareholder and had little say so in operation of corporation, and there was no indication debtor organized corporations to take advantage of creditors or to manipulate or abuse corporations or their activities to cause them to be unable to pay their debts.
Document Preview: Matter came before court on objection of Chapter 11 debtors to allowance of claims totaling approximately 1.8 million dollars filed by seven oil companies.  The Bankruptcy Court, Rodney R. Steele, J., held that: (1) pursuant to Alabama statute of frauds claims based upon alleged guarantee of debtor was void; (2) debtor could not be found liable as alter ego of corporations he founded and in which he held minority interest; and (3) notation by United States District Court judge's secretary that matter was settled was insufficient to establish existence of settlement in which debtor agreed to pay corporate debt to oil companies. Order accordingly. See also 48 B.R. 445, 50 B.R. 55.

Title: In re International Horizons, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: By order to its subsidiary to liquidate its assets, parent did not participate in management of subsidiary to extent required to pierce corporate veil and render parent liable for subsidiary's debt, where there was no evidence to show subsidiary was mere instrumentality of parent when debt was created, and no evidence of fraud or other injustice that would be protected by adherence to doctrine of corporate entity.
Document Preview: Debtor objected to proof of claim filed by creditor of debtor's subsidiary. The Bankruptcy Court, W. Homer Drake, J., held that: (1) creditor of debtor's subsidiary was barred under Georgia's statute of frauds from recovering from debtor on alleged assumption of debt, and (2) by order to subsidiary to liquidate its assets, parent did not participate in management of subsidiary to extent required to pierce corporate veil and render parent liable for subsidiary's debt. Objection sustained.

Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Courts will disregard corporate form or "pierce the corporate veil," and extend liability for corporate obligations beyond confines of corporation's separate entity whenever necessary to prevent fraud or achieve equity.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, 67 N.C.App. 563, 313 S.E.2d 832, granted new trial.  Sublessees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Reversed.

Title: In re Stop & Go of America, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Power to consolidate corporations should be used sparingly because of possibility of unfair treatment of creditors of a corporate debtor who have dealt solely with that debtor without knowledge of its relationship with others.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 trustee filed amended complaint seeking legal title to certain franchise contracts and property rights, and to avoid purported lien asserted by creditor on assets.  In addition, trustee requested substantive consolidation of corporate debtor and another corporation on basis of nonobservance of corporate formalities, lack of legitimate business purpose or joint venture.  The Bankruptcy Court, Harold Lavien, J., held that Chapter 11 trustee was entitled to substantive consolidation of debtor corporation and another corporation, where other corporation was a totally inactive shell which was constructed as a deliberate scheme to protect interest of seller of franchise to debtor by insuring its status as sole creditor of legal titleholder of franchise, the shell corporation, in a manner likely to result in fraud to other creditors because of concealment of relationship. Judgment for trustee on Counts II, III and IV.

Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: Where corporation had sufficient assets, though probably not cash on hand, to pay creditor's claim, corporate veil could not be pierced to hold individual officers and shareholders liable on claim against corporation.

Hill, C.J., concurred in judgment only.

Headnote: Debtor, individually, was liable for debts of his corporation if debts were found to be nondischargeable where debtor at all times operated his business as a sole proprietor despite existence of a corporate charter.

Judgment accordingly.

Title: Entech Systems Corp. v. Gaffney
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: If a sole shareholder fails to conduct business on a corporate footing in such a manner that corporation's identity cannot be distinguished from that of the shareholder, then corporation can be determined to be the "alter ego" of the shareholder, and shareholder will be personally liable for corporate debt.
Document Preview: Distributor of water treatment device brought breach of contract and negligent representation action against corporate manufacturer, its sole shareholder and second corporation allegedly controlled by that shareholder.  The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Joseph V. Dirosa, J., entered summary judgment for shareholder and second corporation, and distributor appealed. The Court of Appeal, Williams, J., held that affidavit by certified public accountant indicating undercapitalization of manufacturer, commingling of funds between two corporations, and disregard of corporate identities raised genuine issue of fact as to integrity of manufacturer's corporate identity, precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Harris v. Best of America Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: There are limited exceptions to rule of nonliability of shareholders for debts of a corporation whereby court may ignore corporate fiction and hold individual liable; in such situations, a litigant can reach an individual shareholder by piercing the corporate veil, thereby rendering the individual liable for the debts incurred by corporation.
Document Preview: Contractor and its president appealed from the Twenty-Second Judicial District Court, Parish of Washington, James R. Strain, Jr., J., which determined that owner was entitled to recover certain damages for faulty work under construction contract.  The Court of Appeal, Carter, J., held that: (1) stipulated damages provided in contract did not limit award of damages to owner for faulty workmanship; (2) trial court properly relied upon testimony of plaintiff's experts in determining award of damages; and (3) totality of facts did not support a finding that corporation had ceased to exist as an entity, separate and distinct from its sole shareholder, so as to pierce corporate veil to hold shareholder liable on contract with plaintiff. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: A parent corporation and a subsidiary are in law separate and distinct entities, and under ordinary circumstances a contract in terms and in name with one corporation cannot be treated as that of both, and a parent corporation will not be liable for the obligations of its subsidiaries.

Title: Flanagan v. Jackson Wholesale Bldg. Supply Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Wife of deceased owner of home building and remodeling corporation which had its corporate charter revoked was not personally liable for business debts as a "person who assumes to act as a corporation" because she was not actively involved in the control and management of the organization, notwithstanding the fact that she was director and incorporator of the former corporation, business finances were intertwined with her household, and she regularly performed services for the business. Code 1972, § 79-3-285.
Document Preview: Building supply company brought action against home building and remodeling business and wife of its deceased owner, individually and as administratrix of owner's estate.  The Circuit Court of Madison County, R.L. Goza, J., entered judgment against wife, and she appealed.  The Supreme Court, Prather, J., held that wife was not liable for debts incurred after revocation of corporate charter, because she was not so personally involved in management and control of the business as to come under statute establishing liability of persons assuming to act as a corporation. Reversed and rendered.

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: An actual fraud need not be perpetrated upon creditors as a prerequisite to piercing a corporate veil.

Title: Ward v. Cooper
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. II.
Headnote: Where there was no fraud practiced against plaintiff by corporation president and president had scrupulously observed requirements of law in operation of two corporations but president dominated and controlled operation of the two corporations, used funds from subject corporation to benefit other corporation, and effected repurchase of stock in subject corporation order to avoid future personal liability, and where president's actions in regard to such corporations operated to defeat plaintiff's legitimate claim against corporation, alter ego doctrine was properly invoked to impose liability on president for corporate debt to plaintiff.

Title: Baker v. Caravan Moving Corp.

Headnote: Corporate judgment debtor's affiliate, which held the only asset of value of the judgment debtor, was liable for the judgment, since both corporations functioned as a common enterprise.
Document Preview: Pension fund trustees brought suit to satisfy a judgment obtained against corporate judgment debtor for failure to make monthly health and welfare contributions as required by a collective bargaining agreement and multiemployer plan under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. On motion of the trustees for summary judgment to enforce their judgment against a holding company and against the president and sole shareholder of both the holding company and the judgment debtor, the District Court, Aspen, J., held that: (1) corporate judgment debtor's affiliate, which held the only asset of value of the judgment debtor, was liable for the judgment, since both corporations functioned as a common enterprise, and (2) the Illinois Wage Payment Collection Act, insofar as it applies to employer contributions to employee benefit plans, is preempted by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. Headnote: Facts that parent owned 100% of stock in subsidiary, parent and subsidiary filed joint tax return, there were interlocking officers and directors, and one loaned money to another did not, in and of themselves, defeat their separate existence so as to allow piercing of corporate veil to hold parent corporation liable for debts of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Creditor brought suit attempting to pierce corporate veil of subsidiary in order to hold parent corporation liable for debts owed to creditor. The Court of Appeals, E. Grady Jolly, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Texas law, a finding of fraud, injustice or some form of bad-faith dealing is not required before a court may pierce corporate veil; it is sufficient to show that subsidiary existed as mere agent or conduit of parent, and (2) subsidiary had no separate corporate existence, and therefore creditor was entitled to pierce corporate veil in order to hold parent corporation liable for debts owed creditor. Court: United States District Court, S. D. Florida, Miami Division.
Headnote: Where business reality regarding corporate structure of debtors was that of a singular economic enterprise which was recognized as such not only by those associated with the organization, but by those who dealt with it, although vendors may have communicated exclusively with Florida portion of debtor companies, the existence of Texas corporation and the paper transfer of assets from the Florida financing arm to the Texas corporation were not factors infringing upon trustee's ability to prevail in a suit to void certain transactions as preferential transfers. Bankr.Act, §§ 60, 60(a, b), 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 96, 96(a, b).
Document Preview: Trustee in bankruptcy filed complaint alleging voidable preferences. The District Court, Hoeveler, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to establish that the vendors received a greater percentage of debts than others of the same class for purposes of preferential transfer provisions of Bankruptcy Act; (2) where none of the transactions challenged as preferential transfers by trustee were entered into on a cash or COD basis, and all of those transactions were on terms of ten days or longer, the extensions of credit gave rise to an antecedent debt for purposes of preferential transfer provisions of Bankruptcy Act; (3) testimony of trustee's expert witness established that debtors were insolvent at the time of challenged transactions, despite conflicting expert testimony that debtors were not insolvent prior to creditor's demand for payment of a loan; and (4) evidence established that each of the nine vendor defendants had reasonable cause to believe that debtors were insolvent...

Title: In re Snider Bros., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Creditor may be estopped from asserting reliance on corporate separateness of debtors where such a claim would be unreasonable in light of all the facts.
Document Preview: Creditors committees for six corporate debtors, which comprised family-run integrated business operation involving purchasing and slaughtering of beef cattle and the processing and sale of meat, sought consolidation of all of debtors assets and liabilities, as well as elimination of all intercorporate debts. The Bankruptcy Court, Paul W. Glennon, J., held that consolidation of estates of such debtors was not warranted under circumstances which, though there had been frequency of intercorporate transactions, loans, direct sales and guarantees, each debtor had kept separate records, creditors committee only generally alleged that they would be harmed by continued separation of estates, use of single bookkeeping staff was not shown to have prejudiced creditors, debtors had ceased doing business and possibility of consolidated sale of all of debtors' assets was remote. Request denied.

Title: Fenick v. Robertson
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Individual liability of a corporate officer for corporate obligations may be imposed upon a showing that the relationship between the individual and the corporation was completely personalized, i.e., that the individual was the sole beneficiary of the corporation's activities, directed and managed its activities, and used the corporate name at his pleasure.
Document Preview: In suit seeking to recover upon a promissory note, in replevin, and damages, the Palm Beach County Circuit Court, Rosemary Barkett, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiffs, and defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Downey, J., held that although the corporate defendant was a legitimately organized corporation, the individual defendant operated it as a sole proprietorship, where he testified that he decided to turn over to another corporation, of which his son was president, the computer equipment in question, which constituted the sole assets of his corporation, at no charge except that his son's corporation would be responsible for maintenance of the equipment; accordingly, the trial court properly found that defendant was individually liable because the corporate defendant was his alter ego. Affirmed.

Title: U.S. v. Thomas
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Corporate existence should be disregarded to prevent fraud, illegality, or injustice or when recognition of corporate debt would defeat public policy.
Document Preview: United States brought suit against medicare provider and its sole shareholder. On motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Spears, J., held that: (1) statute governing judicial review did not authorize judicial review of pre-1973 provider reimbursement decisions; (2) judicial review was barred because defendants failed to exhaust, prior to initiation of lawsuit, congressionally prescribed procedures for reviewing pre-1973 provider reimbursement claim; (3) administrative decision was not arbitrary, capricious, or otherwise not in accordance with law; (4) sole shareholder could be held personally liable for overpayments to hospital under so-called trust fund doctrine; and (5) piercing of corporate veil was appropriate. Government's motion for summary judgment granted.

Title: U.S. v. Pisani
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether a physician should be held liable for medicare overpayments made to his solely-owned corporation, factors to be considered are whether the corporation is grossly undercapitalized for its purposes, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at the time, siphoning of funds of the corporation by dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, absent corporate record, and fact that the corporation is merely a facade for operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders; also, the situation must present an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: The Government brought action against physician to recover medicare overpayments made to physician's solely-owned corporation. The United States District Court for the District of New Jersey, Anne E. Thompson, J., entered judgment for the Government, and physician appealed. The Court of Appeals, Van Dusen, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) federal, rather than New Jersey, law controlled; (2) the corporate veil was to be pierced and physician was personally liable for the overpayment; (3) the action was not barred by statute of limitations or laches; and (4) the Department of Health, Education and Welfare was entitled to use cost data for a facility which it considered to be comparable in determining amount of overpayment, and such determination was not arbitrary or capricious. Affirmed.

Title: U.S. v. Healthwin-Midtown Convalescent Hospital and Rehabilitation Center, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C. D. California.
Headnote: Where individual defendant was former president and owner of 50% of stock of provider of services under Medicare Act, alone controlled provider's operations, and caused undercapitalized provider's finances to become inextricably intertwined with both his personal finances and his other business holdings and where operations of provider were marked by essential disregard of corporate formalities, corporate entity would be disregarded under alter ego theory of liability under California law and individual defendant would be held personally liable to United States for Medicare overpayments to provider. Social Security Act, § 1801 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 1395 et seq.
Document Preview: United States brought suit to recover Medicare funds paid to provider of services under Medicare Act. The District Court, Maletz, J., of the United States Court of International Trade, sitting by designation, held that the individual defendant, the former president of the provider and owner of 50% of its stock, was proximately liable for the overpayments made to the provider, where individual defendant, had 50% interest in partnership which owned both realty in which provider's health care facility was located and furnishings used at that facility, had signed provider's checks without prior approval of another corporate officer, and in effect controlled corporation's operations and where provider was undercapitalized and individual defendant had caused provider's finances to become inextricably intertwined with both his personal finances and his other business holdings, thus making it appropriate to pierce corporation's veil. Judgment for plaintiff.

Court: Supreme Court of Idaho.
Headnote: In action to hold sole director-shareholder personally liable for corporate debt, undercapitalization of corporation, alone, would not justify piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: Corporation's creditor brought action to hold director-shareholder personally liable for corporate debt. The District Court, Fifth Judicial District, Twin Falls County, Theron W. Affirmed.

Title: FMC Finance Corp. v. Murphree
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Creditor has a duty to first ascertain creditworthiness of corporation he voluntarily deals with, and assumes the risk of possible default by that corporation when he extends credit; however, when the shareholder or affiliate engages in conduct likely to create in the creditor the reasonable expectation that he is extending credit to an economic entity larger than the corporation he actually contracted with, and the creditor reasonably relies to his detriment on his reasonable belief concerning who or what he was dealing with, then the corporate veil can be pierced.
Document Preview: Suit was brought to enforce an unconditional personal guaranty contract of payment which covered payment of monies that a closely held Georgia corporation owed to plaintiff under an equipment lease agreement. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi, at Clarksdale, Orma R. Smith, J., directed a verdict for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Sam D. Johnson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) warranty disclaimer language was conspicuous and thus validly negated any implied warranties on the part of plaintiff; (2) warranty disclaimer clause was not unconscionable; and (3) there was sufficient evidence to create a jury question on the corporate disregard issue raised by defendants, who attempted to assert against plaintiff the affirmative defense of its parent corporation's breach of manufacturer's warranty of repair or replacement of the leased buses. Affirmed in part, reversed and remanded in part.

Title: Northern Illinois Gas Co. v. Total Energy Leasing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Service corporation, stock of which was wholly owned by a second corporation the stock of which, in turn, was wholly owned by a third corporation, was a mere instrumentality of the third corporation, the parent, for purpose of holding the latter liable for natural gas purchased by the service corporation where there were common directors and officers, the parent financed the purchaser, which was grossly undercapitalized, and incorporated second corporation solely to own the purchaser and paid salaries and other expenses of purchaser, important business dealings were conducted in name of the parent and it used purchaser's property as its own and formal legal requirements were not observed.
Document Preview: Utility which had furnished natural gas to subsidiary sued parent corporation seeking to pierce the corporate veil. Utility moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Flaum, J., held that: (1) applicable Turner factors were present in proper combination to conclude that subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of parent, and (2) the two remaining elements necessary to pierce corporate veil were present, i. e., fraud or wrong by the parent through the subsidiary in stripping subsidiary of its assets and unjust loss or injury to the utility in view of insolvence of the subsidiary. Motion granted.

Headnote: Separate entity doctrine will be disregarded when its application would serve to allow an evasion of an obligation created prior to existence of corporation or where application would void defenses which a maker of a note would have against a corporate payee because owner of corporation claimed to be a holder in due course by virtue of his endorsement thereon.

Title: Truckweld Equipment Co., Inc. v. Olson
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 2.
Headnote: Where informality with which corporation was operated did not prejudice or mislead supplier of hauling equipment in its consideration of corporation's credit application, sole shareholder of corporation intended that corporate formalities be observed, but instructions were not carried out, supplier would not have been in any different position even if corporation had meticulously documented its corporate actions and there was no injustice to supplier from mere fact that corporation was unable eventually to pay for assembly and modification of hauling equipment, supplier did not present characteristic injustice to justify piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Supplier of hauling equipment filed action against sole shareholder of corporation to recover pursuant to contract for modification and assembly of hauling equipment for corporation. The Superior Court, Pierce County, Stanley W. Worswick, J., denied the claim, and supplier appealed. The Court of Appeals, Reed, C. J., held that even though the issue of whether the corporate entity should be disregarded in order to impose liability on the sole shareholder was a close question, such was question of fact, and the trial court's determination was supported by substantial evidence that there had been no such wrongful conduct as to justify piercing the corporate veil on theory of injustice, that the thin capitalization did not manifest a fraudulent intent, and that the supplier's loss was caused by its own failure to utilize safeguards rather than any misconduct or abuse of corporate form by the sole shareholder. Affirmed.

Headnote: Where there was no evidence of fraud in formation of corporation, and where whatever loss the corporation's creditor has suffered or might suffer could have been mitigated entirely by securing itself to extent that law would allow, and where resolution was passed which provided that pursuant to notice and to its bylaws the president or secretary-treasurer be authorized to effect loans, advances and renewals at any time for the corporation and that certified copy of resolution shall be delivered to creditor bank, stockholders complied with corporate formalities and, thus, maintained separateness of entity.
Document Preview: Bank made claim for stock certificates on grounds that stock was security for corporate loans and guarantor's surviving heirs claimed that stock was released as security upon payment of indebtedness on original loan. The Clark Circuit Court, James S. Chenault, J., held that debtors and guarantors should pay amount of original loan to individuals which pledge secured, and debtors and administrator of guarantor appealed. The Court of Appeals, Martin, C. J., held that: (1) debtors signed later notes in corporate rather than individual capacity; (2) corporate veil would not be pierced, and (3) evidence presented material issue of fact as to whether renewal notes constituted novation so as to release original debtors, thus, precluding summary judgment. Reversed.

Title: Brunswick Corp. v. Waxman
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Where seller of bowling alley equipment knowingly entered into conditional sales contracts with no-asset corporation which was created for the sole purpose of taking title to the equipment, and investigated to determine whether bowling alleys operated by the owners of the corporation in partnership capacity were likely to generate revenues sufficient to make payments for the equipment, seller did not bargain for or contemplate the individual liability of the owners of the corporation, and piercing of the corporate veil would not accomplish justice or equity, and thus corporate entity would not be disregarded in suit against the individuals to recover deficiencies following default on the contracts and repossession and resale of the equipment.
Document Preview: Seller of bowling alley equipment sued officers and shareholders of corporate buyer to recover deficiencies after repossession and resale of the equipment. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, John R. Bartels, J., 459 F.Supp. 1222, dismissed the complaint and entered judgment for defendants, and seller appealed. The Court of Appeals, Mulligan, Circuit Judge, held that piercing the corporate veil would not accomplish justice or equity, and thus the corporate entity would not be disregarded, where seller knowingly entered into conditional sales contracts with no-asset corporation created for the sole purpose of taking title to the equipment and investigated to determine whether bowling alleys operated by defendants in partnership capacity were likely to generate revenues sufficient to make payments for the equipment, and thus did not bargain for or contemplate the individual liability of the officers and shareholders of the corporation. Affirmed.

Title: Colandrea v. Colandrea
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Where president of corporation and sole shareholder fraudulently transferred business of original corporation to subsequent corporation and patently misrepresented in stock reduction agreement and promissory notes that debt would be paid to her former husband, president's dealings, through the corporation, with her former husband, were fraudulent and barren corporate entity would be disregarded and liability imposed upon president and sole shareholder.
Document Preview: Former shareholder of original corporation sought recovery from remaining shareholder and subsequently formed corporations of payment of promissory notes. The Circuit Court, Howard County, Robert F. Fischer, J., found that shareholder would not be personally liable upon the notes but that corporations were liable, and appeals were taken. The Court of Special Appeals, Couch, J., held that: (1) corporate veil would be pierced and sole shareholder found liable for payment of notes, and (2) subsequently formed corporations would be liable for fraudulent acts of sole shareholder under circumstances of case. Reversed in part and remanded in part and affirmed in part.

Title: Hale v. Parmenter Ins. Agency, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In action by sole proprietor claiming funds which were garnished pursuant to judgment against corporation, court was authorized to consider that proprietorship and corporation were involved in same type of business, that both did business on the same premises, both had same telephone number and used the same office equipment, that both had basically same employees and carried same utility bill account numbers, that inventories of both were commingled, that majority of vehicles of corporation was sold either to individual proprietor or his relatives, and that loan of corporation, as well as other corporate debts, was paid out of proprietorship assets, and to determine that proprietorship and corporation were one and the same for purposes of enforcement of judgment against corporation, and thus it was not error to render judgment in favor of judgment creditor on proprietor's claim to garnish funds.
Document Preview: In hearing on claim by sole proprietor to funds garnished pursuant to judgment against corporation, the Superior Court, Bartow County, White, J., entered judgment in favor of judgment creditor and sole proprietor appealed. J., held that: (1) court was authorized to determine that sole proprietorship and corporation were one and the same, and thus it was not error to render judgment in favor of judgment creditor on proprietor's claim to garnished funds, and (2) where sole proprietor testified that corporation had ceased doing business, testimony to agreement between shareholders to cease operations would have been cumulative, and thus no harmful error was shown in sustaining objection to such testimony. Affirmed.

Headnote: While debts of corporation are not individual indebtedness of its stockholders, in an appropriate case corporate form will be disregarded and corporation and its stockholders may be treated as identical.

The Court of Appeals, Abbott, J., held that: (1) trial court erred in excluding evidence tending to show an independent warranty by selling agent; (2) evidence as to alleged independent warranty by selling agent and as to whether selling agent was alter ego of manufacturer was sufficient for jury, and (3) trial court correctly instructed jury concerning damages which included damages for special circumstances as well as incidental and consequential damages. Judgment affirmed as to plaintiff and reversed as to defendant selling agent.

Title: Amsted Industries, Inc. v. Pollak Industries, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Record showing, inter alia, that loans made by sole shareholder to two close corporations he owned and controlled were paid back, that shareholder did not borrow money from corporation which owed debt to third party and that shareholder did not borrow excessive amount of money from other corporation and intended to pay back what he did borrow established no intermingling of personal and corporate funds so as to render shareholder liable for debt owed third party.

The Appellate Court, Simon, J., held that: (1) that sole shareholder controlled and dominated two corporations and was their sole source of equity financing did not render him personally liable for cost of machinery; (2) that two corporations may have been operated as one corporation did not establish shareholder's liability for debt and (3) factual issue existed as to whether corporate buyer and other related corporation were mere alter egos of shareholder precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Title: American Kitchen Foods, Inc. v. Hersch Cold Storage Co.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: A "unitary enterprise" finding is one which prevents debtor from using fiction of separate corporation to shield real owner of enterprise or related corporations from liability, but such finding is never applicable to bar creditor from asserting his rights.
Document Preview: Owner of frozen potato products which were stored in public warehouse owned by sister entity of food distributor brought conversion action against distributor's creditor, which sold potato products at distress sale, and buyer of potato products. After partial summary judgment order was entered by district court, 435 F.Supp. 1127, against defendants, creditor and buyer moved for reconsideration and for leave to enlarge record. The District Court, Weber, Chief Judge, held that: (1) Uniform Commercial Code section dealing with situation where goods are delivered to person under name other than name of person making delivery did not apply; (2) theory of unitary business enterprise did not bar owner's claim, and (3) warehouse receipts issued by sister entity of food distributor were valid and protected owner's interest in bailed potato products. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Berlinger's, Inc. v. Beef's Finest, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil was properly pierced and personal liability for corporate obligation was properly imposed upon individual who was its president and sole shareholder, where president had complete management and control, no directors' or shareholder's meetings were held, president's investment in corporation was inadequate given corporation's expenses, president failed to offer any legitimate excuse as to why he could not produce records supporting his statement that 18-year-old employee, given carte blanche to sign president's name on any checks, issued stop payment order due to accounting error resulting in insufficient funds in corporate account, and president told seller bad check would be paid.
Document Preview: Meat wholesaler brought action against corporate purchaser and individual who was corporation's president and sole shareholder to recover monies due for meat sales. The Circuit Court, Cook County, James D. Crosson, J. P., entered judgment against corporate purchaser and its president, and president appealed. The Appellate Court, Johnson, P. J., held that: (1) under circumstances, corporate veil was properly pierced and personal liability for corporation's obligations was properly imposed upon corporate president, and (2) wholesaler's application for credit form, bearing name of corporate purchaser as credit applicant and bearing what was purportedly signature of corporate president was admissible as a business record. Affirmed.

Title: Peterson v. Harville
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: Incorporators of defendant corporation who were aware of transaction by which another corporation transferred its major asset, an interest in a land contract, to the major shareholder in the other corporation who then transferred that interest to the defendant corporation could not hide behind the corporate veil of the defendant corporation to avoid personal liability with respect to debt which had been owed by the other corporation and which had been assumed by the defendant corporation as a result of the land transaction.
Document Preview: Persons who had made loans to a corporation brought an action against the incorporator of that corporation, against a second corporation to which the first corporation's chief asset, an interest in land, had been transferred, and against the incorporators of that second corporation. The District Court, Skopil, Chief Judge, held that: (1) under the facts of this case, the second corporation became liable for the debt owed to the lenders by the first corporation; (2) under the facts of this case, it would be inequitable to permit the incorporators to hide behind the corporate veil to avoid personal liability; (3) even though note called for repayment of loan at 100% Interest and even though, since the total amount was in excess of $50,000, the note was not usurious under Oregon law, it would be inequitable to grant lenders judgment for $200, and (4) lenders would recover the $100,000 which they had lent plus 6% Interest. Order accordingly.

Title: In re County Green Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Virginia, Charlottesville Division.
Headnote: Thin capitalization is normally an independent basis for piercing the corporate veil in order to hold corporate shareholders liable or to subject their property to the debts of creditors.
Document Preview: On appeal of mechanic's lienors from a judgment of the bankruptcy court holding invalid the liens on certain property owned by the bankrupt debtor, the District Court, Turk, Chief Judge, held that the bankruptcy court's findings that development corporation, the general contractor for debtor's apartment construction project, was not the alter ego of the debtor and that the claimed mechanic's lienors did not furnish labor and materials to the owner were clearly erroneous, since an examination of the manner in which the affairs of the development corporation were conducted made it apparent that it had no separate existence of its own and was in all respects a mere fiction and the alter ego of the debtor; e. g., its policies were not directed to its own interests but to those of the debtor and the debtor's general partners, it was undercapitalized, and it failed to keep reliable records. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Ladjevardian v. Laidlaw-Coggeshall, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: For purpose of rule that successor corporation is liable for debts of its predecessor where there is a merger or consolidation of the two firms, fact that two corporations have an identity of members of officers does not necessarily suggest that the corporations do not have a separate identity.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporations, certain officer of both corporations, and registered broker, in which plaintiffs alleged various violations of federal securities laws, and one of the corporations moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Lasker, J., held that: (1) summary judgment in favor of corporation which had purchased certain assets of other corporation was precluded by existence of factual issue as to whether buyer corporation had impliedly assumed liability for debts of seller corporation; (2) transactions between corporations did not constitute consolidation or merger; (3) buyer corporation was not a mere continuation of the seller corporation, and (4) buyer corporation did not violate securities laws with respect to corporation's handling of plaintiffs' accounts after sale of assets. Motion for summary judgment granted in part and denied in part.

Title: Ecklund v. Nevada Wholesale Lumber Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Fact that corporation's president influenced and governed the corporation, and president's use of the pronoun "we" in answer to complaint to State Contractors' Board were not ground for applying alter ego doctrine in favor of seller of materials where it did not appear that the corporation was undercapitalized, seller knew it was dealing with a corporation and could not reasonably have relied on president's personal credit and there was no showing that president used corporate shell as a conduit for his individual enterprise.

The Second Judicial District Court, Washoe County, John E. Gabrielli, J., held that president was personally liable for the debt and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Mowbray, J., held that seller failed to prove elements upon which the alter ego theory is predicated where the corporation did not appear to be undercapitalized, seller knew it was dealing with a corporation and it could not reasonably have relied on president's personal credit and there was no showing that president used corporation as a conduit for his individual enterprise. Reversed.

Title: United States v. Normandy House Nursing Home, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Individual who was medicare provider's sole stockholder and who had a lifetime beneficial interest in a trust which owned the premises upon which the provider was operated could be held liable to Government for alleged overpayments made to the medicare provider, especially where the provider had sold all of its assets and had gone out of the nursing home business at the time when the audits began so that failure to disregard the corporate entity would result in circumvention of the statutory provisions for recovery of overpayments. Health Insurance for the Aged Act, § 1801 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 1395 et seq.
Document Preview: Government brought action against nursing home which had been a medicare provider and against the sole shareholder in the nursing home to recover alleged overpayments. On pretrial motions to dismiss, the District Court, Freedman, J., held that six-year statute of limitations did not begin to run until the time that the audits of the nursing home's receipts were completed; and that where individual defendant was the sole stockholder in the nursing home, where the nursing home's premises were owned by a trust in which the individual had a lifetime beneficial interest, and where the nursing home had sold all of its assets and gone out of the nursing home business by the time that the audits were beginning, so that failure to disregard the corporate entity would lead to circumvention of statute providing for recoupment of overpayments, the individual stockholder could be held liable for the overpayments. Motions to dismiss denied.

Title: Sampay v. Davis
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Courts will not strip a principal stockholder of the shield of personal immunity from liability for corporate obligations except on the necessary showing of fraud or other misconduct in which he actually participated or is deemed to have participated through his corporate alter ego.
Document Preview: Guest passenger, allegedly injured in rear-end collision, brought suit against, among others, corporate employer of driver of the following vehicle and principal stockholder of the corporation. The latter filed exception of no right or cause of action. The Sixteenth Judicial District Court, Parish of St. Mary, No. 46,496, Robert M. Fleming, J., sustained the exception, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeal, Claiborne, J., held that postjudgment deposition of the shareholder could not be considered on appeal, that a tort claimant may proceed against the principal stockholder and his corporate alter ego without first obtaining a judgment against the corporation provided the allegations of fraud, deception and identity are otherwise adequate to state a cause of action against the stockholder and that plaintiff's allegations satisfied such requirement. Reversed and remanded for further proceedings.

Title: Rosenthal v. Leaseway of Texas, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: Corporate entity was disregarded and organizer held personally liable for its debts where he organized, controlled and managed corporation in such manner that it became his alter ego and the corporate formalities mandated by statute were ignored and if organizer's acts were to be treated as those of the corporation an inequitable result would follow, notwithstanding contention that no fraud was shown and that there was no fraudulent transfer of assets.

The 191st Judicial District Court, Dallas County, Spencer Carver, J., rendered judgment against all defendants, and two of them appealed. Title: Kingsman Enterprises, Inc. v. Bakerfield Elec. Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: There are limited exceptions to rule of nonliability of shareholders for the debts of a corporation whereby the court may ignore the corporate fiction and hold the individual member or members liable; one exception involves situations where fraud or deceit has been practiced on the third party by the shareholder acting through the corporation and another involves failure to conduct business on corporate footing, thereby disregarding the corporate entity to such an extent that the corporation ceases to be distinguishable from its shareholders. The Court of Appeal, Cole, J., held that concept of the separation of corporate entity from its shareholders is a general rule and should be disregarded only in exceptional circumstances and that shareholder was not personally liable absent showing that the corporations had ceased to exist as entities, separate and distinct from him. Affirmed.

Title: Holmes v. Clow
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: Although corporation had authorized capital of $500,000 and only sum of $1,000 was paid in, where paid-in capital was adequate at time of incorporation in view of commitment from bank for interim loan which incorporators believed sufficient to cover its debts and individual sought to be held liable to creditor of corporation as its alter ego did not misrepresent to creditor extent of capital or receive any personal benefit from blueprints supplied by creditor to corporation, corporate entity would not be disregarded and individual held personally liable to the creditor on ground that the financial setup was a mere sham.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporation and its president to recover sum for blueprinting and design work for housing project to be constructed by defendant corporation. The 160th District Court, Dallas County, Leonard E. Hoffman, Jr., J., rendered judgment in favor of plaintiff against defendant corporation but rendered take nothing judgment against individual defendant and plaintiff appealed . The Court of Civil Appeals, Moore, J., held that plaintiff failed to show fraud in forming of corporation or in corporation's making other payments while plaintiff's bill was unpaid; that plaintiff failed to establish that individual defendant had used the corporation as a sham to perpetrate a fraud, or to avoid personal liability; and that finding that the corporate entity had not ceased to exist and had not become individual defendant's alter ego was not against overwhelming weight of evidence. Affirmed.

Title: Electrical Equipment Co. v. Security Nat. Bank
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Where joint adventure for construction of office building was entered into by corporate shells of the defendant corporations the corporate shell was required to be disregarded in order to permit recovery against the defendant corporation for reasonable value of materials furnished for construction of building pursuant to the joint adventure.
Document Preview: Action was brought by furnishers of materials used in office building to recover therefor. The District Court, Pratt, J., held that agreement entered into by corporate shells on behalf of defendant corporations and individual defendants was a joint venture agreement for construction of office building and that equity demanded the piercing of corporate veils in order that the materialmen might recover from defendant corporation. Judgment for plaintiffs.

Title: Frigidaire Sales Corp. v. Union Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: When creditor of partnership deals with corporate general partner in full awareness of the corporate status of the general partner and there is no showing of any fraud, wrong and injustice perpetrated upon the creditor, the corporate entity of the general partner should be upheld. RCWA 25.08.070.
Document Preview: Creditor of partnership brought action against corporate general partner and limited partners individually when partnership failed to pay installments due on contract. The Superior Court, King County, Frank D. Howard, J., entered judgment for creditor against corporate general partner but dismissed claim against limited partners and creditor appealed. The Court of Appeals, Callow, J., held that limited partners are not liable as general partners simply because they are active officers or directors, or are stockholders of a corporate general partner in a limited partnership. Affirmed.

Title: Plaza Hotel Associates v. Wellington Associates, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term, Part I.
Headnote: Where a partnership and corporation are in fact one and the same, with the sole difference being one of form, the court ought to disregard such difference when creditor of corporation seeks to reach assets held in partnership name.
Document Preview: Partnership, alleged by plaintiff to be successor in interest of corporate judgment debtor, moved for a protective order vacating a restraining notice issued by plaintiff, the judgment creditor of the corporation, to the partnership's bank affecting its bank account, and the partnership, together with others, moved to vacate subpoenas issued by plaintiff requiring appearance for examination in aid of satisfaction for the judgment. Title: Wise Tag & Label Co. v. Swansea Products, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Where evidence demonstrated that individual defendant had organized corporate purchaser of goods for the purpose of defrauding creditors, trial court, in action against the corporate purchaser and the individual by companies which had sold and delivered goods to the corporate defendant properly disregarded the corporate entity.
Document Preview: Two sellers of goods brought actions against corporate purchaser and an individual to recover for goods sold and delivered and for damages against individual based on fraud in that the individual allegedly organized the corporate purchaser solely for the purpose of defrauding creditors. The Supreme Court, Sullivan County, entered judgment on verdicts in favor of sellers and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that evidence sustained finding that individual was guilty of fraud; that trial court properly disregarded the corporate entity; and that trial court properly held a joint trial where there were common questions of fact and law and there was no showing of prejudice to defendants. Affirmed.

Title: Computer Center, Inc. v. Vedapco, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Courts are reluctant to disregard corporate entity unless it is necessary to prevent fraud, illegality, or injustice, however corporate veil will be pierced when it is shown that corporation is mere device or sham used to mislead creditors or for fraudulent purposes.
Document Preview: A creditor brought action against a corporate debtor and the two sole stockholders of the corporate debtor upon an open account and an account stated, and brought an action for damages against the two stockholders for the value of services rendered. Title: Computer Center, Inc. v. Vedapco, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Where creditor's claim that individuals who were sole stockholders of a corporate debtor withdrew $65,000 from the corporation prior to a sale of the corporate assets was not proven, where books of the corporate debtor showed corporate indebtedness to one of the stockholders and showed that such indebtedness had not been repaid, and where the stockholders personally guaranteed the indebtedness on a building purchased by corporate debtor and used the proceeds of a subsequent sale of corporate assets to pay other creditors of the corporation, corporate veil would not be pierced so as to fix personal liability on the stockholders.
